PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide independent radio and television service.
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will

Refer the above mentioned Bill to an appropriate Parliamentary Committee and will examine the operation of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Appointment of Ambassador to Ireland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
Whereas the Hon. Brian Burke whilst serving as Premier of the State of Western Australia was also fulfilling the position of State Treasurer:
Whereas the State Treasurer is the Officer of the Parliament responsible for the oversight of Building Societies and Credit Unions, and the Superannuation Board in Western Australia:
Whereas investigations appear to be suggesting at least maladministrations and possibly illegalities in the affairs of the Superannuation Board and some Building Societies and Credit Unions:
Whereas Section 25 (Subsection 2) of the Superannuation Act states that no loans shall be made by the Superannuation Board without the approval of the State Treasurer:
And whereas it would appear that investigations to be complete would require the presence of the principal officer involved:

We would therefore humbly request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, in the interests of justice and good government, should seek to have the appointment of the Hon. Brian Burke as our Ambassador to Ireland deferred until such time as these matters are fully investigated and proved.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

In line with the Government's commitment to ensure that the National Crime Authority has all the necessary powers at its disposal to fulfil its functions, ss. 219A-K of the Customs Act 1901 are being amended to provide the NCA with the same powers as the AFP to apply for a judicial warrant for the use of a listening device in the investigation of narcotics offences.

The abuse of both legal and illegal drugs is acknowledged as one of Australia's most serious social and law enforcement problems. As exemplified by the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse, the Commonwealth Government, together with the State and Territory Governments, is committed to fighting drug abuse on both fronts.

The National Crime Authority's primary function is to assemble and furnish admissible evidence to Commonwealth and State prosecuting agencies. Its concern over drug trafficking, as a major profit earning activity of organised crime, is reflected in the fact that the majority of its eight references and of its general investigations involve drug-related offences.

In order to perform its functions effectively and efficiently, the National Crime Authority, as with any law enforcement agency, needs to have at its disposal the most effective investigative techniques.

Over recent years it has been recognised that traditional methods of detecting and investigating criminal activity are rarely successful against the increasingly sophisticated techniques of organised crime. Electronic surveillance techniques such as telephone interception and listening devices have now emerged as an invaluable investigative tool in this area. Overseas experience, particularly in the United States, has confirmed that such a useful tool should be available to all agencies investigating organised crime, especially in relation to drug trafficking.

If we are to be successful in our efforts to attack major drug trafficking networks, it is important that the NCA be put in the same position as the AFP and State police in having available the most appropriate, up-to-date techniques. Listening devices have made key contributions in a number of major narcotics investigations undertaken by the Australian Federal Police, for example in the Paltos case.

The amendments to sub-sections 219a-k of the Customs Act 1901 also clarify the disclosure provisions for information obtained by use of a listening device under warrant for the purpose of conducting legal proceedings, in particular to ensure that prosecution authorities and defence counsel are able to be provided with the necessary information for the conduct of the proceedings. The amendments will also extend the disclosure of such information to applications for orders in confiscation proceedings under the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 and to extradition proceedings. This is consistent with the current provisions relating to confiscation proceedings under the Customs Act, and will contribute to law enforcement agencies' ability to effectively deal with major drug importation and related offences.

Part III of the Bill effectively makes five amendments to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 (``MA'' Act). That Act provides the legislative basis for Australia to enter into and give effect to treaties and arrangements with other countries whereby it can request or grant assistance in criminal matters. The assistance relates both to the investigation and prosecution of crime. The range of assistance covered by the legislation includes provision of evidence, documents and articles, location and identification of witnesses, execution of requests for search and seizure, and tracing, freezing and seizure of proceeds of crime.

A number of implementation problems with the MA Act emerged during recent treaty negotiations with other countries. All but one of the five amendments proposed in this Bill are to redress those problems.

The first amendment is for the purpose of expanding the current definitions of ``Australian forfeiture order'' and ``foreign forfeiture order'' in the MA Act. These amendments are consequential upon amendments to the statutory forfeiture provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act ``PC Act'' whereby an Australian court can make a declaration that automatic statutory forfeiture of property has occurred. Under section 30 of the PC Act statutory forfeiture occurs where a restraining order made against property of the defendant is still in force six months after the defendant's conviction of a ``serious offence'' as defined by the PC Act. Such a declaration can then be recognised for enforcement purposes by a foreign court pursuant to a request by the Attorney-General under section 32 MA Act as a judicial order for the purposes of executing an MA request by Australia. A further amendment will enable a similar declaration by a foreign court, where the law of the particular foreign country has equivalent ``automatic'' forfeiture procedures, to be registered and enforced by an Australian court pursuant to an authorisation by the Attorney-General under section 34 MA Act.
The second amendment is to include a definition of ``political offence'' in an MA Act.
Offences of a political character are excluded from those for which assistance may be granted under Australia's extradition and mutual assistance legislation.

Until recently it was left to the courts to determine whether an offence was of a political character. The Extradition Act 1988 now limits the offences which may qualify as political offences for extradition purposes. That limitation was to declare Australia's clear abhorrence of terrorist conduct and our unwillingness to withhold extradition to other countries seeking to bring to justice criminals whose serious or violent crimes have been allegedly perpetrated for ideological reasons.

The amendment is intended to achieve the same objectives in the field of international mutual assistance. Clause 13 of the Bill inserts a limiting definition of ``political offence'', and substitutes that expression for ``offence of a political character'' in the operative refusal of assistance provisions of the MA Act.

The definition excludes from political offences crimes which have been recognised by the international community in multilateral treaties as being extremely serious (hijacking, safety of aircraft, genocide, torture, taking of hostages and the protection of internationally protected persons). The definition also permits crimes to be excluded by way of regulation, such as crimes recognised in future multilateral conventions to which Australia becomes a party, crimes against Heads of State or Heads of Government and crimes of violence committed in circumstances where a collective danger to innocent life is created.
The third amendment deals with the foreign law testimonial immunities of persons who give evidence in Australia as a result of a request by a foreign country or by Australia.

Where a person gives evidence in Australia as a result of a request by a foreign country, the amendment confers on the person the testimonial immunities the person would have if giving evidence in the requesting country.

Where a person consents to come to Australia temporarily to give evidence as a result of a request by Australia the amendment preserves the foreign law testimonial immunities which apply in the requested country. The amendment ensures that the person may refuse to answer a question or produce a document in the Australian proceedings on the grounds of a privilege, duty or obligation which does not apply before Australian courts, but which would enable or oblige the person to so refuse in proceedings in the person's own country. This is to remove concern that such a person, upon return to his own country, could be liable to civil or criminal action for breach of the duty or obligation on which the privilege is based.

The amendment also provides for a certificate procedure to facilitate proof of, and application of, foreign law immunities in particular proceedings, together with a definition of ``foreign law immunity certificate''.

The fourth amendment is to clarify the ambit of immunity from civil suit of a person when in another country to give evidence or assist in an investigation at the request of that country. The intention of the existing provisions is to ensure that advantage is not taken of the presence of the person for the purpose of civil proceedings in the requesting country. In particular, the intention is to protect the person from the commencement, continuation or enforcement of civil proceedings, which could not occur but for the presence of the person in that country. A number of countries have also expressed concern that the Act arguably protects the person even from suits which do not depend upon the person's presence. The proposed amendment will clarify and limit the immunity to that which was originally intended.

The final amendment will ensure that the Attorney-General is able to grant a request where the foreign government gives an adequate undertaking of civil suit immunity, even though it falls short of an unconditional guarantee. Several foreign governments had doubted whether their authorities had the practical or legal competence to give what they regarded as the unconditional guarantee of civil suit immunity on their reading of the Act as presently worded.
Parts IV and V of the Bill contain amendments of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 and the National Crime Authority (Status and Rights of Chairman) Act 1984.

The primary purpose of the amendments to the National Crime Authority Act is to enable the National Crime Authority to disseminate information relating to criminal activity or to security matters, in a proper and timely way.

The Authority's significant achievements to date in combating organised crime in Australia has resulted in a growing amount of unsolicited information relating to criminal activity being provided to the Authority by members of the public and other agencies.

Under the present provisions of the National Crime Authority legislation the Authority has prescribed to it as one of its general functions, the dissemination to law enforcement agencies and designated persons, criminal information and intelligence related to `relevant criminal activity'. The Authority also has a clear discretion to furnish to law enforcement agencies any information that comes into its possession in the course of an investigation conducted by it, concerning the commission, or possible commission of a Commonwealth, State or Territory offence. The Authority has a similar discretion in respect of passing information to authorised authorities and persons responsible for taking civil remedies action arising out of offences against Commonwealth, State or Territory laws.

Much of the unsolicited information now being received by the Authority, however, falls outside the definition of `relevant criminal activity' in the Act and is not relevant to any investigation by the Authority. This has resulted in the Authority being unable to pass such information to the relevant law enforcement agency. This is clearly an undesirable situation. Accordingly, the amendments proposed to sub-sections 59 (7) and (8) are designed to enable the Authority to disseminate unsolicited information relating to criminal activity in a proper and timely manner.

A similar defect in the present Act has been highlighted in respect of the receipt by the Authority of information relevant to security (as that word is defined in section 4 of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979). At present the Act does not provide the Authority with the power to transfer such information to ASIO. Clearly it is desirable that such information when it is received should be passed by the Authority to ASIO in accordance with ASIO's functions. The proposed new sub-section 59 (11) is designed to overcome this difficulty. Similar provisions exist in the Telephone (Interception) and Customs legislation.

The amendments will also enable the Authority to delegate, by signed instrument, to a member or acting member or to a member of the staff of the Authority, its powers to furnish information under sub-sections 59 (7), (8) and (11). At present section 59 of the Act requires the Authority to meet to determine when information should be provided to another agency. It is appropriate that such decisions be delegated to ensure that where information is to be transferred, that action occurs with a minimum of delay.

The Government is also proposing an amendment to the National Crime Authority (Status and Rights of Chairman) Act 1984. This amendment is consequential upon the Government's recent announcement of its intention to recommend to the Governor-General in Council that the Chairman of the National Crime Authority Mr Justice Stewart, be re-appointed for an additional year. The amendment is required to ensure that the provisions of the Status and Rights of Chairman Act will apply to Mr Justice Stewart for the period of his re-appointment.

Part VI of the Bill amends the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 to enable a certified copy of a warrant authorising the interception of telecommunications to be received in certain proceedings as if it were the original warrant. This provision will help to reduce the cost and inconvenience arising at present in connection with the secure transmission of original warrants. The amendment does not alter any rule of evidence which may apply in relation to proof of the issue of a warrant, except that the original warrant will not be required to be produced.

Part VI also amends the Telecommunications (Interception) Act to enable the National Crime Authority to obtain, for a purpose connected with its investigation of serious offences, information in the hands of Telecom obtained as a result of lawful interceptions.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the State of Pennsylvania in the United States of America there is a community of people called the Amish who live on their own without affecting others and without adopting any of the practices and community benefits the modern state. They live as their forebears did in the nineteenth century. That is exactly the situation that the Government is existing in in the area of telecommunications and broadcasting generally. Here we have a golden opportunity for the Government to adopt a new approach with broadcasting, a deregulatory approach, which would allow new operators to come into the field, but the Australian Labor Party Government is bogged down in nineteenth century thinking and is shunning the whole new world of technology.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the reality of the Government's approach to the Opposition's proposal to deregulate the broadcasting industry in such a way as to lead to greater and better services for the average television viewer in this country. The Government refuses to take up the challenge and refuses to accept a deregulatory approach that the Opposition is offering it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you been doing for the last five days?

—I repeat, for Senator Schacht's benefit, that the Government has a golden opportunity to present the viewers of Australia with a service far superior to that which they are now getting, by adopting the Opposition's proposals, as outlined last night by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), and taking positive steps towards that direction.

SPEECH.PARA: This horse-and-buggy approach to the broadcasting industry is just typical of the phoney approach by the Labor Party to deregulation and privatisation generally. Yesterday we saw the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, after all the regurgitations and the period of gestation through his party committees, finally emerge as a mouse. He declared that Australian Airlines was to be turned into a public company. Where does that take airline consumers in this country? Absolutely nowhere, of course. I put it on record that the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia support the total privatisation of Australian Airlines, rather than the kind of halfway approach which this Government is prepared to hand out.

This Minister, this Government, this Cabinet, do not have the support of the ALP Caucus to get into a full-blooded deregulation and privatisation program. That is the simple reason why they cannot take Australian Airlines any further, and that is why they are faced with a situation over broadcasting where they will not adopt proposals which are reasonable and which are going to enhance services to the Australian consumer by the deregulation of the broadcasting industry. That is a challenge which we give them and which we have proposed in a very reasonable fashion, and which they have refused to pick up for all the most obtuse, stupid and absolutely silly reasons which I will outline a little later. All that this shows is the weakness of Senator Evans's position in dealing with his Caucus, and we will come to that a little later as well.

I return to the point about the horse-and-buggy era that we are locked into with this Government in this area of telecommunications. Firstly, more reviews of policy are being undertaken by this Government than are run in the Follies Bergere on a Saturday night. We have no fewer than nine reviews going on. Let me outline these reviews. Where is the action? We have nine distinct reviews. One that has something to do with telecommunications is described as the managerial environment of government business enterprises. We have a review of international telecommunications regulations. We have a series of interrelated reviews on broadcasting policy matters, commercial, national and Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) matters. There are no decisions. All we get is reviews-and that is precisely what we had about a month ago when the Government brought out this weak little statement about what it intended to do with the crisis in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The Government even failed to tell us what it was going to propose to the SBS so that it could consider the matter. It has another inquiry on metropolitan radio, one on public television and one on a whole rethink of the broadcasting legislation. It has an inquiry into radio frequency spectrum pricing. Policies are being reviewed on the governing and allocation of frequencies for radio-and God knows what else. The fact is that there is no action from this Government and no decision.

Let us now turn to the point about broadcasting policy. It is now something like eight months since Senator Evans became the Minister for Transport and Communications. He proudly announced that he was going to review broadcasting policy, particularly for television. He set up an inquiry to undertake that. We were going to have the results of that inquiry by last Christmas. Nothing came forward. Then it was to be put off until March or some time like that. We still have not seen it and March has come and gone. We are now being told that in this area and in the telecommunications area we will perhaps hear something in Mr Keating's May statement. After the very disappointing burst that was produced yesterday on Australian Airlines we have to assume that we will not hear very much at all about the privatisation or deregulation of either of those areas.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING (OWNERSHIP AND CONTROL) BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATIONAMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987]

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Messner.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Powell-Mr President, I am not sure whether this is a point of order or whether I am seeking clarification from the Chair. Do I understand that we now have a cognate debate?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we are now debating the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill 1988 and the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Powell-I would simply like to point out that this arrangement has been made in the middle of a second reading debate on one of the Bills. I would like to object to that and also express an understanding that neither the Government nor the Opposition probably wants to address the specific issues in either of the Bills, and I want to make a comment on the changing of the Order of Business at this point.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Messner-Why didn't you speak when he got up? You had your opportunity. Do you want to undo it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on Senator Messner's interjection.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did rise when the Minister agreed to the suggestion. Unfortunately, the President was then drawing attention to the presence of guests in his gallery and obviously did not notice that I had stood at that point.
—There was no objection, so we will debate the two Bills cognately. I call Senator Messner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night there was issued a statement of the position on the question of broadcasting legislation which this Government is going to move amendments to at a later stage today. The Liberal and National parties have considered very closely the Government's proposal to increase audience reach limits for television from the present level of 60 per cent to 75 per cent. As we all know in this place, there has been a long debate on this matter over the past couple of years. I will not go into it too much, but we observe that it was an arrangement between the parties in the Senate last June that brought about the 60 per cent limit, whereas at that time the Government wanted a 75 per cent limit.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to put it quite clearly that the reason the Liberal and National parties oppose the Government's increasing the audience reach limit from 60 per cent to 75 per cent is simply that there has been no attempt by the present Government at the same time to introduce new operators into the field of television or to ensure that there is a speedy introduction of pay television in this country. In other words, the Government is maintaining the monopoly position of those players who are currently in the field and who will benefit from an expansion of the audience reach limit to 75 per cent, but it is not taking the next step to allow more operators to come into the field and to provide for pay television to allow the total service to the Australian consumer to be expanded and improved. That is the fundamental objection of the Liberal and National parties to the Government's proposal.

The legislation, which covers a multitude of matters other than the audience reach limit for television, will be supported, but I shall move an amendment to the second reading motion which draws attention to those aspects on which the Liberal and National parties disagree with the Government. In committee, we will oppose the Government's amendments from the floor to expand the audience reach limit to 75 per cent. In the event of the Government succeeding in getting support for that proposal from the Democrats, we will need to consider the situation more carefully, although I understand that that is not a likely proposition.

The fact is that this issue is about deregulation of the broadcasting industry. The Liberal and National parties want to establish a 100 per cent audience reach, on the basis that there is to be expanded competition with new operators coming into the free to air broadcasting area and, in addition, the speedy introduction of pay television. Pay television is a feasible proposition in Australia. It is an opportunity to expand diversity, through which there will be more information sources available to Australians. The Government is delaying that process purposely, Senator Evans cannot go back to Caucus and put forward the proposition that we should be expanding into pay television, because he knows that he will be rolled on that.

The matter of pay television is a key factor in the Liberal and National parties' approach to diversity and the expansion of information sources in this country. There is about a 50 per cent utilisation of pay television in the United States of America, with very creditable and beneficial results for the consumers. It obviously provides diversity of information and, consequently, leads to a far better informed democracy in that country. We want to see that happen, because in this country-and in the United States, for that matter-there are five established networks, but they produce programs that not everyone wants to see. Other programs which can be provided on cable or pay television provide that diversity and freedom of choice. We believe it is fundamental that it is introduced as quickly as possible and, if the Government accepted that as a proposal and removed the moratorium on pay television which applies until 1990, we would have something to talk about in terms of the expansion of audience reach limits. I remind the Government that without the introduction of those new methods we will not support its 75 per cent proposal.

There has been much talk recently about the Liberal and National parties developing media policy, so let us run over the history of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) in recent years and the question of its media policy. It first came to the attention of the Press in December 1985 when the then Minister for Communications-the present Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy)-proposed an audience reach limit of 43 per cent for national television; but because no-one seemed to go along with that, Cabinet set up a committee which decided on 35 per cent. At that point the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) intervened and persuaded the committee not to adopt that Caucus committee proposal because, if the Packer and Murdoch stations were sold, the new owners would have to comply with that 35 per cent rule. During those Cabinet discussions the Prime Minister is reported to have referred to the Packer and Murdoch organisations as `the only mates we have in the ALP'.

At that time Cabinet referred reconsideration of this matter to a committee of Ministers which included the Prime Minister, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and Mr Duffy. In October 1986, about a year later, Mr Keating emerged with a new scheme for television ownership to take an owner's newspaper holdings into account in respect of the purchase of television stations. This was supposed to be an alternative to the conflicting proposals put forward by Mr Duffy and Mr Hawke. Under Mr Keating's proposal any owner could have had an unlimited proportion of national television audience provided that the owner did not have a print outlet of more than 50 per cent of the circulation in the same area. I maintain that that is an unlimited proportion-which is exactly what the Liberal and National parties propose at the moment; yet the Government is now casting aside Mr Keating's proposal of 1986 and refusing to take it into account. In November 1986, apparently as a result of some kind of deal, Cabinet settled on a further compromise-a Keating compromise-of 75 per cent, and it is significant that that proposal was opposed by Mr Duffy.

All that confusion continued in the ALP, over not two days, three days or even four days-it took 2 1/2 years to work it out. The ALP squibbed on the only sensible decision, which is to increase audience reach limits to 100 per cent with new entrants coming into the marketplace. That is the position of the ALP Government opposite. The most significant feature of the history of this matter is that in the end it came down to who was going to best look after the ALP. It has been said that Mr Packer and Mr Murdoch are mates of the ALP and that is why this compromise decision was arrived at at that time. It comes down to that.

Having dealt with that matter, let us look at the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) and the comment he made last night on the Liberal and National parties' proposals. If ever there was a squid statement, that was it. It was a phoney statement drawn up in the heat of the moment and no doubt it was dictated to his secretary over dinner. It was a kneejerk reaction to quite sensible discussion. Only yesterday the New Zealand Labour Government announced total deregulation of its broadcasting industry by the end of the coming year-not to the point where new licences are being called; the whole system of broadcasting is being thrown open to new operators. Yet this Government again squibs on proposals to introduce new operators to the field. The key question is: Why will the Government not face up to decisions in this area and adopt a practical policy for broadcasting in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. I will not go through all the self-serving nonsense that Senator Evans mentioned in his Press statement released last night. It was just designed to protect his position so that he would not have to go back to Caucus and argue his case again.

Let us turn for a moment to pay television because it is really an important part of our proposals. Senator Evans says that we will have to go through another one of his famous reviews to determine what kind of policy we will have on pay television. A moratorium has already been placed on pay television until 1990. Yet there would have to be an absolute plethora of information around the place on pay television, and the Minister knows it. First and foremost, an Australian Broadcasting Tribunal report commissioned by the Fraser Government in 1982 brought down an outline of what kind of system could be implemented in this country. That report has been ignored; we have heard nothing at all. It has been hanging about ever since this Government came to power in 1983; yet the Government refuses to take action in this area, which is, of course, one of the very significant developments in this country.

One might ask whether such a system is likely to be viable in this country. Many of us would have to rely on fairly subjective evidence about that. But let us remind ourselves that there has been a huge explosion in the use of video cassette recorders (VCRs) in this country since 1980, to the point where more than 50 per cent of Australian homes now have video cassette recorders. In other words, people want an alternative to the normal television broadcasting system and VCRs are one element of that choice. Yet they are quite clearly another form of pay television. Why will not the Government immediately move to adopt pay television as a national proposition so as to take advantage of that trend and set it up on a more diverse basis? We await the Minister's comment about that.

On the question of diversity in a society such as ours, certainly as a nation and as a Parliament we are looking to far more diverse information sources so that the widest possible range of views can be provided to the Australian people. This is, of course, what the Liberal and National parties are concerned with at the moment. But what is the Government doing? It has a golden chance to pick up the Opposition's proposal for 100 per cent audience reach limits, yet it refuses to accept it. What, for instance, is it doing about the possible decline of competition which may occur as networks develop across this country and take over more and more smaller television stations in the far flung parts of Australia? There are some very significant issues at stake here. There is the question of what proportion of network time being broadcast will go to local production; in country areas, how much time should local television stations be required to set aside for local news services, sports services, weather services and local information services to the population of that area, rather than having those wiped out by a network which seeks to impose itself over those local stations. There is no attempt by the Government, in its proposal for 75 per cent ownership, to protect people in that situation. There is no proposal to require a minimum amount of local content to be provided on the network stations. There are no safeguards whatsoever for local people. I believe that that is a serious omission. It is another reason why we in the Liberal and National parties will not support the Government's proposals.

How committed is the Government to Australian-made drama? Obviously, an Australian local network is developing in television-the three networks are expanding rapidly-yet there is no requirement for an increase in, or even the maintenance of, as I see it, the present level of drama produced in Australia. Where has the Government stated its guarantees on that? Where are its requirements that that be maintained by the networks? In other words, these essential points which are critical to the development of the Australian industry and to the development of a far better service for Australians are being ignored by this Government. Why will it not pick up our proposals? Why will it not say to us, `Look, you have the best idea, which is to expand the networks, thus providing more competition in such a way that a better service will be offered to the Australian consumer.'? Surely that is the only direction which any government should be taking.

The only conclusion to which we can come after all this is that we return to the first point: Mr Hawke made it absolutely clear at the very beginning when this debate started within the Labor Party 2 1/2 years ago that the Government had to look after its mates. It has decided who its mates are and it is going to look after them. We have heard the descriptions of Labor Party back bench members during the debate in terms of their attitudes towards some of those people. So there is not a universal approach in the Labor Party. Mr Allan Morris, a New South Wales backbencher, speaking in support of a 35 per cent option, as opposed to the Government's present 75 per cent, said that the then two-station rule was a sleazy deal created by former Prime Minister Menzies to protect the Fairfax and Packer groups; but this has been taken up by the Hawke Government. Back bench members and leading Government members have made similar statements. Their remarks have led us to the conclusion that these sleazy deals are being maintained. At one stage Senator Button was reported as having said to the Prime Minister in the Cabinet room, `Mr Prime Minister, why don't you just tell us precisely who you want us to help in the media?'. The Government's approach is not about developing a rational system that will provide a broader and better service for all Australians; it is about looking after mates. That is what the Government's approach basically is about.

That is the key to this piece of legislation. It does not provide any safeguards or guarantees for the development of the industry in Australian hands. It does not provide for localism. It does not provide for pay television to be introduced. It does not provide for the future introduction of new television networks to provide greater competition. Therefore, it leaves the Australian television viewer out in the cold, back in the nineteenth century, where this Government is rooted in its thinking on all telecommunications matters. For that reason we oppose the Government's amendments. I now move:

At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate expresses its view that all television audience reach restrictions be removed to allow a potential 100 per cent audience reach for all competitors on the conditions that:
(a) the Government's moratorium on the introduction of pay and cable television be removed;
(b) the existing television licensing procedures be substantially streamlined;
(c) cross-media rules between pay and cable television and existing free-to-air broadcasters be introduced subject to `grandfathering' of existing holdings; and

(d) when the process of aggregation has been completed, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal conduct an inquiry into issuing new television licences in metropolitan markets, subject to a final decision being made by the Government''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an amazing opportunity one is given today to speak in this debate. This is a cognate debate on the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill and the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill, but, more than that, it marks the death of the leadership of John Howard in the Liberal Party of Australia. My colleague in another place last week described him as the `living dead'. Over the last four or five days John Howard's parliamentary colleagues have certainly proved that true. Mr Howard, accompanied by the shadow Minister for communications, Senator Messner, has taken the Liberal Party through one of the most amazing performances in recent political history. One only has to see--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point or order, which is twofold. It concerns firstly the issue of relevance but, more seriously, the offensive House of Representatives reference to the Leader of the Opposition which has been repeated in this place. It is no defence of the use of unparliamentary language that one is merely quoting the Treasurer, whose reputation in that respect is, of course, abysmal. I ask that the honourable senator withdraw his reference to the Leader of the Opposition. I do not intend to dignify it by repeating it.
—I ask Senator Schacht to withdraw the comment.

—I withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President. The leadership of the Liberal Party has been destroyed by the events of the last four or five days. This has been portrayed openly in the Press. Members of the Liberal Party could not restrain themselves from going to the Press with various stories about what happened to the leadership of John Howard and, if one could call it the leadership, of the shadow Minister for communications, Senator Messner. Let us look at what has been said in the Press recently. In an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald, Alan Ramsey says:

SPEECH.PARA: At 5.30 pm yesterday, the Canberra Press crowded into John Howard's office to see what seven meetings in 32 hours of embarrassing confusion had produced.
What had it produced? It had produced the destruction of John Howard's leadership. Alan Ramsey goes on:
How to make no look like yes.
How to make the party of free enterprise and deregulation look less restrictive than its opponents.
So we have yesterday's formula. In rejecting 75 per cent, John Howard and his colleagues have now dressed up a policy that disguises 60 per cent to look like 100 per cent.
That is all it is, pretence. John Howard the Flim Flam Man.

I do not think there could be a more precise description of what has happened to the Liberal Party over the last few days than that written by Alan Ramsay. What else have we had in the Press in the last few days? An article in the Melbourne Age was headed `Opposition in disarray on TV ownership policy'. In the Canberra Times an article was headed `Opposition TV chaos deepens'. The headline `Howard expected to lose TV ownership issue' appeared in the Australian Financial Review. Other headlines were `Peacock backs decision to block TV audience move' and `Top Liberals rolled on TV reach'. Finally, I draw the attention of the Senate to an article in the Australian of 14 April, headed `Coalition backs higher TV limit', which stated:

The Opposition's draft communication policy signals support for a Cabinet proposal to increase television ownership limits, allowing proprietors such as Mr Christopher Skase and Mr Alan Bond to retain their national networks.

That article was written over a couple of weeks ago. Since then, presumably, either Senator Messner or someone from his staff has leaked this information to the Press to get some publicity, not realising that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I ask Senator Schacht to withdraw that statement. I had nothing to do with the leaking of that document.

—I withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am glad that Senator Messner has cleared that matter up, that he did not leak it. Obviously someone in the Liberal Party did because it is a Liberal Party document. It clearly exposes the fact that two weeks ago Senator Messner and Mr Howard made it quite clear to Mr Skase and others, `It is okay; we made a blue last year when we opposed 75 per cent, but'-with a wink, a nod and a nudge-`you will be okay; it will go through'. Of course, accounts of what happened last Thursday night in the shadow Cabinet meeting indicate that Mr Howard and Senator Messner were left like shags on a rock when they put this position to their colleagues. That has been the effort of the Liberal Party over the last week.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, it is not often in politics that what is supposedly not major legislation-it is significant, but it should not be a major political event-has turned out to be a significant political event because it has destroyed the credibility and the leadership of the present Leader of the Liberal Party. It has certainly destroyed the credibility of the shadow Minister for communications. Whether Mr Howard survives one day, one month or another year before he is rolled, he will have to replace the present shadow Minister, who has been so inept at trying to explain to his parliamentary colleagues the difference between 60 per cent, 75 per cent, 43 per cent, 100 per cent and 15 per cent. About the only thing he has not proposed is that we have an audience reach of 115 per cent. Of course, that would defy mathematics, but that is the position the Liberal Party is in at the moment.

Another problem for the Liberal Party is that the Howard-Messner view has been completely disowned by the four major State leaders of the Liberal Party, including the Premier of New South Wales, the new hero of the Liberal Party, Mr Greiner. They have made it quite clear that they think it is crazy not to go to an audience reach of 75 per cent. We also see in the Press today that Messrs Peacock and Sinclair, Senator Chaney and Senator Stone all oppose the policy put forward by Mr Howard and Senator Messner. It really does emphasise the fact that the present Liberal leadership is in such terrible disarray.

The Bill before us is based on a decision of the Government, reached without the extraordinary confusion evident on the other side over the last couple of weeks. It is based on a decision reached overwhelmingly by our Caucus. In discussion between the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) and our Caucus policy committee, we considered rationally all the aspects of this important issue of media policy, and especially television broadcasting in Australia. The three elements on which the Labor Government has based its decision are important. First of all, we agreed to support an increase in audience reach from 60 per cent to 75 per cent. Those who say this will increase monopoly ownership or control of the television networks in Australia do not understand the difference between ownership and network operation in Australia. Many years ago the Liberal Party Government agreed to allow a 43 per cent audience reach, or the two-station ownership rule, which meant that if a person owned a station in Sydney and Melbourne he effectively controlled the network. That is when the genie was let out of the bottle; that is when we allowed this network development to occur.

If Opposition senators are really serious about getting rid of networks, or control by one company, they have to be fair dinkum and say that they want to have less than 43 per cent; that we should have 30 per cent to stop someone owning a television station in both Sydney and Melbourne. When someone owns a network in Sydney and in Melbourne, he runs the rest of the network-whether it is the Nine, the Ten or the Seven network-around the rest of Australia. There was an example some years ago, I understand with the Nine network, when Kerry Packer owned Sydney and Melbourne, and Alan Bond owned Perth and Brisbane-a much smaller part of the network. Apparently Alan Bond had a couple of programs produced which he wanted shown on the Nine network. When he put them forward to Kerry Packer, Packer said, `No, I am not interested. We will not show them in Sydney and Melbourne; you will have to show them on your own stations'. That made the programs uneconomic and stopped that production taking place. That indicates that when a person gets Sydney and Melbourne together, he has control of the network. All that an increase from 60 to 75 per cent will do is ensure that one last station-one out of five in the mainland capitals-will be part of the network.

It has been put to members of the Government, and I am sure it has been put to members of the Opposition, that if we want a diversified network, if we want some decentralisation and if we want regional production in the outlying State capitals, stations should be owned by the same network so the investment can be made. Of course, this is of particular concern in South Australia. I am sure Senator Messner has been lobbied by Channel 7 staff in Adelaide, as I have. It has been pointed out that if that station is part of the Seven network, owned by the Skase organisation, it would be expected that Channel 7 in Adelaide would become the centre of a number of local productions, including children's television productions, for that network. If Channel 7 in Adelaide is left as a separately owned station, it will just be the tag end or the dag end of the network, merely relaying programs with no local production. As a senator from South Australia, I am more than surprised that Senator Messner is not supportive of local production being decentralised to South Australia under the 60 to 75 per cent proposal. He is acting against the interests of television production in his own State.

A second aspect of the decision that the Government made in the last two weeks is that, in allowing the networks to go from 60 to 75 per cent of audience reach, we also decided to strengthen the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT). One should remember that it was the Fraser Government in 1981 that gutted the powers of the ABT to make sure that it did not have the strength or the powers to control the networks or the media owners. The Fraser Government did this because the ABT was stopping Rupert Murdoch from buying, as it then was, Channel 0 in Melbourne. The Fraser Government put legislation through to gut the powers of the ABT so as to allow that purchase to go ahead.

I must say that it is really extraordinary to find that members of the Liberal Party of Australia, such as Mr Macphee, are now saying, `Oh, that was one of Malcolm Fraser's most dreadful mistakes'. I know that Senator Chaney chided Mr Macphee only two days ago when Mr Macphee gave credit to the Labor Government over industrial relations. But Mr Macphee is now, in a lame duck way, saying, `The Fraser Government should not have done it'. It did do it; it wrecked the powers of the ABT. The Federal Labor Government, through the Department of Transport and Communications and the appropriate House of Representatives standing committee, is investigating the ways in which the powers of the ABT can be increased and strengthened to ensure that the three major networks are appropriately controlled in the public interest and that they are made responsible for what they broadcast.

I think it is important to give the ABT a medium range power to penalise networks if they do not carry out their public function. I remember in the late 1970s going to some public hearings in South Australia on the renewal of television licences. A promise of performance was tabled by each of the television stations in which they said what they were going to do in the next three years if their licences were renewed. This was wonderful stuff; no one could disagree with it. Of course, three years later, when one went back to see what they had carried out, one found gaping holes in what they had done to meet their promises of performance. I think the ABT should have medium range powers to penalise stations which do not carry out their promises of performance. Such stations or networks should suffer not necessarily the sledgehammer effect of having their licence taken off them, which would be almost impossible to impose, but some financial penalty or some other effective penalty to show them that they cannot ignore their promise of performance.

Also, I would like to see the ABT, of its own volition, have the powers from time to time to investigate a station which is the subject of public complaint that it is not carrying out its particular public performance. For example, Mr Skase and the Seven network might promise to decentralise children's television production in the network to Adelaide if this Bill is carried. I believe that there should be a public requirement that this promise should be carried out. If it is not carried out they should suffer some penalty that is effective in a financial way. So, the second aspect of the Government's decision was to strengthen the ABT. I do not see Senator Messner, anywhere in any of his confused statements over the last week, or anybody in the Liberal Party, supporting the Government in its proposals to strengthen the ABT.

The final decision which the Government took in the last week as part of the overall decision was to stop any move to increase the cross-ownership of television stations from 5 to 15 per cent. I think everyone would agree that the Government has maintained that position. I have not heard any comment from Senator Messner about it, but I presume he agrees that it would be wrong to allow newspaper owners or companies in Australia in particular to have up to a 15 per cent ownership in the present television networks. This decision means that the Murdoch Press and the Fairfax Press will have to divest some of their shares that they hold in the Ten and Nine networks. That is an excellent decision. When that decision was reached, after considered debate in the Labor Party, and not this mad, stupid chaos--

TALK.START.PARA: —Over 2 1/2 years of struggle in the Labor Party, back and forth.

—The only thing I give Senator Messner credit for is his gall in speaking here today. After his efforts of the last six days, I would have thought that he would have disappeared out of this place for at least six months because of his appalling performance. I am glad the honourable senator has mentioned the Government's decisions. Let us look at some of the Press statements that Senator Messner has issued over the last week. They are really riveting stuff. They are apologetic, ducking and weaving. One was issued on 19 April stating: `Government review of pay TV-Opposition's response'-a lame duck statement. The honourable senator has been going on about pay television here today as though it is the only thing he knows anything about, as though the Opposition has a consistent view about it. Senator Messner made another statement on 19 April-that must have been a pretty busy day for his office: `TV ownership limit charges-Opposition comment'. That is all he could make, a comment. He could not say yea or nay on it-another lame duck statement from the shadow Minister. He made another statement on 22 April: `Coalition's decision on television ownership'-an extraordinarily lame duck explanation of what was, a few days ago, the coalition's decision, which decision of course has now been ripped up. We now have a different one. Then on 25 April there was a statement: `Government should act immediately to expand television services for Australian consumers'. Of all the stupid hypocrisy, that must take the cake. By opposing an increase in the percentage from 60 to 75, the Opposition is clearly preventing the rural people of Australia from having the advantages of aggregation, from having three networks broadcasting to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner is proposing the exact opposite of what he says he is proposing in his bizarre opposition to this Government Bill. He is denying rural and regional people a wider choice of television services. I must say that, for a party and a coalition that go around claiming they represent rural interests, that really is an extraordinary performance. We in the Australian Labor Party will have great pleasure over the next couple of years explaining to rural and regional Australia that they have not got a wider choice of television services because of the bizarre circumstances in the Liberal Party in the last three days.

TALK.START.PARA: —You won't be in government. We will be doing it.

—I do not believe Senator Messner will be doing it. He will be made shadow Minister for country abattoirs, or something, because the only thing he has done in the last week is butcher communications policy in Australia. Senator Messner has made a number of comments as though pay television is the major point. He says, `Let us get on with pay television and introduce it. Why is the Government delaying its introduction for another two years? Why is there a moratorium and why is the Government holding another inquiry?'. But in all the statements Senator Messner has made, he has not once explained what sort of pay television system he wants in Australia. He just says, `Let it rip', whether it is transmission by cable television, optic fibre or copper cable or whether it is the ultra high frequency (UHF) system or whatever. He has not explained once what sort of system should be used. He wants people, in a deregulated way, just to go berserk. Of course, that could happen, but if that was the policy that was introduced, in five or seven years time we would have an unholy mess in Australia in cable television. It would not be serving, or working to the advantage of, the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: We are waiting for Senator Messner to explain whether he wants it on the UHF system. If he does, does he want the people who have the frequency also to be the programmers? How does he want the receivers to operate their devices to account for pay television? None of that has been raised by Senator Messner. He just wants to let it rip. The Government has done the correct thing and set up an inquiry. If Senator Messner does have any ideas which can stand up, which I am extremely doubtful about, he can put those forward in a submission. But this is the way communications policy has to go in Australia-in an orderly, planned way. It is expensive and it has enormous social impact, something that Senator Messner is not interested in.

Senator Messner then said that the Opposition would deregulate the existing television broadcasting system and let further players come in. How many more players does he want in the system? Does that mean that the Opposition will allow individual people to start a channel up wherever they like? Is there going to be an abrogation of the control or the licensing of the broadcast band? Is just anybody going to be able to run a television transmitter and start jamming others? Deregulation in broadcasting is just not on. There has to be government control and planning of the broadcast spectrum. If we have deregulation, we will have madness. We will not have a system at all. We have not heard from Senator Messner any explanation about what he means by `deregulation'. It is about time we did; but of course we will not because he will have to go back to the party room or the shadow Cabinet to get it approved, and he will get rolled because he is incapable of explaining it to his colleagues.

The situation with broadcast policy in Australia is complex. It is very difficult to draw up a policy that is going to satisfy everybody. The Government recognises that, and it does Senator Messner or the Liberal Party no good to disparage the number of reviews that the Government has had. The only way in which we are going to get decent public participation at all levels in the sort of broadcast system we need in Australia is to have the reviews and the inquiries. Whether Senator Messner and the dills in the Liberal Party make submissions, or whether the present operators or the general community do so, that is the only way we are going to end up with a comprehensive broadcast system.

In the broadcasting field we are dealing not just with television; we are dealing with radio and, as I have said before, with pay television and with the new elements of communications, some of it dealing with computers, some of it dealing with data information, and all of it interconnected. It is just extraordinary to me that we have a major plank announced today by Senator Messner that the Opposition is in favour of deregulation. It will not work in Australia. It will create chaos. Not even in America, the home of world capitalism, is there the level of deregulation that Senator Messner is trying to impose upon the system in Australia. Australia, a big continent with a sparse population, has to have a regulated communications system in which the public feel confident that the Government is acting on their behalf and in which they can put their views forward.

In conclusion, I want to come back to the point I started on. The circumstances of this debate today are extraordinary. This debate is really about the funeral oration for the leadership of John Howard in the Liberal Party. It is certainly the funeral service for Tony Messner as the shadow Minister for communications in the Liberal Party and in the coalition. As I said in earlier remarks, whether he lasts one day, one week or one month, Tony Messner has no credibility left anywhere with anybody in the communications industry. If they read his speech today opposing this Bill, they will see why his standing would have no credibility. It was one of the worst performances I have seen from a shadow Minister. Admittedly, I have been here only about nine months, but it was an appalling performance to try to explain why the Government Bill should be defeated.

A former senator in this place, though not a member of my Party, once said of a Liberal leader, `He could not go two rounds in a revolving door'. One is of the opinion today that Senator Messner is perpetually trapped in a revolving door on communications policy and does not know how to get out of it, and he has taken with him Mr Howard and helped destroy his leadership.

As we are talking about communications, the media and entertainment, after listening to Senator Messner one cannot help but be reminded that maybe the Marx Brothers are writing the Liberal Party's communications policy. Many years ago I had great enjoyment from seeing a classic Marx brothers' comedy called Monkey Business. I believe Senator Messner and Mr Howard could take over the roles of Chico and Harpo Marx in that movie, because they have the same level of logic in putting forward their policy today. I believe they made such a mess of it that, if there was any integrity in the Opposition parties in this place, they would support the Government's Bill and allow it to go forward to ensure the continued orderly development of communications policy in Australia. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Powell I just make the remark that the previous speaker referred to a member of this place by his first name only. For the dignity of the Senate we should use the correct titles of members of this place. I call Senator Powell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to what the previous speaker, Senator Schacht did, I think I should point out what this debate is really all about. Senator Schacht concluded his remarks by saying that the debate was all about the leadership of the coalition. Of course, that is a significant sideshow to this exercise. But we are here engaged in a cognate debate on two significant Bills, the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill 1988 and the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. In particular, the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill 1988 represents a significant milestone in the ongoing debate on media regulation and ownership in Australia. I do not think that that should be forgotten in all the rhetoric and invective that is flying around the place clearly as a result of disarray and discord on media policy within both the Opposition and the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is significant for what it does. Amendments are to be moved at the committee stage which, if passed-either the Government's amendments or my own-would go further to making significant changes to the current situation. The decisions we must make basically boil down to whether we will put first the interests of ordinary Australians, the 15 million viewers of television, or whether we will look after the mates; that is, the select few major media owners-and getting fewer-who wish to extend their domination of television still further. Later, in the committee stage, as I have said, I will be moving, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, two amendments. One is to reduce the limit on television ownership from 60 per cent of national audience reach, which is the current position, to 43 per cent. This, the Democrats say, would halt the increase in concentration of television ownership and ensure that the political and social power which comes with major media ownership is more widely distributed in the interests of the 15 million ordinary Australian television viewers, less three.

The other amendment which I will be moving is to reintroduce the prior approval powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for media ownership changes. The recent purchase by Christopher Skase, when he went well beyond the 60 per cent limit, is probably the best but certainly not the first example of why we need those powers back in place. Over the past few weeks-and even this morning we have seen some great theatre in Canberra-we have seen media proprietors exerting pressure to get the laws changed to accommodate them. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) seemed to believe and be convinced that now is the time to push things through the Caucus. However, fortunately, the back bench was a bit sensitive about blatant pandering to corporate mates, due to recent electoral disasters-and the Australian people have certainly made their voices heard on those issues. So Senator Evans has been able to extract agreement to his proposed amendment to raise the audience reach limit to 75 per cent only on the condition that he drop moves to raise the prescribed interest level, which would legalise the Murdoch and Fairfax moves to remain significant television operators in spite of the cross-media rules-rules which I must point out the Democrats very strongly support-and allow television proprietors such as Bond, Skase and Lowy to achieve, in effect, above the 60 per cent ownership level. Fortunately, that has been knocked on the head.

The Minister has also had to agree, and Senator Schacht has referred to this, to additional powers for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal-another move which the Australian Democrats heartily endorse. The possibility of an inquiry into the print media has also been part of the debate within the Caucus. However, the wining and dining continued. I would like to place on the public record the fact that Christopher Skase is a very competent business person. He judged, quite rightly, that it would be an absolute waste of his dollar to wine and dine the Australian Democrats. So I have not had a free meal in the last couple of weeks. The petitioning of backbenchers by Christopher Skase made the other media players, interestingly enough-Bond and Lowy-extremely nervous about the attention he drew to their favours which, frankly, were on the edge of being accommodated. Fortunately, some people within the Opposition, too, had the sense to kill that idea, although it did take, as we have heard this morning, several days for it to lie down and die.

It remains to be seen whether any of those people on both sides of the chamber who have argued in the past in party forums and even in the media against the high level of concentration of television ownership will have the courage to vote for the Democrat amendment which reduces the level to 43 per cent. I remind the Senate that 43 per cent is the level of the mighty Packer and Fairfax television empires of the 1960s and 1970s. It is a figure that would allow at least 10 significant television owners in this country, all with a resource base for significant production, either independently or as part of a network by affiliation. I think it is important to point out that I am not the only one, on behalf of the Democrats, who is pushing for a 43 per cent figure. I have a list of some of the other people who have argued for it, in particular in evidence before the Senate Select Committee on Television Equalisation last year, of which I was a member. The Bond media group warned that a situation could arise under the 75 per cent rule that three groups could control most of the available markets. The Bond media group said that this is more a theoretical than practical possibility, because Australian commercial television at that stage already had five or six vigorous and ambitious operating groups. Northern Star Holdings Ltd now features prominently among the media moguls. Senator Chris Puplick's dissenting report points out the Northern Star position of last year. I will read from paragraph 146 of his dissenting report:

If one needed further evidence of the cynicism of certain media proprietors to this question of cross-media ownership, one needs to look no further than the evidence of Northern Star Holdings Ltd to the Committee. We received from them a submission favouring the 43% coverage option . . . Between the lodging of the submission and their appearance as witnesses, the company acquired controlling interest in the Channel 10 stations in Sydney and Melbourne. As a result of this, the Company asked us to disregard all its previous arguments of principle and substitute a view in support of the 75% option, as they had acquired-
and this is a quote from the secondary submission-
`a different perspective in relation to some of the matters in the original submission'.
I point out that Senator Puplick made the following comment as a consequence of that Committee's hearings:

For all these reasons I reject the premise of this Bill in relation to the 75% audience reach rule and would limit any such level of domination to no more than 43% as originally proposed by Minister Duffy.

The former Minister of this portfolio, Mr Duffy, is also amongst those people who in the past have supported the 43 per cent figure. I put it on the record at this point that my move to a 43 per cent limit is not based on the fact that I believe it is the ultimate or even most desirable limit, but it is based on all that past support for the 43 per cent limit, because that is a figure which ought to be at least politically possible. In the great bastion of free enterprise, the United States, the upper limit is 25 per cent. I have mentioned that when Minister Duffy held this portfolio he was also in support of a 43 per cent limit; of course, he was shunted out of that job as much for that reason as any, because he was not prepared to go to the higher level and look after the media mates. So, he was given the flick because he was interested in taking into account the interests of the Australian public.

I think it is worth considering what a move downwards would achieve, to show, as much as anything, what the issues are. It would of course reduce the enormous social and political power of the big three-Bond, Skase and Lowy. The Democrats believe that it is quite wrong to deliver the political future of this country into their hands in these days of electronic presidential-style elections-as that is the reality of the situation. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said only a couple of weeks ago in a major contribution that he made to the debate on this issue:
The importance of television in formulating and developing public opinion is unquestioned.

The Democrats agree with the Treasurer, and therefore we want to see the ownership of this enormously important form of the media in as many hands as possible. Secondly, a reduction in the ownership limit level would encourage new players into television ownership. The greatest protection we have is in the widest possible ownership of all of our media. The Government has stated that that is its aim and, of course, it is what the amendment that I will propose would bring about. Thirdly, lower audience reach levels would prevent regional television from being engulfed. If the limit was raised to 75 per cent, as the Government proposes, it would allow those who presently dominate the metropolitan scene to carry on and buy out major regional holdings as well.

At this stage I think it is important to consider this issue further. In his contribution, Senator Schacht referred to the remaining South Australian channel, NWS9, as being in a pretty invidious position as a result of a decision of this Senate to have the level remain at 60 per cent. In fact, I wrote down what Senator Schacht said-it was a bit poetic; he said, `It would leave them the tag end of the dag end of the network'. I submit that if we go to the 75 per cent level-and it is bad enough now at 60 per cent-the remaining Adelaide and other metropolitan stations would not be left as the tag ends of the dag ends of the networks-because they would be bought up, as would many of the other regional groups; but not all stations would be. We would have scattered around Australia more of what Senator Schacht calls tag ends of dag ends of networks, without any potential influence whatsoever on the media bosses and network owners. The networks would not be there as has been the case in the past, as a result of affiliation-and we need to remember that. At a 43 per cent level, an ownership group of at least 10, and possibly more, of relatively the same size would be better able to put the case for the smaller capital cities or the regional areas that they serve.

There is another aspect of this debate which I think reflects very badly on the Government, and I refer to the scare tactics aimed at regionally based Australians and the matter of aggregations. The Government's saying that blocking a move to 75 per cent would hold back aggregation is absolute rubbish. The only way that that can occur is if Northern Star decided to spit out the dummy because it did not get its own way in relation to the 75 per cent level and not cooperate in the southern New South Wales aggregation. If so, it will be the media owners who are responsible for holding this proposal up, and no one else. If that happens it will be a classic example of commercial interests coming first, with the interests of viewers receiving no consideration. I think we could expect retaliation here in Canberra. We have become used to that sort of industrial action happening in Canberra, and we must remember that on the business side industrial action is also possible-although perhaps by another name.

We must remember that there are significant media groups out there in regional Australia that are interested in building up their ownership levels, but they would not be able to do it to any significant degree. It is difficult enough now at 60 per cent; it would be virtually impossible at 75 per cent, and we would have lots of Senator Schacht's dag ends hanging around in regional Australia, and we do not think that is good enough.

The issue of the imbalance of power in negotiations between major networks and regional groups is very important in this. The only way that we can ensure any balance at all is to reduce the limits-certainly not lift them. I stress that I am not arguing against networking as such but I am saying that networking can take place and indeed should take place by affiliation, not by ownership. That is how it happens in the United States of America and it is the way that it was happening in Australia before the dramatic changes that have taken place in the past couple of years occurred, with confusion arising due to those changes and with advantages being taken by the business interests involved because of the political and legislative vacuums and the lack of teeth of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. As I have said, in the United States, the home of probably the mightiest networks in the world, there is a 25 per cent ownership limit, and for 30 years it worked here in Australia.

I think it is somewhat unlikely that a reduction of the ownership level to 43 per cent will occur at this point, but at least the defeat of a rise to 75 per cent and a rise in the prescribed interest level would be major achievements in the television area. The Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill 1988 lays out all the media ownership limits, and the fact that within this legislation the radio ownership laws are more stringent than were first proposed, as well as those in legislation that was passed at the end of last year, is due in no small part to the pressure that the Australian Democrats-joining with certain members of the back bench of the Government, as well as community interest groups-were able to exert in this area. Perhaps we should remember that in the radio broadcast area the initial proposal was that new FM stations should be auctioned to the highest bidder. The outcry that occurred after that time, of which the Democrats were a part, indicated that the community was really saying that enough is enough. Fortunately, the Government took heed of that message.

Subsequent to that, the licensing system was proposed, and amendments made to the legislation at the end of last year by the Australian Democrats set the limits at reasonable levels, designed to enable as many players as possible to obtain in the first place new licences and, also, through negotiations, to provide the sorts of limits that are in this legislation. I do not think it would be overstating the case to say that without those negotiations having taken place, there would be no State limit in radio ownership. There would be a far higher national limit in this legislation, and the auctioning of radio licences would prevent smaller operators from competing. All those things are major achievements and that is why at the beginning of this debate I wanted to stress that what we are talking about here involves far more than an exercise in the execution of the coalition leadership-although, as I say, if that has happened as a sideshow along the way, it should not be ignored either.

The Government has made quite a song and dance about cross-media laws and aspects of that relating to this Bill. Senator Evans has placed great stress on that in his second reading speech. I think that is really because that is the only major achievement that the Government can point to in its media legislation to date. But the fact remains that in the space of just two years the Government has successfully caused a dramatic reduction in the number of television owners, a dramatic reduction in the number of radio owners, and a dramatic reduction in the number of newspaper owners. There has been an overall contraction in relation to media ownership, with it being placed in fewer and fewer hands. There are now fewer publications, and one recalls the demise of the Times on Sunday, the Western Mail, the Brisbane Telegraph and the Daily Mirror. There is less variety in the print media and other media. Independence has been reduced across all forms of the commercial media.

By any standards, and certainly by standards of diversity, the Government's media policy is failing. It is a matter of great concern to an enormous number of Australians that there is an increasing concentration of our media in few hands. Of course, we need to look at what the coalition Opposition would do.
