We have seen, as has been clearly stated already in this debate and probably will be again, a circus performance over the past few days as a result of a vacuum of policy. Our attention is drawn to what the coalition Opposition would do by the second reading attachment, and I will address myself to that for a moment. We have the extraordinary situation of an Opposition saying, `We will not support a rise to 75 per cent because we want 100 per cent audience reach, we want a wide-open slather'. I assume that that means deregulation. After looking at the attachment, some questions need to be asked. I will shortly address the question of pay television, the first item in the attachment, but I point out that there is a conflict between what is expressed here and what was expressed in the statement put out by those in the Opposition yesterday; that is, they talk about removing audience reach restrictions, they talk about 100 per cent audience reach and they talk deregulationist terms, yet I do not see in print whether they would actually go as far as to say, `Let us do away with licensing altogether'. Of course, that would mean that anyone who wanted to get into television ownership would be able to get in; there would be no restrictions. I assume that the Opposition is saying that it is fine to have 100 per cent reach, but only for the people who are in charge, the media moguls and network bosses. While we retain our present licensing system, that must be the deduction. So we have a party which says that a two-airline policy is not good but a three television owners policy is all right. It is an argument which really does not stand up.

I am pleased that the Opposition, by its attachment, supports a cross-media rule between pay and cable television and existing free to air broadcasters. The point that needs to be made about that is that there is considerable doubt about whether pay television will be viable and whether it will ever get off the ground here. At this point perhaps I should comment on pay television. Recently it has become quite a furphy and has been raised by both the Government and the Opposition. Obviously Mr Keating's 500 per cent ownership argument was not getting very far so, to create the impression of greater diversity and to bury the story about Caucus backing 75 per cent, pay television came up on the agenda. As I say, there is considerable doubt about whether pay television is viable and whether it will ever get off the ground. We should recall that there was a similar fanfare about pub television, which has now collapsed fairly dramatically. If pay television ever comes about, I suggest, it is still a fair way down the track.

I refer to the Opposition's statement last night which was headed, `More competition not less' but which I think ought to have been headed, `More competition and less', and in which the Opposition first committed itself, as it has also done in the second reading attachment, to cross-media rules between pay television and existing free to air broadcasters. This raises the question of who will be the pay television proprietor. Bond is the only possibility now-and the Opposition seems to be promoting pay television at this point-yet its own attachment, its own statement, says that it would have cross-media rules in respect of those two forms of media. It seems to me to be a cloud cuckoo land proposal altogether and places a cloud over the Opposition's claim that it has some sort of media policy. If those in the Opposition were to put up arguments about diversity, they would have to talk about real options. Some real options are available to us now and not at some possible distant time when someone else is available other than Bond, who cannot be the pay television proprietor as he has pub television, and so on.

Senator Messner talked a lot about the United States and pay television over there and so on, but he did not mention community television, or public television, as it is sometimes known. The United States has had public television for 35 years. There are 320 public television stations serving viewers in that country and some of its territories, if you like, each of them being independent but affiliated with a public broadcasting service. Their budgets come largely from local, foundation and educational institution funding, with a small amount from local, State and federal governments. I raise this because I think that public television is a real alternative and I point out that a public television group, the Melbourne-based Television Unlimited (TVU), after a two-year campaign in which I have had great pleasure in participating, has been granted a test licence. It will broadcast throughout the western suburbs of Melbourne from 5 to 11 June on UHF channel 47. Television Unlimited is a local, non-profit group which has 100 per cent local content. It will offer all sorts of community groups the opportunity to have their programs beamed out to Melburnians over this important and influential medium-remembering Mr Keating's words. TVU coordinator Jenny Wilkins has said in the TVU newsletter:
The existing television networks, because of their centralised structure and national programming policies, cannot and do not cater to anything other than mainstream tastes.

The Opposition is simply offering us more of that. The programming policy of TVU is different in that it favours Australian programs, encourages experimentation and traditional formats and aims to demystify the television process for the viewer. Senator Evans has made some moves in this area which have been helpful and I hope that the Government will continue to assist and promote public television.

The Metro Group in Sydney is keen to begin and the Broadcasting Tribunal is looking at its application for a permit. Melbourne has led a 10-year campaign for the introduction of community television and a consultant with the Public Broadcasting Foundation, Mr Brian Walsh, a former Chairman of Open Channel where production work is done for community television in Victoria, has said that the prospects for community television were brighter now because the groups could use low power services and even share frequencies to cut costs. Issues such as frequency sharing, community television, and so on must be on the agenda of any political party, as they are on the agenda of the Australian Democrats. We profess to want to give more genuine diversity and localism to people in television viewing.

I have not heard today anything about the possibility of a narrowcaster for Australia on the channel 4 model which would provide an opportunity for specialist broadcasting and would attract specialist advertising, which is about the only way that we will get any more for broadcasting out of the advertising sector at the moment, if we listen to what the advertising sector is telling us. It is all very well to say that we should have more channels and more proprietors through a licensing system under the old tunnel vision network model, but it must be supported with advertising and that looks difficult at this time. Let us remember what is happening. This is significant legislation. Let us look at who are the winners: the viewers; certainly the Democrats, in that we are able to have it at 60 per cent; Ian Macphee in the Liberal Party; and, on the other side, the Caucus committee, which has made achievements in all of this. The losers are the network bosses; Senator Evans, who has not even been able to get up to 15 per cent; and, of course, as has been well canvassed in this debate and no doubt will be further canvassed, the leadership of the Liberal Party of Australia and in particular Mr Howard and Senator Messner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —So far in this debate on the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill 1988 and a related Bill we have heard two issues. First, we have heard some discussion on the merits of the legislation, but only some. The main points that were made by the Government's only speaker so far bore little relationship to the merits or otherwise of the proposal to change after the event the ownership limits of television stations in order to suit a particular purchase by a particular entrepreneur. The Government's only speaker so far has preferred to deal with prescribed disagreements within the coalition over the general issue of the level of ownership which should be permitted in an endeavour to brush aside the reality of the massive and major divisions which have existed and which continue to exist today in the Australian Labor Party over the question of media ownership. We have seen one Minister shunted aside, out of this portfolio, by the Labor Government because he would not toe the line on the dictates of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about which of his mates would be looked after in which way by this Government. To hear the hypocrisy coming from the Government on this issue today is quite sickening, particularly when it comes from one of the key operatives-the Government's only speaker-within the quaint power groupings, the factions, of the Labor Party. It is sickening that he should have had the capacity to spout this hypocritical nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look, as I intend to, at the actual merits of the issue. I know that it will distress members of the Labor Party that the merits should be discussed, but that is the approach of the Opposition because it is on the merits of the issue that our amendment is based. I want to restate the amendment moved by Senator Messner, which says:

At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate expresses its view that all television audience reach restrictions be removed to allow a potential 100 per cent audience reach for all competitors on the conditions that:
(a) the Government's moratorium on the introduction of pay and cable television be removed;
(b) the existing television licensing procedures be substantially streamlined;
(c) cross-media rules between pay and cable television and existing free-to-air broadcasters be introduced subject to `grandfathering' of existing holdings; and
(d) when the process of aggregation-
that is, of course, of rural television stations to provide competition-
has been completed, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal conduct an inquiry into issuing new television licences in metropolitan markets, subject to a final decision being made by the Government.''

In other words, the coalition is presenting the clear, free market alternative to the proposal by the Government which, in fact, is restrictive of the marketplace and limits the capacity of new entrants by limiting the number of television stations that exist and having a moratorium on cable television. We can now see which party has the coherent, positive and proper approach to allowing the consumer to dictate what should happen in the television markets of Australia. This Government persists with the view that it, and the bureaucracy in Canberra, should dictate to the people who actually watch the programs on television what sort of competition should be allowed, how it should be limited and how those limits should, after the event, be changed to suit the requirements of individual entrepreneurs.

That is what this Government is all about. It is not interested in protecting the interests of consumers. We have not yet heard a word from the Government's only speaker so far about the interests of the consumer. We have only heard the tirade about perceived problems within the coalition. Let us look at this from the point of view of the consumer-the Australian, the person whose interests we are representing but who has received no attention whatsoever from the Government, which makes decisions based not on what is good for the consumer but what is good for individual media magnates.

There are only two coherent positions that a government can take on the issue of ownership of television stations. One can go to a total free market; in other words, allow 100 per cent access to the market. If a television group wants to have access to compete in every market in Australia-not monopolise, but compete-it should have it, provided that there is much freer access than there is now to new participants and to more competitors who come into the marketplace to provide whatever the consumer wants. That is one position. The alternative, soundly-based position which can be argued is that no one should have access to more than, say, 25 per cent of the market. I can understand that position, but in the end I do not favour it as against 100 per cent. But I understand the 25 per cent position and the merit of limiting ownership to 25 per cent because in this way one would prevent any one operator dominating or controlling networks that exist around Australia in such a way that other members of that network will be unfairly treated or dominated, not only to their disadvantage but also to the disadvantage of the viewing public. The one thing that has escaped the notice of the Government and many of the skilled-I use the word `skilled' in inverted commas-commentators in the media, judging from this morning's response, is that there is such a thing as networking in Australia. The bright sparks from the Press Gallery have apparently not recognised that there is networking and that when someone owns either 60 per cent or 75 per cent of that network that person dominates it and is in a position to impose his views and, in effect, his programs on many of the smaller groupings within those networks.

I would not be surprised if some of the smaller members of those networks would be quite happy to see the 100 per cent ownership rule, which we support, introduced so that they could sell out and cease being in that dominated position. But, as I said, the existence of networking, which is here now, renders the debate for between 60 per cent and 75 per cent ownership largely ludicrous. In terms of the benefits to the consumer, it is almost immaterial whether it is 60 per cent or 75 per cent ownership. It means nothing to the consumer because it does not change the essential networking system. Despite Mr Skase's arguments about the need to have what he described as a `critical mass'-in other words, a basic audience-if one is to provide more and better Australian-made services, there is no evidence to indicate that one needs 75 per cent ownership to achieve that critical mass. It has not been established, nor do I believe it is capable of being established, that there is any increase in benefit to the consumer, the Australian television watcher, in moving from one artificial number, 60 per cent, to another artificial number, 75 per cent-or, as the Democrats say, to another artificial number, 43 per cent. Under the Australian Democrats' proposal, if one has control of Sydney and Melbourne, in effect one has potential domination over one's network. It is the network that is the issue; networking exists.

Why should consumers be in favour of increasing the audience reach from 60 to 75 per cent? There is no clear benefit to them. But there is a clear benefit to the Australian Labor Party. The clear benefit to the Labor Party is that, once again, it will be seeking to demonstrate to a media owner that the Labor Party is pliable to the requirements of media owners and that that pliability should be rewarded appropriately at election time. Why have we had a succession of Labor Government legislative changes which have been of specific benefit to specific people and, I might say, of specific disadvantage to other specific people? There is no doubt in my mind that the cross-media legislation was aimed largely at destroying the viability of the Fairfax group because the Fairfax group was seen, particularly by the right wing of the Labor Party of New South Wales, as an enemy of the Labor Party. That legislation has succeeded. We have seen legislative change over and over again to bring benefit to individual people and, in this case, after the event-after a media owner has expanded beyond the limits set by legislation. There are no benefits to the customer, but there are to the Labor Party and there are, of course, to the person who, if the legislation goes through, will be able to retain a television station which he would not be able to retain under the present legislation.

Whether anyone else stands to benefit from the proposed change is a question that has to be answered in the negative. In fact, the legislation will disadvantage other people in this area. Had other participants in the marketplace known before the event that the 60 per cent level was to be increased by the Government to 75 per cent, they may have wanted to bid for the South Australian and Western Australian licences. But there was no knowledge of the Government's intention. The Government obediently responded to change the law only after the bids had been made, after the purchase had taken place.

One of the essential elements of good government is that governments should ensure there is a level playing field in the marketplace. Governments should ensure that one operator, one purchaser, does not have special access to, or special knowledge of, changes, or potential changes and that all participants should have the opportunity of knowing what the ground rules are. There may be people who have every right to be angered that they were denied the opportunity to make a bid for those stations because they did not know that the law was to be changed and they took the view that it would be illegal to acquire and hold those stations because that is what the law said. Those people may not have realised that this Government is purchasable, not necessarily for money-the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd affair showed that it does not even honour those debts-but for other benefits, apparently. When a government responds consistently to the pressures of people from whom it sees the possibility of an ultimate benefit, that government is innately corrupt. This legislation is all about a level of corruption within this Government-not a corruption in terms of money, but a corruption in terms of morality.

In my view, on those grounds alone, there is a sound case for saying that either one goes to 100 per cent now, which would enable Mr Skase to acquire these television stations, or one does nothing about it-one does not go down the Government's track; one reminds the Government that its position is intolerable and disgraceful, and one rejects the legislation. There is no doubt that in the absence of freeing up the marketplace there can be no argument for increasing the ability to hold a larger capacity of access Australian television markets. Yet this Government is not interested in doing that. It is not interested in the benefits to the consumer that would emerge from genuine competition in the marketplace. That is in total conflict and contrast with the Government's public statements.

The Government has claimed to be the arch-deregulator. In recent days Mr Keating has, quite absurdly, attacked the coalition, which has come out with the most deregulatory policy on the media that has ever been seen in Australia. Mr Keating accuses the Opposition of saying in its party room: `No, we will not have a sensible, logical network in television. We will not have a sensible, logical basis driving our industry policy. We will not let market forces determine anything. We will decide it'. Let Mr Keating put his vote where his mouth is. If he does not want the Government to decide it and he wants the marketplace and the people of Australia to determine things, let him vote for our amendment which seeks to allow 100 per cent access and increase the real competition in the marketplace. But, of course, Mr Keating behaves with the same hypocrisy that we are seeing from other members of his Party in this place today.

Mr Keating claimed that the shadow Ministry and the coalition say that a fragmented market with no economies of scale and no logical structure is preferable to a sensible, viable network. Apparently, Mr Keating does not realise that networks already exist and that it is not a question of ownership that creates networking. At this level of control it is a question of domination of the network already. Once one gets to 60 per cent control one dominates that network.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even if you have 45 per cent control you dominate the network.

—Despite that interjection, one also heavily dominates it when one has Sydney and Melbourne at 43 per cent. As I said, 25 per cent is the only other coherent position. That is the ratio that is allowed in the United States, where-for Mr Keating's benefit-there are networks which are effective and which work. So, as I say, though, I prefer the 100 per cent option to the 25 per cent option, but I can understand the logic behind the 25 per cent position. We have here the Labor Government claiming the clothes of deregulation while refusing to go along with our amendment which would genuinely deregulate the market.

SPEECH.PARA: I also have some concerns about the manner in which this issue has come to us. The sixth report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, brought down on 27 April 1988, also expresses concern about this continuing tendency to govern to Press release. That report stated:

The Committee noted that it would be undesirable if information as to the Government's intention on such questions as ownership and policy were either the subject of rumour and speculation, or available only to a privileged few in the community while legislation was in the course of preparation and drafting.

Equally, the Committee is concerned to point out that the two principal problems for the Parliament which were highlighted in the above reports in the practice of `legislation by press release' are again illustrated by this Bill.

Firstly, by indicating that the legislation changes in ownership rules, such as broadcasting, is to be retrospective to the date of a Minister's announcement, a degree of uncertainty as to the status of the law during the period between the announcement and the passage of the necessary legislation by the Parliament is created. The ability of Parliamentarians to assess the merit of proposed legislation may be prejudiced by the realisation that people have altered their position (for example by making large investments) in reliance on a government's prior media announcement that the legislation is to be introduced. To that extent such announcements are a matter of concern.

Second, by the time the Parliament considers the Bill, the Parliament may be placed in the invidious position of either agreeing to the legislation without major amendment or upsetting transactions which may have taken place during the intervening period in reliance on the Minister's announcement.

The Committee accordingly draws the clause to the Senate's attention in that by reason of its retrospective effect it may be considered to breach principle 1 (a) (i) and trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.
According to that bipartisan Scrutiny of Bills Committee, there is no doubt that the Government is doing the wrong thing in a bad way in regard to this issue.

I have another concern regarding the way this matter has been handled in the media itself. In particular, I think the sort of headlines that we have seen, particularly today, justify the sort of comment that Mr Howard made about the media being extraordinarily selective and having incredible double standards in its handling of this matter. It is extraordinary that on the very issue of media control the continual governmental disagreements seem to have been forgotten by reporters and commentators at this time. In a newspaper report of last night's Press conference Mr Howard said of the media:
`I think you, in the main, as a group, have a double standard. Duncan and West, with monotonous regularity-
I point out that one of them is a member of the inner Cabinet and the other is a Minister-
are publicly bucketing the Hawke-Keating position on privatisation. Almost every weekend they are doing it.'
The newspaper article continued:
When a reporter interjected, `Mr Howard, almost every weekend you've got a bunfight going,' Mr Howard said: `That's a bunfight?-
that is, what is going on in our Party-
The other is an orderly discussion process.'

That is, what is going on in the Australian Labor Party. The double standards of the media in handling this matter concerning the Opposition and the matter of the continual governmental disagreement and factional warfare are, I believe, extraordinary. As an ex-journalist I raised this problem with a former colleague in the Gallery. His response was: `Yes, it is true that we tend to concentrate more on disagreements within the coalition when you are forming policy because we are so accustomed to brawling and disputation within the Labor Party that it is no longer news. But it is unusual and therefore newsworthy when we see evidence of disagreement within the coalition'. There is a double standard there. In other words, because Opposition disagreement is worth reporting only because it happens so rarely, this means that it gets enormous publicity. I believe that this is an admission of incompetence by members of the Press Gallery.

I believe the reality is largely as it was reported by Paul Kelly-another member of the Press Gallery-in this morning's Australian newspaper. He says quite clearly that what we have ended up with now is:
an Opposition television policy of more competition, more players and more deregulation in the run-up to the next election.

Perhaps we could thank the Government for maybe hastening the development of what I believe to be an outstanding, deregulatory and proper policy-unlike the ad hoc, disgraceful, bowing to pressure policy of the present Government, a policy which bears no relationship to the needs and requirements of the consumer but continually kowtows to the demands of media magnates.

I think that Mr Paul Kelly is right when he says that Mr Howard now has a policy that `he feels he can champion. Indeed, the actual policy seems quite clever'. I think that the policy is far more than quite clever. I think it is outstanding, particularly in the vacuum created on the Government side. What is the Government's real policy? Does it favour deregulation, or does it not? To use Mr Keating's own style of words, he says, `You have to free it up, and the Government is doing it'. If the Government is doing it, why is it limiting ownership to 75 per cent? Why is it prohibiting new competitors from coming into the television area?

I must say that I can think of better ways for the birth of this sound and proper coalition policy. It could have had a more comfortable birth, but the reality is that now we have a policy as the coalition which will be an effective and coherent one when we are in government. It is a policy which will not allow a situation whereby a government can continually make special concessions at special request as a result of pressure from people who have in fact extended their ownership beyond the limit set by the law, and whereby it can make a special fellow of itself, to be owed a favour, by making those kinds of changes. Alan Ramsey, a Sydney Morning Herald reporter, who is not unknown for having some political associations, has said that the Opposition has imposed conditions in going to this free market because it knows the Government almost certainly will reject them. The reason is that the left wing of the Labor Party will not let the Government go to the free market because it is opposed to the free market. The left wing is opposed to allowing 100 per cent access. It is opposed to having new media players. It is interesting that neither Mr Ramsey nor any other journalist in the Press Gallery has noted that the only reason our amendment will not be accepted by the Government is the internal dissension which made it so hard for this particular proposed amendment to get through the Labor Caucus. For Mr Keating to plead purity on this issue is a hollow sham. The Government stands condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I turn to the key themes of the debate on the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill and the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill I feel I need to comment briefly on the remarks made by poor old Senator Michael Baume in his attempts to pretend that somehow or other--
—What's this `old' business? We are both losing our hair.

—I thought the honourable senator was much less poor than old. It seems to me that Senator Baume made only four points in his speech. First, Senator Baume, at least, opposes the cross-ownership rule, the one thing which did something to change substantially the nature of media ownership in Australia. The second point is that he does not understand that nobody in Australia, no television owner anywhere near the 60 per cent limit, could have bought the stations in Adelaide and Perth. The only two owners near the 60 per cent limit already own stations in Perth and are not eligible to buy the stations up for offer and purchased by Mr Skase. So all that stuff about there perhaps being other people wanting to buy it who were deprived because they did not know about any forthcoming change in Government policy is absolutely specious. Thirdly, Senator Baume has a problem with his short term memory. He thinks that the 75 per cent policy is a new Government policy, whereas it was announced in November 1986. He also seems to have a problem with his memory when he complains about media bias. One of the things which I and all my colleagues in the Australian Labor Party find most amusing is Liberal Party representatives complaining about media bias. I do not want to be diverted to that for too long; I merely note with amusement the irony of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The other interesting point is that Senator Baume, in a brief aside about the Labor Party taking donations from companies, said that we do not even honour our undertakings in that regard. That seemed to me to carry some implication that people who donate to the Liberal Party do expect undertakings to be honoured in return, and the Opposition's attitude to matters raised concerning Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd is more understandable in that light.

I turn to the key themes I want to raise in this debate. First, are we to have any consistency and rationality in policy on television ownership and media ownership in general, or are we just to have a hotch potch? That applies both to the ownership of television and-more importantly if we look at the broader question of ownership of the media-to the development of pay television. I was also very interested to hear Senator Baume ask whether we were going to have a policy that provided, in the interests of the viewers, for the development of localism and local production, or a policy that gave us the domination by Sydney and Melbourne that the old 43 per cent rule used to mean.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two-station rule is different from the 43 per cent rule.
—The two-station rule was actually worse than the 43 per cent rule, but the 43 per cent has the same effect.
—No, it doesn't.

—I know the honourable senator likes to pretend it does not, but she does not comprehend that that is its effect. That is perfectly understandable. We must also ask whether the interests of the viewers, and particularly those who are constituents of mine, will be influenced by an effective denial of aggregation. Of course we must also consider the interests of the workers in the industry, who have been lobbying various senators, particularly those from South Australia and Western Australia-I understand why they have not been to the Australian Democrats or to members from New South Wales and Victoria, such as Senator Baume and Senator Powell-on localism and local production.

SPEECH.PARA: Fundamentally we have here a debate about 60 per cent as against 75 per cent. We have had a couple of red herrings drawn across, and we have this fig leaf of 100 per cent-a fig leaf to try to cover the embarrassing exposure of the defeat of Senator Messner and Mr Howard. It is a very small fig leaf trying to cover a very large embarrassment. They could well be guilty of indecent exposure. Certainly they want to impose a large number of irrational requirements as pre-conditions for the extension to 100 per cent. They say, `Let's quickly get in and change the policy on pay and cable television before we find out the facts about it'. They know nobody would do that, and they would be horrified if we did. They also say that we should let the existing television licensing procedures be substantially streamlined. That may or may not be a good idea; no-one knows what they mean. What they do not say is that those procedures need to be strengthened. After considering these matters the Labor Party Caucus made the very appropriate decision that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal needs effective strengthened powers.

Senator Messner and Mr Howard want to do something with cross-media rules for pay and cable television. I will come back to that because I am sympathetic to that proposal, but it does not make sense to deal with it before we have an inquiry and establish the facts. However, as I say, I do not totally disagree with the thrust of that proposal. They want to have an inquiry into issuing new television licences in metropolitan markets, when they know or they should know-certainly the shadow Minister who is supposed to be responsible for communications policy should know-that it cannot and will not work because of the nature of the Australian advertising market in contemporary circumstances. So we have this 100 per cent fig leaf or we have the 43 per cent proposal, which I acknowledge is different from the two-station rule and better than that rule but which has the same effective impact of concentrating production in Sydney and Melbourne. That is what the 60 per cent rule will do, as well. They are the places from which the networks will be totally dominated and in which production will be concentrated, because if a company cannot sell its program to Sydney and Melbourne it cannot make a profit.

In 1982 the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal noted that the two-station rule, which effectively gave owners 43 per cent access, had largely contributed to the concentration of power and influence which it was originally designed to prevent, and the structural imbalance had caused domination by the Sydney and Melbourne stations. It noted that such dominance was out of proportion to their population size. So it was not just their 43 per cent coverage but also their dominant position in the market that led to the two-station rule not working. That is why the 43 per cent rule will not work, even if it were possible to unscramble a scrambled egg-which it is not.

We now have an effective choice between 60 and 75 per cent. What is wrong with 60 per cent? It can fundamentally be summarised like this: Government policy should not be like a pair of kid's shoes. We should not just be able to grow out of it. That is what will happen with the 60 per cent rule. Current owners, consistent with the present laws and without any change of policy, and without any action by them, will grow out of the existing policy unless they deny aggregation to people in rural Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —All they have to do is sell Capital 7.

—Exactly. So the policy is saying that these owners have not done anything that they should not do but because of very good and appropriate government policy to introduce aggregation to this area of southern New South Wales, to south-east Queensland and to north Queensland they have to sell, and sell from a position of weakness because they are required to sell. We would be imposing a forced sale upon them through no fault of their own. The impact of this forced sale provision is different for Mr Skase in Adelaide and Perth. That is his risk. He took the risk; I do not debate that. But the forced sale of the far north Queensland stations, the south-east Queensland stations and the Canberra station is not caused by any breach of the law by the Seven, Ten or Nine networks; it is caused because somebody has imposed a silly policy that we can grow out of. That is, firstly, an unfair, unreasonable and nonsensical policy that ought to be amended as soon as possible but, secondly, it will deny for at least 12 months, until that forced sale is finalised, services to the people of southern New South Wales and, effectively, the south-eastern and northern parts of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is an entirely inappropriate outcome. It is not surprising that we get a silly outcome from a silly process like that which the Opposition went through in formulating its policy. If I thought we would be better off under 43 per cent or a two-station rule I might have agreed. Dealing with the Nationals is a very bad idea. Dealing with the alternatives is worse. It is a bit like Winston Churchill's comment about democracy-it is the worst form of government except all the others. The deal with the Nationals was the worst conceivable proposal except all of the others that were before us, including the Australian Democrats proposal.

Let me turn briefly to the Opposition's so-called policy. I notice that everybody who gets up to defend the policy does not spend much time talking about it, and they never actually say why they are going to vote in this place for a 60 per cent rule, because it never logically follows from the other comments they make. The Opposition was described by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as a bunch of wimps, and certainly that summarises the longer comments that other people have made concerning the leadership of the Liberal Party. What I am trying to find out is whether, having heard Senator Michael Baume, the Opposition is actually deregulating regulators or regulating deregulators. It is doing one or the other, because it is saying that it wants a free market and deregulation, but it is actually going to vote for the 60 per cent rule. I would be fascinated to hear the intellectual contortion that gets the Opposition through the eye of that particular needle so that we can understand, because it is not supporting 100 per cent. It knows that that fig leaf is very insubstantial. Its objective is really 60 per cent. It is true that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) would like 100 per cent, and I suspect it is true that the shadow Minister for communications, Senator Messner, and perhaps even Senator Michael Baume-nobody could tell-would really like 100 per cent, but why are they all going to turn out and vote for 60 per cent? By what rational criteria are they going to do that?

I support the range of Government decisions that are reflected in this legislation and in the decisions that went with it and the package of decisions that will lead to a series of further reforms. I support the decision about 75 per cent. We need consistent, logical and predictable decisions in that area. That policy has been extant for 18 months. It ought to be sustained so that people know the environment in which they are making decisions. I support that part of the package of decisions that will require divestiture by the Murdoch group from Channel 10 and the Fairfax group from Channel 7. I did sympathise with the crocodile tears that Senator Michael Baume shed about that, but I think most Australians believe that it is entirely appropriate that those cross-ownership provisions should be retained.

I support the proposal for an inquiry into pay television. That is why I was fascinated by the proposal that we ought just to go helter-skelter into it without looking at the matters that need to be taken into account and without hearing the views of the Australian people. The Government has proposed that a policy options paper will be released, and then there will be months for public comment and consultation. But, of course, that is not a good idea. According to the Opposition we ought to charge in and do something without the facts. For the inquiry to be objective it first has to look at whether we ought to introduce pay television services or not. I do not object to someone trying independently to make a decision about that. It is a matter of economic judgment. I believe it is an arguable proposition, although I think the inquiry is appropriate.

But what are the answers to these questions: the number and range of pay television services that should be provided; the effects of the introduction of pay television upon the existing broadcasting and communications systems; the regulatory requirements, such as limits on ownership and control, cross-media ownership and foreign ownership. I did not see anything about that in the Opposition proposal. What about the likely effects on the production in Australia of films and television programs; the scope for participation by Australian industry in the provision, manufacture, installation and servicing of equipment; and, the appropriate timetable for the possible introduction of pay television? They are a series of sensible questions for an inquiry. Unlike some people, we do not come up with the answers before we have the inquiry. I know that the facts could be an embarrassment to anybody trying to defend the Opposition's communications policy, but I support the pursuit of them.

There have been, of course, inquiries in other countries. In the past they have made some very substantial contributions to the debate about cable television. I refer briefly to just one of them, the Sloan Commission on Cable Communications in 1970-71 in the United States, set up by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation and headed by Edward Mason, the then Chairman of the Graduate School of Public Administration at Harvard University. It was a very interesting report, although I do not agree with all of its conclusions. But it made some very interesting comments about ownership, which I would like to put on the record. Although they are not necessarily entirely appropriate in all respects for Australia, they are an interesting starting point. They state:
The Commission recommends that network ownership of cable franchises be prohibited . . .
It recommends:
that a limit be set on the number of cable subscribers served nationally by any single individual or corporate enterprise engaged in ownership of cable franchises . . .
Perhaps some sort of percentage limit of market access. What a revolutionary idea, but of course the Opposition would support 100 per cent, because that is its policy. We know that.
The Commission recommends that local commercial television stations and newspapers of general circulation be permitted to seek franchises within their own . . . areas . . .

I am a bit doubtful about that proposal, but I think it is an interesting distinction between local stations and newspapers and network owners, provided no single such enterprise possesses franchises capable of reaching more than 10 per cent of households within the area. The Commission recommended that the public television stations in America be permitted to operate cable franchises and that restrictions on commercial stations and newspapers be waived if no other bidders for cable franchises appeared. It believed that the separation of ownership and programming were undesirable. I think some of those proposals, on the basis of the examination I have made today, I intuitively agree with. Some I am not persuaded of, but I do think they have made a substantial contribution to the debate. I think they indicate the sorts of issues about which we need an inquiry before we proceed in that direction, desirable as it would be, if it proves viable.

In conclusion, the people of Australia at the moment are faced with a stark choice in communications policy. There are really only two choices. They can have an irrational, changing and unpredictable policy that is not supported by the Leader, shadow Minister or any Liberal Party State Leader or any participant or informed commentator in the area, or a logical and consistent policy which provides the basis for investment in production for localism and development of the industry and creates the opportunity for expedited aggregation. I regret that the Senate will probably make the wrong decision about it but I am very confident that the people of Australia will not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my strong opposition to the Government's proposed amendment to the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill 1988. We call our country a democracy. The sort of democracy we have depends on information. It depends absolutely on ordinary individuals getting accurate and up to date information on what is happening in the country and what is happening overseas and on the various debates which go on in this place and in other places about matters of the day. The way in which ordinary people in this country participate in the political process is either by joining a political party or by voting. Either way, the effective use of their access to the political process depends upon their ability to judge between competing points of view. Yet we find, increasingly, that the main organs of information are becoming controlled by fewer and fewer people.

SPEECH.PARA: New South Wales once had a very extensive network of local and regional newspapers. Such a network hardly exists today. Such newspapers have been bought out by the big print media interests. That has been beneficial to the odd radio station-because local radio stations have gone the same way-or newspapers around the State. It may have been useful for some local media interests to get a financial and creative input from outside the local region but, in general, because profitability in these large-scale enterprises is the key to success, there is a preoccupation with advertising and a de-emphasis on editorial content. So any old thing that comes to hand is thrown in as news while all the energy and resources of the enterprise are put into making sure that the advertisements are correct. So the advertisements are proofread and they get the creative input; the news and editorial content get a cursory glance and are thrown in.

I find it disquieting that this Government-supposedly a Labor government but it is the Hawke conservative Government-which is meant to represent the interests of ordinary Australians, has succumbed to pressure exerted by the media barons who can formulate and develop public opinion by their stranglehold on the media. In this day and age television is probably the most influential medium-and television is the subject of this debate. On 18 April I received a long letter, by fax, from Christopher Skase. I wrote a letter back to Mr Skase in which I said, `Thanks, but no thanks. I am voting against the proposal. I do not believe that your interests match the interests of the ordinary Australian'. But still I get letters and faxes from Mr Skase, which I will go into later. Mr Skase was arguing the case for increased television reach. The fact that he faxed such a long letter to every senator and member indicates that money is no object to Mr Skase and that he already has enormous power and influence. Attached to this letter was a copy of the editorial from the Australian that day, an editorial so ludicrous it suggests that Rupert Murdoch might have written it himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —He probably did.

—Senator Powell said that he probably did. The editorial asserted that commercial television is composed purely of channels of entertainment and that commercial television does not change a vote through argument.
—At least it doesn't agree with the Treasurer.

—Obviously it does not. I wonder whether the writer of the editorial in the Australian meant what he was saying-and it probably was a he. I wonder whether he was serious. Surely it is stretching credibility too far to argue that current affairs programs and news are purely entertainment. What do the producers of 60 Minutes think, or the producers of the news programs? Sometimes I look at news and current affairs on the commercial stations and I see a large swag of time being taken up with cute stories about fat cats-real fat pussy cats, not other sorts of fat cats. Is this news, current affairs or entertainment? Obviously, commercial television has at least to be interesting. Perhaps some people get confused about what is interesting and what is entertaining. So we get entertaining things in news rather than interesting things. I do not know whether any of the Willesee clan, who seem to be ubiquitous in just about every medium, believe that commercial television is about anything other than entertainment. Either way, commercial television influences the views of Australians, not least by its choice of news items and subjects for current affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Because commercial television influences and develops public opinion, it is necessary to restrict television reach and control. The Americans restrict television reach more than we do. They restrict it to 25 per cent. I would favour a figure in Australia of something like 20 per cent. The city of Sydney is probably a reasonable maximum limit in terms of commercial reach. So I would favour something like a 20 per cent limit which would allow ownership of a television station in the large city of Sydney but no more.

The current level of 60 per cent is too high. To consider raising it to 75 per cent is nothing short of a major sellout of the interests of ordinary Australians. I support Senator Powell in her arguments in favour of her Broadcasting (Ownership and Control Television Licences) Bill, restricting television reach to 43 per cent. I disagree with the Australian Democrats on the figure they have struck; my figure would be lower. Senator Powell cited four main reasons for her Bill. One was to reduce the enormous social and political power of the present big three owners of television, Bond, Skase and Westfield. Increasingly, we have presidential style elections with image outweighing substance. Over the last few elections we have seen how style and image in our political leaders are more important than substance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you say that that is how you got elected, on image and style, rather than substance?

—I will answer Senator Messner. In New South Wales, the Nuclear Disarmament Party made a conscious decision not to adopt the cult of personality in our election campaign. My name appeared in no place other than on the how to vote cards and on the ballot paper. The Nuclear Disarmament Party in New South Wales campaigned on the issues and on the Party. I do not believe in the politics of style and image but in the politics of substance, which is why I am saying that I do not believe in the presidential style of elections, which is what is happening. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) admitted that the importance of television in formulating and developing public opinion is unquestioned. If this situation does not change, the big three will be determining the political future of this country to a much greater extent than they already do.

SPEECH.PARA: The second aspect of Senator Powell's Bill is that it will encourage new players into television ownership. I find John Howard's platitudes concerning free enterprise quite extraordinary. If he were sincere about free enterprise he would like a bit of healthy competition, one would think, but not monopolies by media giants who can buy everyone else out, which is what he is advocating. It seems to me that monopolies are in direct opposition to free enterprise. But in a lot of the economic argument that I have heard in this place, free enterprise is merely the means to create monopolies.

That sort of economics, that sort of free enterprise, involves the development of larger monopolies, so fewer people make more profits. If people were sincere about deregulation, they would be advocating a complete and absolute deregulation of the whole industry, including licensing, so that anyone who can afford to build a transmitter can broadcast. That is what free enterprise and deregulation are all about: anyone who can afford to broadcast should be able to do so. What would happen then to Skase's almost monopolistic interests?

The third aspect of Senator Powell's Bill is that it will prevent regional television interests from being engulfed. Despite Christopher Skase's arguments to the contrary, an increase in television reach will simply allow those who presently dominate metropolitan television to buy up and dominate regional television holdings. It will lead not to a diversity but to a horrifying sameness from coast to coast. There is already a horrifying sameness from channel to channel. One switches channels and gets the same American situation comedies; they are there no matter what channel one looks at.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good argument for pay television, isn't it?

—It is a good argument for local production houses producing community television, producing programs for a community of interest. Finally, the Bill seeks to redress the imbalance in negotiations between the major networks and regional groups aligned with the networks and lower the limits, so that Sydney and Melbourne will not be the only centres to make production and programming decisions. It seems that everyone everywhere will be watching Sydney or Melbourne television. We have already had the horrifying experience in New South Wales of having that great entertainer Derryn Hinch gracing the television sets of Sydney.
—You are welcome to him.

—Senator Powell says that we are welcome to him, but I point out to Senator Powell that she can have him back with pleasure. I suppose that Derryn Hinch would be the example par excellence of where the line between what is news and what is current affairs and entertainment blurs.
—I will trade him for Clive Robertson.

—We will keep Clive Robertson. I will not trade Clive Robertson for Derryn Hinch. If the Labor Party really cares about democracy, about sharing power, it should allow regional groups some negotiating power, power which they do not have now and which certainly they would have less of if the limit were raised to 75 per cent. Despite the fact that I politely wrote back to Christopher Skase outlining my views, laying it fairly clearly on the line where I stood on his proposal, this morning I got another letter from an increasingly desperate Christopher Skase, with a copy of the editorial from yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald. The editorial argued for an increase in the limit. It is a pity that Mr Skase did not include the editorial from yesterday's Age, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: If there is a case for public regulation of commercial television . . . then such regulation should be based on reasonable criteria of public interest and not the arrogant dictates of media moguls . . . what is best for Christopher Skase or Alan Bond or Frank Lowy is not necessarily best for Australia.

`Hear, hear', say I. Maybe we should be abolishing the whole system that we have here and follow instead the model in Britain, where no television channel is commercially owned. Most people would agree that British television is the best and most varied in the world. There the Independent Television Authority franchises 15 competitive program companies to produce commercial television programs for 14 regions. The companies that make the best programs make the most money, by selling them to other regions and abroad. There is real competition in production. If the Opposition wants to talk about private enterprise and producing quality television, let us have a serious look at the British system and at how applicable it is to the current situation.

It is time that the media moguls stopped calling the tune in this country. Because Christopher Skase arrogantly bought up a couple more stations and raised his coverage to 67 per cent, the Government seems to be falling over itself in its rush to accommodate him through this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wanted to do it anyway.

—Yes; this is probably just a prod in the right direction-or in the wrong direction, depending on one's point of view. What we need in this country is control and regulation of the media moguls. The public interest should dictate what these media moguls do, not the other way round. It is not in the interests of the public to have wealth and greed the sole determinants of television ownership. It is imperative that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal have the power to rule on takeovers so that the interests of the public can be preserved. The Tribunal awarded the third television licence in Perth to Kerry Stokes, after an exhaustive inquiry, and yet after no time at all it was sold, at massive profit, to Westfield's Frank Lowy, and that pushed his audience share to 60 per cent. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal was not able to stop that. It is a ludicrous situation that must be redressed.

SPEECH.PARA: In considering further the matter of the interests of the public, we need to look at Alan Bond and his comments about Chile. I hope that no-one in this chamber has any sorts of fond feelings for Pinochet, the most foul dictator there has ever been. Yet, Alan Bond came away from Chile and said that things were fairly okay over there and that Pinochet had had a bit of bad Press. He said that perhaps a film crew ought to be sent over there to clean up Pinochet's image a bit. Is that in the best interests of truth? Is that in the best interests of objective reporting? If Bond has that sort of attitude to Pinochet, where is the commitment to any sort of objectivity? Where is the commitment to any sort of unbiased reporting? Of course, there is no commitment in that regard. Neither Bond nor Skase nor Lowy care about information. They do not care whether the information that goes through their media outlets is unbiased or informative or truthful-none of that. All they care about is having stuff going through their media outlets that is entertaining, that will sell television time and newspapers, or whatever it is-anything that will make money and be profitable.

It seems to me that we need more control over who says what to the Australian people. Bond should not be allowed to simply clean up Pinochet's image just because Bond has gold mining and other interests in Chile. Of course, Bond has interests with the Pentagon from which he is receiving billions of dollars to produce airships. It is a very important contract for Mr Bond, so where will Mr Bond sit with his media interests if a situation arises where Australia's interests are in direct conflict with American foreign policy? There is no doubt about it: Mr Bond has proved to us with the Chile example that he will come down on the side of where his profits and commercial interests lie.

In Australia we no longer have media barons in the Fairfax tradition of concern for the media. Of course, Fairfax was Fairfax, and media barons of his ilk had their biases; they came from a particular class with a particular background and that showed in their publications. Nevertheless, they had an interest in the media. Their concern was the media and they had a commitment to produce what they thought was unbiased reporting. However, we now have financial barons-rather than media barons-whose interests are primarily financial and only one of their interests is the media. The media interests of these financial barons are secondary to their overall commercial interests, and that is something that we must address.

I oppose the amendment because I do not believe that it is in the public interest. I would argue for a figure even lower than the 43 per cent proposed by the Australian Democrats, and I will support Senator Powell's amendment to that effect. I call on the Senate to look again at the whole industry and give serious consideration to adopting the British system, under which media moguls are not allowed to control and influence the media. The time when media interests in this country catered to the interests of the general public is long gone. The media is now secondary to the interests of big business and to the financial interests of large corporations. There should be a guarantee that the media will produce information which is unbiased and as informative as possible to assist ordinary Australians to make informed decisions about the great political and social problems of the day.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tate) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The proposed Admiralty Bill will give Australia, for the first time, a comprehensive, up to date, locally enacted and uniform law governing the exercise of Admiralty jurisdiction by Australian courts. The law will replace existing Imperial legislation. In the Bicentennial year it is appropriate that we remove one further piece of old, inherited British legislation from our statute book and replace it with legislation specifically designed for Australian conditions. This the Bill is designed to do.

The Bill follows the recommendations contained in the Report No. 33 on Civil Admiralty Jurisdiction prepared by the Australian Law Reform Commission and issued at the end of 1986. That Report followed a reference given to the Commission by the former Coalition government in 1982.

The need for reform in this area has been recognised over a long period. A Joint Committee of the Maritime Law Association of Australia and New Zealand and the Law Council of Australia, with Justice Zelling as Chairman, in 1982 had produced a Joint Report on reform of Admiralty jurisdiction. The Law Reform Commission was required to have regard to this Report in its consideration of the matter. It received, as well, input from other maritime and legal bodies, State Governments and individuals, who it consulted in the preparation of the Report. All were agreed on the need for reform of Admiralty law.

The Report is a comprehensive analysis of admiralty jurisdiction and the Government, in seeking reactions to the Report, found widespread support for early implementation of the recommendations contained in it. I commend the Commission for its Report which has been widely praised.
Admiralty has long been a distinct jurisdiction in the court system. Business expectations rely on the fact that jurisdiction over ships and shipowners will be asserted in special ways.

Australia is principally a country of shippers rather than shipowners and is dependent on foreign shipping for much of its import and export trade. It is, therefore, in Australia's interest to support a broad Admiralty jurisdiction, which is dependent principally on the presence in the jurisdiction of the ship or sister ship in relation to which a maritime claim arises. The proposed legislation, therefore, asserts a broad admiralty jurisdiction but at the same time takes account of international trends and remains within internationally acceptable limits.

Admiralty jurisdiction exercised by the Courts has its own distinctive features. The key feature is the ability it provides to bring an action in rem-that is the power to arrest a ship (including foreign ships) within the jurisdiction of a State and to use that ship as security for a maritime claim. Actions in rem arise from the existence of a maritime lien or a statutory right of action based on a proprietary or general maritime claim arising under the general law and involving the ownership or operation of ships.

The Bill also provides for Admiralty jurisdiction to be exercised in relation to claims in personam-that is claims directed against a specific person-in relation to maritime claims or claims for damage to a ship.

The Bill does not attempt a substantive overhaul of the law. It does not, for instance, create new causes of action or, with the exception of cl. 34, create new substantive rights, as distinct from creating new procedures. The Bill, therefore, seeks to clarify what claims are subject to Admiralty jurisdiction and which Courts can exercise that jurisdiction. It is proposed that the Federal Court as well as the State and Territory Supreme Courts be invested with Admiralty jurisdiction.
I turn now to address the significant features of the proposed legislation:

Maritime claims are defined in detail in cl. 4. A distinction is made between proprietary maritime claims and general maritime claims. Proprietary claims involve claims relating to ownership or possession of a ship. General maritime claims include a wide range of claims arising from the operation of a ship.

The legislation retains the existing distinction in Admiralty law that exists between actions in rem based on maritime liens and statutory rights of action in rem based on causes of action arising under the general law and involving the ownership or operation of ships. It confers a right to proceed in rem over claims involving maritime liens in cl. 15 but does not seek to codify or define the substantive law governing maritime liens. Their traditional priority, ranking ahead of other maritime claims, is maintained.

The scope of the statutory right of action in rem is defined exhaustively and in detail. The circumstances in which claims in rem can be brought on maritime claims are set out in cls. 16-19. These clauses outline the nexus between a ship and the relevant person against whom the claim arises which is required before an action in rem can be brought.
Provision is made in cl. 19 for the first time in Australian law, for arrest of surrogate or sister ships. This is a feature of Admiralty law in certain other countries, including UK and NZ.
Admiralty jurisdiction in personam is conferred in cl. 9 with respect to maritime claims and in addition with respect to claims for damage done to a ship.

Concurrent jurisdiction in Admiralty is conferred on the Federal Court and State and Territory Supreme Courts. Appeals will proceed through the Full Court or Court of Appeal of the relevant Federal, State or Territory Court to the High Court, under the ordinary rules governing appeals from the respective Courts. The experience of the State Supreme Courts in admiralty matters is preserved.

Provision is made for the promulgation of uniform admiralty rules, applicable to all Admiralty actions. There is provision for a Rules Committee with a judge of the Federal Court and a Supreme Court to advise the Attorney-General on the Rules and possible amendment to them. The rules will be made by the Governor-General in Council and will be subject to disallowance by the Parliament.

The Bill will remove the uncertainly that arises from the continued application of old imperial legislation. In particular, the 1890 Colonial Courts of Admiralty Act will cease to operate in Australia. A number of other old Imperial enactments are repealed.
The Bill makes a number of minor consequential amendments to the Navigation Act 1912 and the Shipping Registration Act 1981.
Financial Impact Statement
The financial impact of the legislation is expected to be minimal. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to sessional order, the Senate will now consider matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March I asked the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who represents the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in this place, a question without notice about the funding of the drug Azidothymidine (AZT). Honourable senators will know that AZT is the main drug to have shown significant benefits to sufferers of acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). Certainly, it is one of the significant breakthroughs in terms of quality of life for such people. In his answer, the Minister stated that the Commonwealth had undertaken to contribute $1m to a program of clinical evaluation of AZT, on a dollar for dollar basis between the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories. The clinical trial involves about 200 patients around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: AZT, of course, has been approved for general use in the United States of America but it is currently available in Australia on a limited trial basis only. The Minister said in his answer that the Commonwealth would not contribute beyond the scope of this arrangement, and that any supplementary funding `was a matter for the State and Territory administrations'. He also informed the Senate that the renegotiation of a revised Medicare agreement between the Federal and State governments to incorporate AIDS treatment and the provision of AZT would be considered in May at a meeting of the health Ministers.

The effect of the Government's policy is that there now is a growing number of people suffering from AIDS who fulfil the clinical requirements to be part of the Government trial but who are being denied access to AZT. Indeed, in New South Wales, where about 70 per cent of Australia's AIDS patients are, on average six people join the waiting list for the drug treatment every week. Because of the lack of government funding, these people are being denied treatment by a drug that has been proven in clinical trials to be effective.

The problem, then, is twofold. Until the clinical trials in Australia are completed and evaluated, the drug will not be publicly available. The appropriate United States agency has approved AZT for general use and, of course, it is hoped that the Australian authorities will complete their program speedily and efficiently. However, because of the limited funding for these trials, we are now in a catch-22 situation. This is probably best illustrated by the Commonwealth's seeming lack of concern for the sick and many of the disadvantaged in our society.

The discussion has been couched very much in terms of dollars. I would be quite happy to engage in that discussion if, in fact, it were legitimately based. However, I do not think it is legitimately based. When we see, as we heard in a debate yesterday, many of our large corporations still being able to pay tax of 10c in the dollar, one wonders why we need to discuss the costs of health care to so many people in our community.

Commonwealth and State governments have pointed to the cost of treatment by using AZT which, on average, is about $10,000 per patient per year-a very large cost indeed. But, when we compare this to the cost of similar treatments of life-threatening illnesses, it would not seem to be an excessive amount. I want to mention some of the treatments which are covered under the Medicare arrangements because I think this is the way we really have to go. We have a situation basically, then, where clinically ill people are being deprived of a drug because of funding restrictions. As the AIDS Council of New South Wales has made clear, this would seem to be one of the only situations where a scientifically proven drug is being denied patients on the basis of economic considerations only.

The drug in question has been around for quite some time. It was originally marketed about 20 years ago by researchers who were looking for some cure for cancer. It ended up being relatively useless in that area and, indeed, quite toxic, and was put aside. It was found to be very effective during routine tests on the AIDS virus. It has since gone on to be the major operative drug in the area today. There is a difficulty, however, in its manufacture and this has led to some of the extraordinary costs that are associated with the drug itself. There is still a fair amount of dispute between the originally public funded research which provided the drug and Burroughs-Wellcome, the drug company that currently has control over the drug for another seven years.

There is also some discussion about how the drug actually works. But, I think, these points can be put aside in this debate. What we are looking at is the humanitarian situation, particularly in respect of those people who may be diagnosed very early in the piece as suffering from AIDS and who, in fact, may see that a treatment with this drug would be much more beneficial at that stage than at a later stage. It would seem that one of the ways that Australia could go might be to release funds for research with regard to this area of drugs itself and proceed to the development of a similar drug which operates in a similar way. At the moment the situation is that AZT is available only to people who meet the strict criteria laid down for the trials. So we have a highly emotional-and quite rightly emotional-debate building up in the community.

If one looks at this matter in purely commercial terms, $10,000 may seem expensive but so too, for example, is $35,000 a year for someone who is on dialysis for kidney failure. An average cost of a chemotherapy patient is $11,000 a year and the cost of a drunk driver who spends a month in intensive care is somewhere between $50,000 and $100,000. In other words, it is important to see that there are very large costs in many areas of health care. They are costs which the community has made it clear it is willing to carry. According to information provided by the National Health and Medical Research Council, the cost of treating an AIDS patient in hospital is about $40,000. It would seem, then, that any treatment which is able to be effective and prevent hospitalisation should be looked at as a cost-saving measure. So I think costs in this area are being looked at differently from the costs of ill patients in other areas of health care.

The current funding situation, of course, is that the State health Ministers want the Commonwealth to pay, although the Commonwealth does not pay for drugs given out through the State-run public hospitals. It would seem that what the Commonwealth Government is attempting to do is to make, in terms of a longer term plan, a gradual withdrawal from the provinces of providing medical services.

The New South Wales Minister approached the drug company in an attempt to reduce the costs. But he had no success. He then asked the Commonwealth Government to assist his Government by helping it to shoulder the burden in New South Wales. The Commonwealth Government has refused. The Victorian Government has asked the Federal Government to provide increased funding. The Victorian Government also believes that the method I have outlined is the most cost efficient method available with regard to keeping the number of in-patients down to a minimum. But, of course, it also wants the Commonwealth to come in on the funding exercise.

The Commonwealth Government in turn has argued that it does not allocate money for specific drugs. Rather, it gives the States a block grant and it is up to the States to distribute funds. I think what we have here is an impasse which, unfortunately, is affecting an increasing number of people. It is a impasse which I believe ought to be broken, and broken very rapidly.

The AIDS epidemic has been with us for quite a long time. The country itself has come to grips with the problem. Yet we still have this continuing wrangle between the State and Commonwealth governments about what we are to do about the situation. As of 15 March 1988, there have been almost 800 people with AIDS in Australia, of whom 418 have died. Critics of the existing policy say that if AIDS is not considered a special case, but a complex, potentially devastating disease which will incur considerable expense, all people who need the treatment will have to be treated. While AIDS continues to be seen as something extraordinary and outside the area, governments are going to face charges of withholding medical care on the basis of discrimination against certain groups within our community.

Nobody is arguing that Australia's health budget is unlimited. There is an appreciation that the provision of health care needs careful consideration. Certainly, the current problems of limited availability as a result of government funding indicate the need for this. However, the head of the AIDS task force has made it very clear that he sees that there is now no dilemma, that AZT should be given to people on the basis of medical need without any other further consideration. That, after all, is the way in which we have dealt with all other diseases. Surely in the late twentieth century we have advanced to a stage where we can make available in Australia a clinically proven treatment for a life-threatening disease. I would hope that governments in Australia would not use the federal system as a means of shirking their responsibility collectively to the community. I think that is what is occurring at the moment. It is not good enough for a government simply to say, `This is somebody else's problem' and try to shuffle it off.

I do not believe that we should have to wait to see what happens in May when the health Ministers meet. I think the Commonwealth Government has a primary responsibility in this area. Hopefully, after the May meeting there will be agreement that this matter will come under the normal Medicare arrangements. Additional funding probably needs to be provided in the short term. I think that is necessary and could be provided for in terms of the Government's current health budget.

I have very little time left in which to deal with the last concern that I wish to raise. I refer to the other drugs that are able to be used but which, seemingly, are not being tested extensively. I would hope that these drugs also might become part of the trials that are being conducted and might be able to be funded and used, particularly as some of them have the potential for being as good, if not better, at a significantly lower cost.
