DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY AND SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988[COGNATE BILLS:EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1988EXPORT INSPECTION (SERVICE CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1988EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGES COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 April, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY AND SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I suggest that we have a cognate debate on the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1988, the Export Inspection (Services Charge) Amendment Bill 1988 and the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1988. Also, I table an explanatory memorandum relating to the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill.
—Is that the wish of the Senate? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —As has just been indicated by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), the Senate is debating cognately four Bills-the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1988, the Export Inspection (Services Charge) Amendment Bill 1988 and the complementary Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1988. The Senate is doing this in order to accommodate the Government, which has a backlog of Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall not be speaking at length to these Bills, which are not opposed. However, I point out that, once again, these Bills reveal the shortcomings and bureaucratic ineptitude of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am supported by my colleague Senator Brownhill. In particular, I will point out the major difficulties created by this Government. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is full of rhetoric about what this Government is doing for industry, but, as I point out once again, the Government is either taking the soft option of lowering tariffs-that is the easy thing to do-or, in fact, taking away bounties, as it is doing in this case. The difficult option is to look at the other measures which need to be taken to assist industry by relieving it of some of the burdens so that it can get on with its job.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the Minister's attention in particular to the concerns of two companies-Waltanna Tractors of Hamilton in western Victoria and E.M. Baldwin and Sons Pty Ltd of Mount Druitt in New South Wales. The Government is taking away the bounty on tractors. The Opposition is not opposing this measure because it was brought down as part of the Budget. But both of these companies are in a position where they have to face competition from imported tractors which do not attract duty. At the same time, they have to pay duty on many of their components which are imported or they have to pay a higher price for Australian components, and this significantly adds to their costs.

Both companies have been leaders in design in their particular fields and both have been active in research and development. Waltanna has been actively pursuing export markets and has developed a unique timber and forestry machine which is called a timber forwarder. I gather that this machine is a tractor which incorporates a piece of equipment to enable the operator to pick up timber and move it forward. Part of the machine, as finally manufactured and delivered, is a crane and the manufacture of cranes in Australia is protected by a 35 per cent tariff. So Waltanna either has to pay a 35 per cent duty on a crane which it imports for incorporation in its machine, or has to buy a crane from an Australian manufacturer which is protected by the 35 per cent tariff. Accordingly, the price that Waltanna pays is that much higher. The cost of Waltanna's timber forwarder has increased by approximately $12,000 because of the crane component. Waltanna is competing with fully imported machines which attract no import duty at all.

The Government is in a bind in that the manufacturer of the machines which are being built in Australia finds that he is ultimately responsible for a $12,000 duty imposed on a major component, but his competitors are able to bring in their machines manufactured outside Australia free of duty. Waltanna tells me that a duty is also imposed on other components, one of which I think is an axle. Waltanna either has to pay the duty on the imported goods or the duty, in effect, is encompassed in an Australian product.

The total value of all the duties that Waltanna pays on its timber forwarder is $26,000. So this company is put at a disadvantage of some $26,000 in competing with imported products because the Government simply has taken away the bounty which it was giving to companies to compensate for this problem. The Government has taken the simple option. It has taken away the bounty and not rectified the situation for the company. As a result, its product costs $26,000 more than it should.

I am not suggesting that the bounty should be reimposed; quite the contrary. What I am saying is that a customs tariff concession order should be made available to the company. But when the company tried to apply for some concession to enable it to import these components free of duty, it discovered that it was required to write to every manufacturer in every part of Australia and ask, `Can you produce the particular product that is needed?'. Of course, in any event, the Australian manufacturers themselves may be utilising parts which, down the line, are protected in some way or other. So the company is still faced with this burden. This is the sort of problem which is created for companies in Australia by the Government simply taking away a bounty as a Budget measure and not following through and realising the problems which may arise.

This sorry story reveals inflexibility, lack of understanding of commercial realities, the problems of hasty introduction of harmonised tariffs and, quite frankly, the hasty removal of the bounty in the last Budget. I point out that the Liberal and National parties have constantly criticised the Government for the anomalies created by the harmonised tariff legislation. We understand that there would, of course, be anomalies in such a massive piece of legislation. But the Government is not addressing those problems and anomalies quickly enough and bringing about some redress of the grievances which Australian manufacturers are suffering.

Both Waltanna and E. M. Baldwin and Sons Pty Ltd have the potential to develop export markets but if they cannot compete fairly on the local market and develop sufficient cash flow to carry out this work it is unlikely that they will go ahead with exports. As a matter of fact, it has even been suggested to me by one of them that it might have to cease manufacture because of the burden that is imposed on it. In other words, such an outcome would be solely due to the Government's actions. Of course, they would not be on their own if they ceased manufacture. After all, these are the only companies left in Australia that are manufacturing tractors. All of the other Australian manufacturers of tractors have gone to the wall or had to get out of the business.

I urge the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and his Department to undertake a speedy review of this problem and remove the disincentives to these companies that have been created by the removal of the bounty. The Government has failed to address the problems which they now face as a result of the tariffs on the components that they have to use in their product.

The amendments to the Bounty Books Act 1985 are not opposed. The amendments change bounty assistance to the book producing industry which has been extended to 31 December 1993 and phase down the bounty in five steps. The coalition parties are, of course, in support of that proposal.

The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1988 amends the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to incorporate into the Act various excise tariff proposals tabled in this Parliament during the last sittings and early in this sitting. They are routine six-monthly adjustments based on consumer price index (CPI) and import parity adjustments. The import parity price adjustments probably will be the final adjustments of this kind as legislation has been passed deregulating crude oil marketing from 1 January 1988. The adjustments concern the excise duty on liquefied petroleum gas, refined petroleum products and avgas. There is an adjustment to restrict the total excise duty increases as a result of CPI indexations for the 1987-88 financial year to 6 per cent to honour an undertaking given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during his election campaign. The Prime Minister casually mentioned that he would not allow these things to increase beyond 6 per cent and he now has to keep amending the legislation all the time to make sure that they do not. These measures are not opposed by the Opposition.

The Export Inspection (Service Charge) Amendment Bill 1988 will allow effective recovery of the costs of inspection services at establishments not registered for the preparation of food and primary products for export. The principal purpose of the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1988 is to enable charges to be imposed in relation to export inspection of fruit, vegetables, live animals and animal reproductive material. However, the amendments primarily affect horticultural exports. The Government introduced new inspection charges by export control orders on the horticultural industry as from 1 January 1988. These charges are structured in a way which adds significantly to the costs of these exports, particularly of small consignments of certain types of horticultural products such as cut flowers, nursery items, new variety and high quality items.

These high costs have been fully canvassed in the other place and the Government must be aware that these additional charges may affect the competitiveness of these exports. Sufficient to say that horticulture offers one of our brightest export prospects and I agree with the industry viewpoint that the charges are unfair, cumbersome and counterproductive. While the Government continues to give lip service to increased exports, it seems determined to increase the burdens it imposes on exporters in the private sector. These cognate Bills highlight the bureaucratic ineptitude of this Government and its clear lack of understanding of commercial reality, notwithstanding the rhetoric of the Minister. Surely the Minister has the wit to devise systems that accommodate the needs of the private sector as well as the Government and are neither inefficient nor cumbersome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the comments that were made by Senator Lewis, who is leading for the Opposition in this debate. I would like to direct my attention to the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Amendment Bill 1988 and the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1988. I am somewhat surprised that the Government has decided to press on with this legislation, given the criticism of the legislation within some of the industries affected by it and given the announcement in March by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) of a review of the charges.

SPEECH.PARA: For those not familiar with this legislation, I should explain some of the relevant facts. The purpose of the legislation relates to the ability to make export inspection charges. The first Bill-the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Amendment Bill-will allow effective recovery of the costs of inspection services at establishments not registered for the preparation of food and primary products for export. The other Bill-the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill-provides for charges to be levied for the inspection of fruit, vegetables, live animals and animal reproduction material and some grains.

As Senator Lewis has already mentioned, the most effective industries are the horticultural and grain industries. The Government is aware, and has been for some time, that the horticultural industry and some sections of the grain industry are opposed to the export charges, and so they should be. The legislation will impose dramatically increased costs on these exports at a time when we are supposed to be needing every export dollar we can get. So while the Government talks big on wanting to increase rural exports, it does everything it can to provide disincentives.

I am advised by Mr Lloyd, my colleague in the other House, that the full cost of these additional charges will be of the order of some $8m, of which, on a 50 per cent cost recovery basis imposed by the Government, almost $4m will be recovered from the industry. Of that $4m, almost two-thirds will come from grain exports, particularly from the new types of grain which we need in our export program, and the remainder will come from horticultural exports.

The Government is aware that there is enormous opposition to this legislation but, in its usual style, it has decided to push ahead anyway. Finally, on 15 March, Mr Kerin announced a review of fees for inspection of horticultural produce and non-prescribed grains. The following comment was made in a paper that came from the Minister's office:
The aim of the review is to
1. Examine the effects of the new fees on industry,
2. Examine the cost recovery level that the fees will achieve; and

3. Establish ways in which the Government's policies of 50 per cent inspection cost contribution by industry can be met, while ensuring that no sector of industry suffers a disproportionate financial burden in the course of applying the policy. As such, it is intended to address criticisms of the new fees by industry, and to redress any anomalies or inequities identified.
Under the heading `Terms of Reference', the paper states:
The terms of reference of the review are:
1. Examine the effects of the new fees on industry.
2. Examine the cost recovery level which the fees will achieve.
3. Identify any anomalies arising from the new fees.

4. Devise a range of alternative options for redressing any financial imbalances caused by the fees, while still adhering to the Government's policy that industry contribute 50 per cent of the cost of providing the export inspection service.

5. Decide on a charging formula which equitably and efficiently meets the Government's cost recovery objectives, and provides the maximum incentive for efficient operation of the industry and the inspection service.

The timetable for the review, by anyone's judgment, is somewhat hasty. The Government announced the review on 15 March; it circulated a discussion paper on 29 March; and it demanded that industry responses be in by 15 April, which gave the industry only two weeks to prepare a submission. The working party, made up of representatives of various affected industries and groups, is to meet and report to the Minister. Their report is to be with the Minister by the end of April-that is, by this Saturday. So, presumably, in effect that means tomorrow. I cannot work out why we should be debating the legislation in the Senate today when a report on the review has to be concluded tomorrow.

Why cannot this Government just admit that its legislation was, once again, drawn up by bureaucrats who forgot to consult with the real world and find out what was going on? The legislation is most probably shonky. Why cannot the Government just throw it out? The Government should wait. It should find out what the industry can afford and is prepared to accept, and draw up legislation accordingly. In my opinion, the Government is hardly being fair and, in fact, it is being absolutely scornful of the working party which it established. Does it mean that the Government has no intention of listening to the working party and that, whatever it says, the legislation will proceed? Presumably, and hopefully, if the report of the working paper is accepted by government there will need to be amendments to the legislation.

Earlier today, Senator Wood talked about democracy. I think this is yet another example of an absence of it. Certainly there is an absence of democracy in respect of the horticultural industry. We talk long and hard in this place about the vital and desperate need to reduce our overseas debt and increase our rural exports. This year, not because of any marvellous Government initiative, rural exports are expected to increase by 21 per cent to a total of some $19.3 billion. This is even bigger than the value of mineral exports, which this year will bring in, supposedly, $16.3 billion.

Just to hold our debt at present levels, our trade balance needs to improve by some $10 billion. That is the enormity of the task that this country faces. It is not going to be easy and it will require more than just extra effort from export industries such as horticulture, which have been hit by extra Government charges. It seems as if they have to fight with their own government before they can get their product out of the country.

The number of initiatives that have been made in recent years by people involved in horticulture is quite staggering. As Senator Lewis has already mentioned, they have found markets at premium prices for cut flowers, indoor plants and fresh fruit and vegetables. Horticulture today is more than just apples and pears to the European Economic Community. The Federal Government seems reluctant to recognise this industry and its increasing importance to exports. The Government's actions in bringing forward this legislation when a working party review on it is pending is nothing short of an insult to those affected and the Government deserves all the scorn it will get.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some comments on the export inspection Bills that are before us. The Export Inspection (Service Charge) Amendment Bill 1988 seeks to amend the Export Inspection Service Charge Act 1985 to remove limitations on the imposition of charges for export inspection services performed outside export registered establishments. The Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1988 seeks primarily to enable charges to be imposed for the export inspection of fruit, vegetables, live animals and animal reproductive material.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to delay the Senate for two long but I would like to make a few comments. I have received correspondence from some industry bodies affected by this legislation, including the Australian Nurserymen's Association, some individual orchid growers, and others, who expressed concern at the charges. However, after speaking with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and an industry representative, I understand that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has taken heed of industry concerns. He has set up a working party, which was referred to by Senator Brownhill, with formal terms of reference to look at the industry's concerns.

As a result of debate in the House of Representatives, Mr Kerin said that he was about to start a review anyway but that emphasis would be added by setting up a formal working party within industry, with informal terms of reference. One week later, Senator Cook approved the terms of reference. The industry said that it supported that arrangement. The working party consisted of two members from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, representatives from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, the National Farmers Federation, the Grains Council of Australia, the Australian Nurserymen's Association, seeds people, horticultural exporters, the Association of Horticultural Growers and one State representative from Victoria.

A discussion paper prepared by the Department setting out 10 options has been circulated to 65 individuals and organisations over the last few weeks. About 36 responses came back to the Department. The industry working party met on Tuesday of this week and agreed to one of those options known as option C. In the discussion it was found that the phytosanitary fee was the biggest problem. The problem was not the fee per se but rather that it would hurt some people more than others. The issue for some, especially small exporters, was the ability to pay. Under the legislation before us, the fees are $20 phyosanitary charges, $28 for the first half hour, $11 for each subsequent half hour and $14 for each half hour services at an inspector's office. At Tuesday's meeting the working party opted for option C which is no phytosanitary fee, $38 for the first half hour, $12 for each subsequent half hour and $16 per half hour for services provided at an inspector's office. This is a compromise on everybody's behalf.

There are still some issues to be followed through with the industry working group such as the national residue survey and quality assurances. The Department is in the process of sending to industry members of the joint working party a draft based on the meeting. The Minister has said that it will be looked at urgently next week. An industry representative who was on the working group has informed me that the adoption of option C will assist smaller exporters and clear up the inequities. That issue was of concern to the Australian Democrats when this legislation was first introduced in the other place and when we had contacts from the industry.

I would like to endorse the comments about the strides that have been made by the horticultural industry as a whole as an exporter from this country. That achievement has, I think, been recognised by all of us. This is a sector of primary industry which has great potential and the Australian Democrats are keen to support it in their possible way. I would simply make the point that one of the market niches in horticulture that has opened up and has been recognised as such by New Zealand and other countries is, of course, the area of chemical-free food. This is an area which I have urged this Government and the industry to look at closely, and I make that brief comment at this point. I conclude by saying that while an industry representative commented to me, perhaps along the lines put forward by Senator Brownhill, that the process could have been carried out more easily if the Department had sat down with the industry earlier and discussed its problems more thoroughly, it is my understanding that industry representatives on the working party are now quite happy. Therefore, the Democrats will be supporting this legislation.

DEBATE.TITLE: HONEY MARKETING BILL 1988HONEY LEVY (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1988HONEY LEVY (No. 2) AMENDMENT BILL 1988HONEY EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 April, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Honey Marketing Bill 1988, the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1988, the Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill 1988 and the Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill 1988. The purpose of this legislation is to produce a new honey board with revised powers and duties. It changes the membership structure of the board and it produces a better accountability to the industry. It brings the operation up to date and it is in line with the Government's policies as far as the primary industry boards are concerned. It is in line with discussions held with the industries involved. One of the things that I like about the legislation is that restraints are placed on the raising of the levies. In her second reading speech on the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill, the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) said:

SPEECH.PARA: While the increased levy maximum will create scope for increasing the rate of the Honey Board component of the levy beyond its present level, no increase will take place until such time as the honey industry and the Board recommend a higher rate be prescribed and the recommendation is implemented.
I think it is just as well that the industry should have this much say in the payments that it makes.

I am going to take the opportunity to speak a little about the honey industry because, as a small but important industry, it very seldom gets much of a run in the public arena. The industry represents a group of between 12,000 to 15,000 beekeepers Australia-wide, about 2,250 of whom are currently registered as having 40 hives or more. The vast majority of people in the industry have from one to 20 hives. All of them are very concerned about our health and the health of the nation and they provide us with honey products to keep us healthy.

This industry, which is small by any terms, produces about a quarter of one per cent of the total agricultural production of the country. The health and success of the industry is absolutely vital to a range of other industries, such as those that produce fruit, seeds, vegetables and flowers. It is also of vital importance to the pasture industries. All these industries depend on beekeepers operating profitably and effectively and supplying services to them. To those industries, honey is the by-product. They require pollination and this service is estimated to be worth between $100m and $400m a year. As such, the industry is very important.

The industry has come a long way in recent times. The standards of professionalism are now pretty high and the industry rates well with other industries of this nature throughout the world. In recent times the producers have become more mechanised. They use the latest of equipment and technology and their better breeding program has produced good bees in Australia which are largely free of most of the world's worst complaints. However, there is, of course, substantial international competition. Although Australia is not a major producer, it is in the top 10 countries. The largest is the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the next largest is China. Those two countries between them produce about one-third of the world's honey.

There is still a need for research. The Minister's second reading speech defines two objectives-to maximise returns to the honey industry from exports and to generate a greater demand for Australian honey, both in Australia and overseas. Those are two very good aims and I totally support them, as does the industry. The industry has done a good job with research in the production area but now it wants to concentrate on the market end.

The Rottnest Island breeding station in Western Australia has done a lot to help the industry. It is clean and clear of insects and has produced a considerable amount of very good queen bees. The strain from this source is very good. The industry certainly wants to see this activity continue and progress. The industry still, of course, wants very tight quarantine. Disease is widely spread in the honey industry throughout the world and we want to keep Australia as clean as we possibly can. Australian beekeepers have always been very nervous about chalk brood, which exists in New Zealand, and we do not want it to be any closer than that. The varroa mite is found almost everywhere in the world, and causes considerable trouble in the hives. We still do not have that problem in Australia. North America is now being infested with the Africanised bee. This is another problem which we certainly do not want to be associated with. We are still importing queen bees from the United States of America in reasonable quantities, and many of the beekeepers are very nervous about the possibility of their bees getting mixed up with this strain of Africanised bee. These are all issues that the industry has before it at present.

Production of honey in Australia has been relatively stable for many years at something in the order of 20,000 to 22,000 tonnes. The year ending 30 June 1986-the last year for which records are currently available-was a good year with production reaching 26,871 tonnes from registered producers. About half of the honey produced is exported and about two-thirds of what is exported goes to either the United Kingdom or Germany. The honey produced by small producers and hobbyists is not included in those figures.

Many people find beekeeping a very good hobby and they get a lot of enjoyment from it. There is a large trade in honey. All the major producers have surpluses and there is considerable dumping on world markets from time to time. In fact, it has been recently alleged that 300 tonnes of New Zealand honey was dumped in Australia and this has caused considerable concern.

In my own State of Tasmania, the industry is again small, but vital. It is in every corner of the State and it includes a great number of small producers. When one talks about honey in Tasmania, everybody immediately thinks of our famous leatherwood honey, which is unique by any standards-a prized delicacy for all those who enjoy something nice. I am pleased to be able to keep in close touch with the beekeepers there and I hope to be able to keep it that way.

The industry still faces problems which are mainly ones of cost. I have been recently advised that to ship a container from Tasmania to Europe now costs about $2,300, which is almost double what it was last year. The industry has problems with price fluctuation. Last year it received a good price of $1,750 or thereabouts. This year the price is about $1,500 and falling. At times, difficulties are created by entry requirements to some countries. Currently, the requirements of the Germans are a bit difficult, although the producers believe that they can be met. I support the industry. I encourage members of the Senate and members of the Press Gallery to consider giving the beekeepers a good run. It is an important industry and, on behalf of the Opposition, I support the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Honey Marketing Bill 1988, the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1988, the Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill 1988 and the Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill 1988 do a range of things. The Honey Marketing Bill seeks to reconstitute the Australian Honey Board by revising its functions and powers and changing its membership structure. The levy Bills apply to honey sold in Australia and to honey used in the production of other goods. The amendments will require the Honey Board to consult with the Federal organisations of honey producers and honey packers before recommending to the Minister any change in the rate of levy imposed to provide funds for the Board, and to increase the maximum levy that can be imposed under the levy Acts for Board funding from 2.20c to 5c per kilogram of honey. The remaining Bill relates to export charges.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to take the opportunity to comment on a couple of things. The objectives of the Honey Board are to maximise returns to the Australian honey industry from the export of honey and to generate a greater demand for Australian honey both here and overseas. According to figures released by the Board in its latest annual report, it is meeting its export objectives with considerable success. The Chairman of the Board has stated:

Australia has been able to maintain export prices at at least US$100 per tonne above other world exporters and has been a steadying influence on a world trade during a period when export demand has been extremely quiet.

I think that is worth mentioning in this brief debate. I also want to make a brief comment on the 1986-87 annual report of the Honey Research Council. I note, amongst other things, that a project is involved in the evaluation of the toxicity and residuality of microencapsulated, or slow release capsule, pesticides to honey bees. Also, a project at the Queensland Agricultural College is looking at the long term effects of systemic pesticides on honey bees. Obviously, the honey industry is aware of the potential of problems in the area of pesticide use. Those projects are welcome in that they are looking at that issue. These Bills are non-controversial and they have Australian Democrat support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment, requests or debate.
Sitting suspended from 1.55 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance whether he is aware of the article in today's Sydney Morning Herald headed:

QUESTION.PARA: Banks agree on information boost to ease debt crisis.

Does the Minister agree that the traditional banks may have been more prudent than finance companies in lending? Furthermore, what obligation is there on banks or finance companies to disclose the full cost of borrowing in various forms, including hire purchase agreements and where roll-over facilities are offered?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is no, I did not see the article in the Sydney Morning Herald, so for that reason I am at a bit of a disadvantage. I was also asked whether the article had said, or whether I believed, that banks were more prudent than finance companies. I cannot state that definitively, but I would expect banks to be more prudent than finance companies in their lending policies. As to the last part of the question about the disclosure requirements for banks and financial institutions generally, I do not know; I shall seek an answer to that from the Treasurer.

—Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of recent concern in Tasmania over the possibility of Telecom transferring its Tasmanian engineering function to Victoria? Is there any basis for this concern and is Telecom definitely planning such a transfer? Would not such a transfer have an unacceptable negative effect on engineering job opportunities in Tasmania as well as on the skills level of the Tasmanian work force? In view of this, will the Minister ask Telecom to desist from any further consideration of such a transfer?

—Yes, I am aware of recent concern over the proposal to which Senator Coates refers. Telecom has informed me that as part of its changed management process it is considering the reorganisation of its network engineering activities. There is no basis, however, for the particular concerns that have been expressed. The matters under consideration include changes to reporting lines, but this would not involve a transfer of network engineering activities from Tasmania to Melbourne. There definitely would be no loss of engineering expertise; no change would occur in the ability to deal with major breakdowns in Tasmania. That is the situation in a nutshell. I do not intend to intervene in the matter. Telecom's proposals are the subject of discussions and no final decisions have yet been taken. There are specific discussions to be held in Tasmania today with engineering management and key staff, some of whom are local staff association representatives. I have no doubt that as a result of those discussions any remaining difficulties or concerns that are being experienced on this issue will be able to be amicably and satisfactorily resolved.

—Does the Minister for Justice recall answering a question on whether Royal Australian Air Force crews who bombed Germany would be liable for prosecution under the War Crimes Amendment Bill, if that Bill is passed by this Parliament? Does the Minister remember saying that Australians who took part in allied bombing raids on Germany would not be endangered by the Bill because of article 6 (b) of the Nuremberg Charter? Has the Minister actually looked at article 6 (b)? If so, does he agree that it reads that war crimes, inter alia, are `wanton destruction of cities, towns or villages, or devastation not justified by military necessity'? Can the Minister explain what military necessity justified the destruction of Dresden in February 1945, an operation in which many Australian air crews took part under orders? If he cannot, will he admit that he has misled the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall the question being asked about the liability of Australian and Allied ex-servicemen being dealt with under the War Crimes Bill, if it were to be enacted. As I recall my response to Senator Chaney, it was to the effect that the Bill had been drafted in a way which dealt with the crimes alleged rather than with any particular category of persons who may have committed those crimes and, therefore, there would be no attempt to quarantine any particular alleged offenders in regard to those very serious matters which would be covered by the war crimes legislation, if enacted.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also important to emphasise that Australian and Allied ex-servicemen are already subject to prosecution, if it were ever justified in relation to war crimes, and have been since 1945. This has been operating for 43 years. The War Crimes Act 1945 applies to all persons in Allied or Axis forces and covers the types of conduct proposed to be proscribed in the War Crimes Amendment Bill. The sorts of matters addressed in the War Crimes Bill have been proscribed by customary international law since 1907. The fact is that Allied ex-servicemen have been liable, if indeed they committed an horrendous war crime of the sort we are looking at in relation to the War Crimes Bill, for many decades, and indeed, as is already well known in the Parliament, no allegation has ever been made against Australian ex-servicemen or Australian forces relating to war crimes of that kind. So far as I know, the Special Investigations Unit is not investigating the conduct of any member of the Australian forces in relation to a war crime.

In regard to the example I gave, I was advised that the Nuremberg Charter indicated in its terms, particularly in article 6 (b), that there were situations where the defence could be made out that a particular operation was not undertaken wantonly and was justified by military necessity. I have not got the exact words in front of me, but I have read the Nuremberg Charter and article 6 (b). I was advised that the Charter, in particular 6 (b), was understood to cover the situation of the bombings that occurred in the European theatre of war. As to the particular instance of which Senator Hamer speaks, I do not have a full brief on the application of that principle to any particular bombing raid, but I have been advised that that defence is available in relation to the bombings which occurred in the Second World War.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister under the impression that the War Crimes Act 1945 applied to Allied servicemen? It appeared from his answer that he was under that impression. It does not. I wonder why the Minister is not aware of that fact. With regard to the second part of his answer, where he said that he had been `advised' of certain matters, what I was asking for was the Minister's opinion. He has told the Parliament that servicemen, bomber crews, were not liable under the Act. I think a reading of the Nuremberg Charter indicates quite clearly that they were. Is the Minister prepared to withdraw his previous statement?
—I am advised that the War Crimes Act does apply to Australian forces and that they have been subject to it since 1945. That is the basis on which I have been giving my answers.

—Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism, and Territories aware of recent Press reports that the Queensland Government is considering a proposal to pay $25,000 to a Cairns sawmiller to mill timber allegedly taken illegally from a national park in north Queensland? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the details of this proposal and whether the national park in question is part of the area nominated by Australia for inscription on the World Heritage List?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the Press report in the Courier-Mail, which I find astounding, to say the least. Apparently the Queensland Government is considering paying $25,000 to a Cairns sawmiller, Mr Doug Simms, to mill rainforest trees grown in the Cape Tribulation National Park and worth about $100,000. This is the same Mr Simms who, along with a Mr Quaid, is to appear in the Cairns Magistrates Court in June, I think, to answer some charges in respect of this.

ANSWER.PARA: Cape Tribulation National Park is not one of the areas in dispute in the World Heritage listing. The Queensland Government has long pushed the idea that some areas should be preserved from logging and Cape Tribulation, north of Daintree, is considered to be one of those very special core areas that not even Queensland will touch. And when it gets to the stage that even Queensland will not lay its hands on it, it must be pretty good! Yet not only do sections of the local timber industry choose to ignore that and break the law by going in and logging those trees but also, as a result, the Queensland Government is prepared to offer those same people a profit for doing so. Even in terms of Queensland Government ethics it is, to say the least, over the top for that Government to consider rewarding criminal activity with large sums of money. It is staggering. The fact that it is even being considered is absolutely amazing.

If the industry had gone into this area only once I suppose we could consider allowing an excuse, but it has to be remembered that there were, not one, but two incursions into the national parks where loggers took it upon themselves to ignore national park boundaries, get their bulldozers and chainsaws and go for it. Whatever the standards of forestry management in Queensland-Senator Puplick has been on record as saying that they are very good-I must say that allowing logging in a national park, and then paying the people who did it to mill the logs, is beyond the pale, a disgrace and unworthy of any government worth its salt. I hope that the substantial commercial benefit that may be reaped from this--

TALK.START.PARA: —Humbug!

—Yes, it is humbug; that is exactly what the Queensland Government is engaging in. The fact that the Government is trying to reward those people with a substantial commercial benefit is extraordinary. I might say that in Queensland if one removes trees from a national park the maximum penalty is a wonderful $1,000. So to charge these people $1,000 at the end of the day and then give them back $25,000 and say, `Thank you very much' is not good enough. It really represents Queensland's concern for the environment and Queensland forestry management.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware that in New South Wales over the Easter period and Anzac weekend, petrol prices varied from 42.6c per litre to 59.9c per litre, with the lower prices being in the metropolitan areas and the higher prices being in rural and semi-rural areas? Is the Minister also aware that petrol companies are currently deciding on lease renewal formulae for retail petrol outlets, that lease renewal fees are expected to be between $30,000 and $60,000, and that this amount will be impossible for most small, independent petrol retailers to pay considering the uncertainty of their cash flow due to petrol price wars? Is the Government still determined to do absolutely nothing to help small, independent petrol retailers maintain a livelihood or to ease this manipulation of the petrol industry by multinational petrol companies which produces totally artificially induced petrol price differentials between city and country areas, putting the country areas at a gross disadvantage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no direct knowledge of what happened in New South Wales over the Easter period. But I am aware, of course, that price discounting has been happening in Sydney for a long time. I am also aware that city and rural price discrepancies are generally accounted for by a relative lack of competition in the country and because a ready market for product surpluses exists in proximity to the refineries. Having said that, I must point out that retail pricing is essentially a State government matter. The Trade Practices Commission has announced an inquiry into petrol pricing for completion by the middle of this year and the Government awaits the results of that inquiry with interest.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, with the expiry of the first franchise agreement signed under the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act, oil companies are looking at this so-called `window of opportunity' to review networks and their relationships with dealers. In this context, they have signalled substantial upgrading programs in both outlet appearance and marketing systems. The question of the franchisees' ability to pay premiums currently being charged in the light of prevalent discounting is ultimately a matter for negotiation between an oil company and its individual franchisees. Lack of profitability is clearly a bargaining point in such negotiations.

In answer to perhaps the most important part of the question, the Government has demonstrated its continuing concern for the small operator in the petrol retailing industry by its maintenance and strengthening of the petroleum retail marketing legislation. No further changes to that legislation are contemplated at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that there have been calls from certain sections of the Australian business community for the introduction of a consumption tax or a value added type of tax in Australia? Is the Minister aware that one of the arguments used by proponents of value added tax (VAT) is that it is supposed to be much harder to avoid or evade than the taxes it could be used to replace? Is the Government persuaded by the argument that a VAT should be introduced to replace the existing sales tax and fund company tax cuts, in order to clamp down on tax avoidance and evasion in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that from time to time various people call for the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax. In recent times, the most prominent of those people has, of course, been Mr Elliott. But apparently he-like Senator Stone-has had a dishcloth rammed down his neck and it may take a couple of weeks to cough it up before he starts wiping his boots all over the Leader of the Opposition again. There are problems-I will give one specific example later-with the argument that a value added type of tax cannot be evaded. The normal type of VAT system imposes a disproportionately heavy administrative burden on small business. That is the first point. It also imposes an expensive administration on both the Australian Taxation Office and the private sector, which must comply. In the normal type of VAT system each business enterprise is required to forward to the tax authorities a sum of money equal to the VAT rate multiplied by that business's sales but minus the VAT that has already been paid on the purchases during the relevant period. In other words, the enterprise-at whatever point in the production chain-gets a credit for each dollar of VAT it pays on its purchases. The credit then reduces the VAT amount that must be paid. Let me give a concrete example of how it is possible for VAT to be evaded. The Sydney Morning Herald of 14 May last year reported that Elders IXL Ltd, Mr Elliott's company, had bought a 64-foot world cruising yacht. The yacht was said to be:

ANSWER.PARA: moored on the picturesque Pittwater playground of rich yuppies and the not so young.

Since that yacht was bought with company money, it was presumably claimed to be used in the business activities of the company and claimed as a deduction under, I would expect, section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know?

—It was bought with company money, Senator. By the way, when I have had time to put it all together, I will be giving the honourable senator a proper answer and a proper serve to the silly question he asked yesterday. Ultimately, this promoted a response from Mr Elliott--

—I raise a point of order. Clearly, there are secrecy provisions in the tax Act. Yet the Minister consistently makes statements which relate to the taxation affairs of individual corporations and individuals. Since it is quite clear that the Minister is acting either illegally or in ignorance, the answer he is giving ought not to be in order, if it is in order. Mr President, I draw your attention to that fact and to the present drift of the Minister's reply and ask for a ruling on the matter.

—There is no way I can make a ruling on a matter of law. Therefore, I would have to rule any point of order out of order. I ask the Minister to reply through the Chair and not to take notice of the interjections.

—Certainly, Mr President. I am a little surprised that Senator Chaney chose to intervene because I understand that he was roasted by Mr Elliott for not buying the right pies at some Liberal Party function recently. Because he bought Four'n'Twenty pies, or did not buy Four'n'Twenty pies-whichever way it was-he got a proper roasting from Mr Elliott. To return to the question of this yacht purchase: regardless of whether it was claimed under section 51 as a deduction from the company's taxable income, if the yacht was new-I understand that it was-Elders would have had to pay sales tax of 30 per cent. But if the existing sales tax was to be abolished and a VAT introduced, no tax would be payable on that yacht because it would appear not as a consumption good but as an intermediate business good and the sales tax of 30 per cent currently payable would not be payable under a normal VAT arrangement.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the sort of change that Mr Elliott wants to make in the taxation system to avoid the sales tax currently payable on such luxury purchases so that he can duchess his friends on the company yacht and plug the revenue gap by putting a 10 per cent or so tax on the pies that the hoi polloi eat in the outer at Princes Park while he himself is sitting in the tax deductable company box in the grandstand. Finally-in case Mr Elliott complains about this as well-it should be noted that Mr Elliott was offered the opportunity to debate on television tonight the issues that I have raised in the Senate and that Terry McCrann first raised in the Melbourne Age more than two years ago and he declined that offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Does he agree with his colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who in a recent interview gave support to the proposed Senate inquiry into agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia? Is that the view of the Government also?
—I think that the answer to the two parts of the question is yes and yes.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does this mean that the Minister, therefore, disagrees with the comments made by Senator Walsh, who took the view that the Australian Democrats' inquiry would be counterproductive to Australia's best interests? Given the opposition within the industry and the Government's own ranks on this, why has the Government jeopardised a valuable export earning industry which has the highest standard in the world? Has the Government been forced into yet another deal with the Democrats, a party that Senator Walsh has described as `the fairies at the bottom of the garden party'?

—The first part of the supplementary question, as I heard it, was whether, therefore, I disagree with my colleague Senator Walsh. Senator Brownhill then went on to quote what he alleges Senator Walsh said. I do not have the actual quote from Senator Walsh in front of me and I have not been able to confer with Senator Walsh during the asking of that question to see whether Senator Brownhill quoted him accurately. But my understanding is that if Senator Walsh said those words he would have said them earlier than when the terms of reference of the proposed inquiry were framed.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health to my question of five months ago-on 23 November last year-about a British report that claimed that risks of fatal cancer from low level radiation had been greatly underestimated. The Minister answered that the Australian Radiation Laboratory was reviewing that new information to determine what changes, if any, needed to be made to the Australian recommended radiation protection standards. Can the Minister advise what recommendations have been made?

—During the latter half of 1987 the International Commission of Radiological Protection indicated that the risks associated with radiation exposure could be higher than the estimates of risk which were currently in use. Those higher estimates are based on studies of Japanese survivors following the atomic bomb explosions at Hiroshima and Nagasaki and on a re-evaluation of the doses to which those populations were exposed. A complete review of all available information is being undertaken by the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation and will be reported to the United Nations by the end of this year. This review will provide a basis for new recommendations on radiation protection which are being developed by the International Commission of Radiological Protection. The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) will examine these recommendations when they become available and will adopt them for use in Australia if they are considered appropriate. In the meantime, advice is being prepared by the NHMRC for radiation users which makes allowance for these higher risks. On average, the annual exposure of Australian radiation workers is less than one-fiftieth of the current recommended dose limits.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given reports that trade between Taiwan and mainland China broke the $US1 billion mark last year, it is evident that mainland China ipso facto recognises the existence of Taiwan, and vice versa, at least sufficiently to enable commerce to proceed to a rapidly increasing return. What is the Australian Government doing about following this lead and extending the official, commercial and social limits with Taiwan so that Australian businesses may take better advantage of this market?

—It is acknowledged that Taiwan is a thriving and important market for Australian traders, as indeed it is for those of many other countries. We do have a significant volume of trade with Taiwan. The political sensitivities of that relationship should, however, be extremely obvious, indeed self-evident, to Senator Archer and any other observer of the scene. It has been necessary for us to tread carefully and sensitively in further developing the trading relationship in question. Issues arise constantly about the nature and character of our trade representation there-issues about transport links and so on with it. They are all issues that are under constant consideration and review by the Government. That review process has to take due account of the subtleties and sensitivities of the situation. Beyond that I do not propose to comment any further.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to comments by Senator MacGibbon in a debate on the submarine project on 13 April 1988 when he asserted the Opposition's belief that `Australia, having started to build these submarines, that exercise must be executed as efficiently and effectively as possible'-a proposition with which I agree. Is the Minister aware of other comments by a senior Opposition spokesperson on Defence, the shadow Minister, Peter White, on 10 April-only a few days before Senator MacGibbon's contribution-still advocating a nuclear submarine option? Can the Minister give any indication of the likely cost of pursuing the nuclear submarine option? Is this the first instance in which the Opposition has advocated a massive addition to the defence capital vote? Is the difference evidenced above indicative of division within the Opposition, not only in regard to policy about defence and submarines but also about how to pay for them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked whether I was aware of comments by Mr White about nuclear submarines. I have a copy of the Press release issued by Mr White on 10 April in which he said of nuclear submarines, among other things:

ANSWER.PARA: One of the most effective deterrents, and therefore one of the most powerful instruments for maintaining peace in our region, was abandoned without a whimper.
The next Liberal-National Government does not intend to let this happen a second time.

Of course, that can be read only as a commitment-in the unlikely event of there being a Liberal-National Party coalition government or possibly by next year even a Liberal-National Party coalition of any sort-to procure nuclear submarines. I was asked what the cost of that would be if it were actually carried through. It was reported in the Age last week that the proposed purchase of 10 Trafalgar class nuclear submarines by Canada from the United Kingdom would cost around $8.8 billion-which is roughly double the estimated cost of the submarines about to be constructed for the Royal Australian Navy.

Mr White has not made it clear in that Press release whether he proposes to abandon the present project or whether the Opposition's commitment would be additional to it. That could be inferred from Senator MacGibbon's comment:
Australia having started to build these submarines, that exercise must be executed as efficiently and effectively as possible.

Certainly it seems, if one puts the comments of Senator MacGibbon and Mr White together, that the Opposition is committed to completing the existing submarine program and buying nuclear submarines as well, at a cost, if 10 submarines were chosen, of around $9 billion.

I was also asked whether there were any other commitments for defence expenditure by spokespeople for the Opposition. The answer to that is yes. There is another very significant proposal, again from Mr White, the shadow Defence Minister. On 28 January this year Mr White said in regard to an aircraft carrier:

In due course there is no doubt Australia will acquire a sea-going platform capable of operating fixed-wing aircraft. Without such a platform our Navy is virtually confined to coastal waters in the event of major hostilities.

So to the $9 billion that Mr White has already committed a future coalition government to spending, one has to add another $3 billion, at least. That represents $12 billion extra expenditure on defence alone. This is from a coalition that talks about cutting government expenditure. It has no more sense of coherence in regard to its expenditure and budgetary policies than it has in regard to its media policies-as has been demonstrated over the past week. Indeed, given these commitments by Mr White, I see absolutely no reason why he, too, should not be regarded as just another fiscal ratbag in the Opposition. I expect that Senator Stone so regards him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I ask that the Minister withdraw that last remark.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw that reference.
—What, that Senator Stone regards Mr White as a fiscal ratbag?
—No, I ask the Minister to withdraw the words `fiscal ratbag'.
—Very well, Mr President; I withdraw.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to the Government's discounting by 2 per cent of the annual adjustments to superannuation paid to former Commonwealth Government employees. I particularly remind Senator Walsh of his assurance to the Senate on 3 July, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: As soon as economic circumstances permit a responsible Government to do so it is the Government's intention to put back the one-off discount of the last Budget into the pension base.

As it is now the view of Mr Keating that Australia is on the verge of an economic miracle and that the public is also entitled to know-in the words of Mr Keating-`that the rewards of its restraint and good sense are there now to see', I ask: Why is the Government not now acting in accordance with its commitment to retired Commonwealth employees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let it be noted that here is yet another proposition to increase government expenditure coming from the Opposition, which says it is committed to reducing government expenditure. Its logic is about as sound as its arithmetic.
—But this is what you assured them.

—I am coming to that. If the honourable senator thinks that he will embarrass me by quoting what I have said, I can assure him that he will not. I said not only in the Senate last year, or whenever it was, but also-if it is not the same thing, it is a very similar thing-in the large number of letters I have sent out in the last 12 months, that when economic circumstances permitted, a responsible government would restore the cut. The economic circumstances that at the very least are required for that to be restored are as follows. Firstly, it is required that real wages be on a rising trend instead of, as they have been, on a falling trend. When real wages are clearly again generally on a rising trend, then one of the conditions would have been met. That has not happened.
—Isn't that what you are promising the ACTU now?

—I have no doubt that if Senator Stone's party got back into government, in the short term there would be a significant increase in real wages for those people who still managed to have a job. However, probably there would be half a million people out of jobs very quickly because of that. The Opposition does not have a wages policy, other than one of letting the market sort it out. That is the same policy actually implemented by it in 1981 when wages explosions of 13 per cent and 14 per cent were induced. It is no wonder Mr Macphee said that the Government's wages policies and industrial relations policies are far more successful than those of the alternative government would have been.

ANSWER.PARA: The second condition which needs to be met is that the current account deficit presently, very large though the reduction has been-that is the background to the statement made by the Treasurer and referred to by Senator Hill-is still a higher proportion of gross domestic product than the GDP growth rate. In other words, as long as that applies, foreign debt, as a proportion of GDP, is increasing. In those circumstances it is certainly not responsible to start reversing savings decisions that were made less than two years ago. Of course, it is even less responsible, or grossly irresponsible, to be suggesting that billions and billions of dollars should be added to existing outlays in the way that Mr White, among other people in the Opposition, has been saying.

To sum up, there are two conditions which must be met before it would be responsible to restore that 2 per cent reduction. May I say, of course, that 2 per cent reduction in the payments to retired workers is significantly less than the reduction in incomes taken on average by people who are still in the work force. Real wages for people still in the work force fell by significantly more than that. The two conditions that have to be met are that the foreign debt, as a proportion of GDP, must clearly be on a falling trend and real wages must clearly be on a rising trend.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Transport and Communications heard comments made this morning by the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Sinclair, expressing opposition to the policy of aggregation of regional television markets? What would be the effects on country television viewers if aggregation did not proceed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Sinclair, with his remarks this morning that aggregation would not improve viewers' choice, has joined the ranks of all those other Opposition lemmings jostling for the right to be first over the cliff. He has joined the ranks of the Opposition leaders, spokesmen and self-appointed opinion leaders who have spent, at last count, six days, eight reported meetings and something like 153 consecutive media appearances-and now there is to be a kamikaze urgency motion in the House of Representatives-making comprehensive fools of themselves. Nothing could be closer to the hearts, the minds and the aspirations of country television viewers than the right to gain access to not just one but three commercial television stations. If Mr Sinclair, as the Leader of the National Party, does not understand that-or if he suggests otherwise, as he did this morning-all I can suggest is that he is either a knave or a fool, or he is insensitive.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I suggest that the Minister should not be permitted to suggest that a member of parliament is a knave or a fool, and he should be asked to withdraw.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw.

—I withdraw the descriptions and let the analysis speak for itself. Either he is totally ignorant of the practical benefits that will flow to country viewers from aggregation and the way in which aggregation will be held back by the opposition to the 75 per cent increase in audience reach, or he is totally insensitive and utterly fails to appreciate the quality of life, the aspirations and the welfare of the people he purports to represent. Alternatively-one hopes that this is not the case-it represents his relationship with a number of figures in the National Party who stand, or think they stand, to benefit financially from a continuation of the status quo. They are the only possible explanations for the kinds of remarks made this morning.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Sinclair is suggesting that the four million Australians in eastern mainland regions who now receive only one commercial television service, along with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation service, would prefer to confine their viewing to just that one service, rather than enjoying the benefits of choosing between three commercial services offering the full range of programming that is available to the people in the mainland capitals. He is suggesting by what he said this morning that people do not want the right to choose between watching cricket and watching tennis, as the case may be; they do not want the right to choose between different drama series, between different films, between different comedy programs, between different news and current affairs programs or between different local programs that are put together by the various stations.

It is simply palpable nonsense for Mr Sinclair to assert, as he went on to do in the interview in question, that regional viewers will miss out on local news and sport and other local programs as a result of receiving these additional services. The truth of the matter is that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has a duty to ensure that all stations, regardless of their locality, provide an adequate and comprehensive service. In the case of regional television stations, a comprehensive service would unquestionably include local programming. Quite apart from any statutory obligations of this kind, market forces in the form of viewer demand will clearly act to ensure that aggregated services, operating as they will be in a newly-competitive environment, will be compelled to cover local community events and issues adequately.

The truth of the matter is that Mr Sinclair and his coalition colleagues are being roundly condemned, and should be roundly condemned, by all country viewers for their stated intention to oppose the increase in audience reach limits. As I have repeatedly said, their position means that a major obstacle will now be placed in the way of achieving aggregation throughout Queensland and in the New South Wales southern region in particular. There will necessarily be major delays in viewers getting access to three stations, compared with the one they get at the moment, and the blame for that state of affairs lies squarely at the feet of Mr Sinclair and his coalition colleagues.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw attention to the presence in my gallery of the President of the European Parliament, Lord Plumb. On behalf of all senators, I extend to him a warm welcome to Australia, and Canberra in particular, and I trust that he will enjoy the rest of his visit. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite the President to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Lord Plumb thereupon entered the chamber, and was seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications and follows his expressions of concern for the choice which is available to rural people in Australia. I ask the Minister whether he is aware that it has been announced that East-West Airlines Ltd will close its Western Australian operations this week. Is he aware that the airline will fly the last of its jet services on the two busiest air routes within the State-Perth to Karratha and Perth to Port Hedland-on Saturday and that the closure of those East-West services will mean there will be a monopoly on those two routes? Does the Minister agree that the amount of competition and the potential for greater competition in airline operations has been significantly reduced since Labor came to power, in particular because of the changed ownership of East-West Airlines? Given the Minister's pessimism about getting the needed capital for Australian Airlines from Budget sources, the resistance within the Australian Labor Party to the privatisation of Australian Airlines and the policy confusion in this area, what assurance can the Minister give that Australian Airlines will be put in a financial position to compete with Ansett Airlines of Australia and that there will be a choice of air travel offered to Australian consumers, something which appears to be diminishing under his administration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney presumably will be well aware that the fate of East-West Airlines is squarely a consequence of a decision some little time ago by the Trade Practices Commission-a decision which was itself, of course, governed by a concern to ensure that there were not monopoly situations developing in this instance as a result of the acquisition of East-West Airlines by Ansett. The fact that there has not proved to be a buyer for the routes and the aircraft in question, to date anyway, as a result of the prospect of divestment that followed from that Trade Practices Commission decision is just one of the consequences, one hopes a temporary consequence, not of any Government policy decision but of a bipartisan attachment to anti-monopoly, pro-competitive laws operating under the guidance of the Trade Practices Commission. It is a quite squalid little effort, of the kind with which we have become so familiar from Senator Chaney, for him to suggest that Government policy had anything directly to do with the current state of affairs.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is very anxious, as of course is the Western Australian Government, with which I have been discussing this matter in recent weeks, to ensure that there is a well-serviced set of airline routes in Western Australia and is anxious that that situation should resolve itself as soon as possible. I cannot request or direct Australian Airlines to make what it regards as uncommercial decisions. The truth of the matter is that, as much as Australian Airlines might like to operate F28 services in various parts of Western Australia, it simply does not have the kind of infrastructure into which that kind of operation would readily or financially fit. It is not a matter of the capital base of Australian Airlines in any way contributing to that state of affairs or of any shortfalls in that capital base; it is a result simply of a hard-headed commercial decision that has been made. A number of other operations are potentially available for the restoration of competition and a full range of services on the Western Australian air routes in question, and it is the hope of all of us that the situation will resolve itself in the near future. Beyond that, I am unable to comment on the situation. I simply express the response that it is quite irrelevant to raise the question of the future capital prospects of Australian Airlines for the reasons that I have just mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I simply point out to the Minister that the second part of my question related to the broader question of maintaining competition within the airline system of Australia, and not simply Western Australia. Is the Minister in his answer denying that Australian Airlines does require a considerable addition of capital if it is to be able to compete nationally with Ansett? Does he deny that there is a policy gap, given the opposition of his Party to privatisation and the unlikelihood, according to him, of the necessary capital being found from Budget sources? In those circumstances, what guarantee can he give us that not just in Western Australia but generally we are going to have other than a one-airline policy in this country?

—Of course it is the case, as I have said on numerous occasions and most recently yesterday, that Australian Airlines will need a substantial capital injection if it is to grow and flourish, particularly in the much more competitive deregulatory environment that we are anxious to implement with the termination of the two airlines policy in 1990. As the Advisory Group on Australian Airlines reported yesterday, it does need an injection of something like $240m over three years if it is to maintain the kind of financial viability that we all want it to have in that particular environment. As I also said yesterday, it is the case that there are going to be obvious difficulties about providing that capital injection from the Budget in this year or, indeed, in the foreseeable future. That does create a problem of some significance. I do not suggest there is any ready answer to that problem. I have obviously expressed a view personally, and I do so again, that a private equity injection would be one way of resolving the problem. There may be others, but that is a policy issue with which the Government is continuing to grapple.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister seen an article by Rod Myer in last night's Melbourne Herald headed `Crackdown on Capital Gain brings threat to pensions'? Is the Minister aware of the situation which exists where there is, as the article says, `a treatment of capital gains for pensioners much tougher than the same tax applying to Australian millionaire businessmen'? Does the Minister acknowledge the injustice of a Department of Social Security income test which assesses capital gain as income on a retrospective basis not applicable to the capital gains tax, which takes no account of inflation in its definition of a capital gain and which allows no averaging such as is available in relation to the capital gains tax? Does the Minister agree that pensioners should be tested on capital gain only on the same basis as that on which other members of the community are taxed, not more harshly?
—Can you remember all that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Haines's supplementary question, yes, I can remember all that, because Senator Powell was decent enough to alert me to an article which I had not seen. As a consequence, I have been able to get advice from the Department of Social Security, and I am advised that the statement that pensioners are being tested for capital gains much more toughly than Australian millionaire businessmen is quite wrong. The Government's view is that pensioners should be tested on capital gains on the same basis as other members of the community, and in fact they are. I ask the Senate to note that the social security system is in fact quite different from the taxation system. Its basis is that the level of financial assistance available to a person depends on the availability of other income sources stated as support for that person.

ANSWER.PARA: The new provisions that the article refers to were designed after extensive consultation to accurately and consistently measure a person's resources and available income support. It is interesting to note that in the article Senator Powell is quoted as saying that the system is outrageous. We should note that when the legislation was before the Senate it was recognised to be both necessary and equitable, and it should also be noted that the Australian Democrats at that stage did not dissent from that view.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Can he confirm that he has withdrawn from his scheduled visit in the next two or three weeks to the Katherine region of the Northern Territory to consult with the Jawoyn people about the proposed Coronation Hill gold mine? Can he further confirm that he intends sending in his place Mr Tony Henry, a member of his personal electorate office staff, to conduct these highly sensitive discussions on the future of one of the nation's most valuable mineral deposits? Can he further advise whether it is his view that the Coronation Hill mine should proceed and whether he is dealing with the matter with the seriousness which his portfolio demands?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling asks me first of all whether I have varied my itinerary. Since being on the front bench I have discovered that the itineraries of Ministers are subject to infinite variation because of huge and competing demands, and I vary my itinerary all the time. The fact that I vary it is no indication that I place lesser or heavier weight or responsibility on any particular issue; I do so because of working out the immediate priority. For example, next week I was going to look at some coal mines. Instead, I am going to look at some forests, because I think the forest accord is the immediate and most important issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Tambling's second question asked whether I was going to send a member of staff. The answer is yes. That does not in itself mean that I will not myself go and talk to the Jawoyn people. I have a great deal of respect for the way in which Aboriginal communities come to decisions. Ministers buzzing in and then buzzing out and having a quick discussion may not be the most appropriate way of dealing with sensitive issues. Therefore, the member of my staff, Mr Tony Henry, who prior to being a member of my staff was a lecturer at the Aboriginal college in the Northern Territory and dealt with the Jawoyn people in educational programs, is uniquely fitted and appropriate to go and spend the necessary time to talk to them about the issues.

What does this mean in terms of the Coronation Hill procedure? Of course, the Coronation Hill issue is important for the Government.
