We have heard Senator Richardson refer to the environmental aspects and we have heard other debate in this chamber also on this issue. All of the matters with respect to Coronation Hill are, in the immediate sense, waiting for a conclusion of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd environmental impact statement for there to be a considered response by the Government on the environmental concerns.

The Aboriginal issues concerning Coronation Hill require further discussions with the Jawoyn people, and it is for that purpose that I scheduled the visit and it is for that purpose that Mr Henry will conduct those consultations. That is not to be taken to mean that I will not be attending in person to my ministerial responsibility with respect to the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Resources. Has he read Press reports of a speech made yesterday by the Chairman of Caltex, in which Mr Landels makes the serious claim that the Government is denying Caltex access to Bass Strait crude at free market prices? What can the Minister say about the Government's response to this serious charge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read reports in several journals today of an address by Mr Landels, the chief executive of Caltex Oil, to his annual general meeting on the subject of the underlift by Caltex in terms of its obligations to lift Bass Strait crude oil. I was a bit surprised when I first saw a reference to the matter, because it has been the subject of cordial talks between Caltex and the Australian Government on at least two occasions, although I recognise Mr Landels' obligation to inform his annual general meeting. However, the way in which he puts a gloss on his remarks I think requires some surprise on my part and an answer to the question that has been asked by Senator Burns.

ANSWER.PARA: In June 1987 the Government announced its intention to deregulate the oil industry and to terminate on 31 December 1987 the crude oil allocation scheme that then applied. Refiners were informed that the Government expected them to meet their obligations to lift their 1987 allocation of crude oil so as to bring the scheme to a conclusion on a balanced and equitable basis. Administrative guidelines were issued in October 1987 setting out the Government's expectations of how refiners obligations were to be met. With the sole exception of Caltex all refiners have met their obligations in full.

Caltex claims that it was unable to meet its obligations under the allocation scheme due to circumstances beyond its control. At 1 January 1988 Caltex had failed to lift 5.4 million barrels of Bass Strait crude oil. The Government has carefully reviewed Caltex's claims and has allowed a reduction in the outstanding obligation of 813,392 barrels of crude for product and feedstock imported by Caltex to maintain supplies to consumers during the industrial dispute at the Kurnell Refinery in October-November 1987. The Government has rejected the balance of Caltex's claims, which are based on unsubstantiated claims that Bass Strait crude was unavailable to it or that repairs to its vessels resulted in a shortage of shipping to lift Bass Strait crude oil. Instead of lifting Bass Strait crude, as all other refiners did, Caltex chose to import large quantities of crude oil of similar quality from South East Asia. Thorough investigations have shown that these decisions to import crude oil, rather than lift Bass Strait crude oil, were commercial in nature and quite clearly within the control of Caltex. They led directly to the underlift situation.

The Government has advised Caltex that it expects the company to meet its outstanding obligations under the crude oil allocation scheme by clearing its underlift at the 1 December 1987 import parity price. To do otherwise would be inequitable to the other refiners, all of whom have met their obligations in full. To conclude the matter, if the underlift is not carried through, I intend in the next few weeks to hold a meeting with the other refiners in the oil industry to see whether through that forum it is not possible to persuade Caltex now to attend to its obligations.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The President of the European Parliament is now leaving the chamber.

INTERJECT.PARA: Lord Plumb thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Knowles asked me a question about the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). I gave her an answer but I said that if there was anything I wished to add to my answer I would do so and took the balance of the question on notice. I now wish to add some further points to what I said to Senator Knowles yesterday. The parallel that Senator Knowles drew to screening for tuberculosis is not relevant to AIDS. Tuberculosis is a communicable disease and can be caught by casual social contact. There is no evidence that AIDS can be caught in this way.
—It can also be treated, unlike AIDS.

—That is a very worthwhile interjection and I take it on board. With AIDS, the Government's aim has been to provide all Australians with sufficient knowledge so they do not put themselves at risk of catching the disease. With respect to screening immigrants for AIDS, there are no plans to introduce routine screening. If the routine medical examination that all migrants undergo reveals abnormalities that may be consistent with HIV infection, a blood test may be ordered. If a person is found to have AIDS or AIDS-related disease that person is not normally allowed to immigrate.

ANSWER.PARA: As I stated yesterday, it is not practical to screen all persons entering Australia, as this would include tourists. In addition, as Australia has the third highest per capita incidence of AIDS in the Western world, the net effect of immigration is likely to dilute our incidence rather than increase it. In addition, the immigration process probably selects against people who are HIV infected in that emphasis is given to family reunion. Homosexuals, who are still a large part of the infected group, are less likely to have spouses or dependants than other persons and thus will often not qualify on family reunion grounds. Intravenous drug addicts, another infected group, will already be disqualified by the usual medical examination. The waiting period between application and approval-often up to a year-would discourage persons who, knowing they were HIV positive, were seeking to come to Australia, apparently for our cheaper medical care. Another matter to consider is the cost of routine screening were it introduced. There would be a considerable cost associated with the test, including the recommended counselling and associated administrative costs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 February, Senator Harradine asked me a long question concerning a number of matters about human bioethics, human foetal tissue in embryos and so on. I now have an answer to that question and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am aware of the concerns of Senator Harradine in certain areas of bioethical research and its funding through NHMRC grants. As I stated in a letter to him on 15 December 1987, due to the specialist nature of medical research and the large number of projects which receive consideration each year, I am essentially dependent on the advice of NHMRC. Nevertheless I have noted Senator Harradine's concerns and have asked NHMRC to take particular cognizance of sensitivities in the area of bioethical research when making recommendations in the future.

Many factors are taken into account in assessing projects for funding including the reports of three independent assessors. Regarding Professor Singer's academic standing, the assessors have stated that his centre is the most professional and productive bioethics centre in Australia and that Professor Singer has a reputation second to none in Australia for competence and expertise in this field.
Because of the nature of Professor Singer's research, I consider it quite proper for him and his colleagues to express bioethical viewpoints in the current debate on human embryo experimentation.

Professor Singer's group did not prepare a pro-human embryo experimentation argument to the Victorian Standing Review and Advisory Committee on Infertility. The group were invited by the Chairman of the Committee to respond to a submission prepared by the St Vincents Bioethics Centre. Their paper did not express a one-sided pro-experimentation argument. It took no stand either for or against embryo experimentation. It confined itself entirely to the question of when a new human individual is formed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I present a report entitled Energy 2000-A National Energy Policy Paper. I seek leave to make a statement on the report and to move a motion relating to the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tabling this report concludes an extensive process of consultation with the States, industry, and all interest groups involved in the energy sector. The process of consultation started in 1985 when my colleague and predecessor, Senator Gareth Evans, announced that an energy policy review was to be initiated. A series of 10 discussion papers was released in 1986, submissions were invited on those papers and 76 were received. That process led to a major national conference in Canberra in September 1986, attended by more than 100 delegates, including industry, government, union and academic representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The conference concentrated on issues related to petroleum policy. This in turn led to major policy decisions which were announced in mid-1987. I refer in particular to the changes in the petroleum excise system and the decision to deregulate the crude oil market from 1 January 1988. Since then, there have been further discussions with industry and close consultation with State governments, including a review under the Australian Minerals and Energy Council of the outlook for crude oil self-sufficiency in Australia, the economic implications of the likely decline in crude oil self-sufficiency, and the outlook for alternative liquid fuels. In recent months there has been further close consultation with State governments on the final drafting of Energy 2000.

This process of consultation culminates today in the presentation of Energy 2000. But this does not mean that consultation is now a closed book. Indeed, I propose to put in place some specific new arrangements to continue necessary consultation with the energy industries, State governments and unions, and I commend this document as a thorough and comprehensive basis for those consultations.

Energy policy is vital to all of us. The crucial effect of energy supplies and prices on economic activity and living standards was driven home by the oil crises of the 1970s. This Government has already done much in the energy field. We have been developing energy security through the balanced use of various sources of energy and reducing our dependence on oil; encouraging fuel switching away from oil to alternatives, particularly coal and gas in the case of Australia; encouraging crude oil exploration and development and refining activities in Australia; fostering conservation of energy, especially oil, including by increasing efficiency in energy usage; establishing a long term research and development effort to assess long term energy options, especially in respect of alternative liquid fuels, but also renewable energy sources; encouraging the development and expansion of energy export industries and infrastructure, especially with regard to coal but also uranium and gas; and developing response mechanisms, such as emergency planning, capable of ameliorating the shorter term impact of any future oil crises.

Energy 2000 re-assesses those policies and progress made. Many aspects of the energy framework are volatile and changeable. Policy responses therefore need to be pragmatic and flexible, to accommodate the changing problems and priorities. This is not a doctrinaire master plan. We have adjusted our policies when necessary, and will continue to do so. What have we learned from the Energy 2000 review? In terms of energy outlook to 2000: domestic demand will grow by an estimated 30 per cent, with the major components being 1.6 per cent per annum growth in petroleum products; 2.1 per cent per annum for natural gas; and 2.9 per cent per annum for coal.

Indigenous energy supply will also grow-quite substantially-except in the area of crude oil, where any such growth must depend on major new discoveries. In the absence of such discoveries, we will face a decline in crude oil self-sufficiency and imports of crude oil will grow substantially. Our energy exports will also grow and we should be able to look forward to a substantial positive energy trade balance-as much as $60 billion over the period 1989 to 2000.

With respect to total energy demand: the relative importance of petroleum products will decrease from about 39 per cent in 1986-87 to around 36 per cent in 1999-2000; gas consumption as a percentage of the total will be relatively stable at about 17 per cent; there will be a significant increase in coal usage, from about 40 per cent of total energy demand in 1986-87 to 44 per cent in 1999-2000.

Competition in the marketplace between energy sources and between energy technologies will produce the greatest gains for the smallest cost. But the market mechanism is never perfect and there is a clear need to monitor developments closely and, where justified, to supplement the market by Government initiatives. Such initiatives may be necessary and, if so, will be applied. We may need to ensure that Australia's dependence on oil as an energy source does not grow in such a way as to weaken the nation's energy security. Competition, reinforced where necessary by Government initiatives, is to be the primary driving force that will determine Australia's energy production and consumption mix to 2000.

We have identified three major energy objectives: security of overall energy supplies; development of the export energy sector; and efficiency in the domestic energy sector. Let me review the Government's approach to achieving improved exports and greater domestic efficiency first, before turning to the broader issue of energy security. Energy policies have to complement and strengthen our broader economic policies. We are a major energy exporter. We are the world's largest exporter of coal, accounting for about 25 per cent of world coal trade; a major exporter of uranium; and about to become a major exporter of liquefied natural gas.

We estimate that there will be a favourable energy trade balance of $60 billion over the period 1989 to 2000, in 1986-87 dollars. The principal contributions will be from: liquefied natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas-more than $15 billion; steaming coal-more than $30 billion; coking coal-more than $40 billion; and uranium-more than $9 billion. These exports will offset any projected crude oil imports over this period, bringing the net positive figure down to $63 billion. We will clearly be able to finance our oil imports. However, we will need to ensure that we maintain our international competitiveness if this export potential is to be realised-or even exceeded. Specific policy approaches are set out in the document. The most important current issue is the completion of a coal strategy that will ensure a strong, economically viable and internationally competitive coal industry well into the twenty-first century.

Efficiency in our domestic activities involves productivity and operational efficiency in our oil, coal, gas and electricity industries. In the oil industry, the focus is to make our refining industry as efficient as possible, given our growing relative reliance on the refining sector to process imported crude oil, if self-sufficiency does decline as currently projected. The oil industry is attracting substantial investment under the policies that we have in place. In the last few weeks the Shell Company has announced a $2.8 billion investment program covering its activities in Australia from petroleum exploration through to refining and distribution. Investments such as this will inevitably add to the efficiency of the oil industry. In gas and electricity we have ample resources and raw materials, and the challenge is how best to manage our performance and ensure reliable delivery at reasonable prices. Our approach on these matters is set out in the report. I particularly draw attention to progress with the North West Shelf project, which has both domestic and export aspects. This project is Australia's most important energy project and construction is progressing satisfactorily, with the first export shipment planned for October 1989. More broadly, we should recognise the growing contribution of the gas industry to domestic markets. Natural gas production is now equivalent to about 250,000 barrels of oil per day, a major achievement when it is noted that Bass Strait production of crude oil is currently about 400,000 barrels per day.

We have found a growing recognition that the key to energy security is confidence in our overall energy supplies, based on good management and pursuit of sound economic principles. In terms of domestic energy requirements, our energy security is strongly underpinned by the availability of coal, gas and electricity and our approach is to encourage greater relative reliance on these fuels which we have in abundance. We recognise the scope for concern about future crude oil supplies, although I must say that in recent months it has been mainly from explorers and producers wanting a better tax deal. They are entitled to put their point of view vigorously. So are we.

We currently have a high level of self-sufficiency, but it is running down. We have time to adjust to this, and the Government's approach is to increase the efficiency with which oil is produced, refined and used; search for and develop new sources of crude oil; and seek increasing use of alternative liquid fuels. We have already made substantial progress in refining our petroleum policies, through deregulation of the crude oil market; crude oil excise liberalisation, including reduced maximum rates and the exemption from excise of the first 30 million barrels of production; confirmation that condensate marketed separately is free from excise; introduction of resource rent tax for offshore greenfields areas; improved access to offshore exploration areas; liberalisation of foreign investment rules for petroleum development; support for major energy projects such as the North West Shelf; detailed analysis of alternative fuels potential; and encouragement of research and development to improve fuel use efficiency.

Much attention has been focused by the oil exploration companies on the need for policies more favourable to them. Their financial interest is understandable but as an industry they cannot guarantee a greater exploration effort, nor can they guarantee positive exploration results. For our part, we cannot determine the international oil prices. We cannot change the basic level of Australia's prospectivity. The real judgment is whether the exploration effort being made by the private sector is satisfactory, with all things considered-prices, prospectivity, taxation and the market outlook.

Given the recent events which have affected the oil industry worldwide, the Government is satisfied that the current exploration effort and the present outlook for exploration in Australia are consistent with market conditions. Exploration activity in Australia is following a similar trend to that being experienced in other countries, with drilling activity showing a significant recovery from the effects of the oil price collapse. Latest industry estimates of activity for 1988 include 190 exploration wells onshore and 26 wells offshore. For onshore wells, this is about the average level for the last five years while for offshore wells it is below the five-year average but a substantial improvement on the 15 wells drilled in 1987. The recovery in offshore exploration this year is particularly heartening. Four drilling rigs are at present active offshore and a total of seven rigs are expected to be working offshore later in the year. This is a healthy sign for exploration activity.

In what is becoming accepted as one of our most prospective areas-the Timor Sea region-activity is increasing rapidly, with as many as 20 wells being predicted for 1988. Companies currently not working in the region, including many overseas companies, are actively seeking acreage. Up to four offshore rigs are expected to be working in the Timor Sea region during 1988. It is also expected that the Carnarvon and Gippsland Basins will see a significant level of offshore activity in 1988 and future years. Onshore, activity is focusing on those areas close to established infrastructure, such as the Cooper-Eromanga Basin, and other areas are also showing signs of increasing activity.

In terms of oil development, further very worthwhile investment is being made by Esso Australia Ltd and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to bring onstream a number of smaller fields in Bass Strait while in other areas offshore the West Australian Petroleum Pty Ltd group has announced plans for the early development of Saladin field. Feasibility studies and design work are continuing for the Goodwyn gascondensate project and the Challis oil project. This level of activity would not exist if our policies were unsatisfactory. Clearly, the policies are working.

With companies able and prepared to take a longer term view, and plan on the basis of an expectation of higher crude oil prices towards the year 2000, we are also seeing a re-emergence of interest in higher risk areas with potential for larger discoveries. Nevertheless, we will be monitoring closely the exploration industry performance, in terms of both the ongoing level of activity and the results of that activity. The Government recognises that, unless its policies are realistic and there continue to be commercial successes, exploration funds will be directed elsewhere.

If exploration is unsuccessful and reliance on imported oil grows, then it may become desirable to move to the greater use of alternative fuels, particularly for transportation uses. Such a move would be difficult in technological terms and would have to be justifiable in economic terms. The Government sees its role as monitoring developments, supporting desirable basic research and development, and generally helping to narrow the options, so that the private sector can consider realistically decisions on investment in this area.

In regard to support for research into alternative fuels, I am pleased to announce that the Government will provide an additional $5m over the next three years. I will be seeking industry cooperation on a 50/50 funding basis and the intention is to gear up a substantial new research activity, focusing particularly on the use of gas as a transport fuel. The Government's approach is set out in more detail in Energy 2000.

To sum up, our policy on petroleum is much broader than exploration and we now have in place major policies that encourage a range of options to meet our energy policy objectives. In that context Energy 2000 is not a master plan of targets for Australia's energy industries, or a series of new and detailed policy prescriptions to 2000. If it were, the implication would be that the many energy policy initiatives we have already implemented had not worked or needed radical change-this is just not the case. The initiatives we have already implemented are working and are at various stages of achieving their desired objectives.

What we have done is set a framework in which we can get the best out of our energy resources while remaining ready to respond to circumstances. Recognising this, the Government believes that regular and close monitoring of energy developments and the energy outlook would be facilitated by the establishment of a new consultative body. Accordingly, the Government will establish a broadly-based consultative group comprising representatives of the Commonwealth and State governments, the energy industries and the trade union movement. It will, through consultation, help to identify any major changes in trends away from the projections and positions outlined in the Energy 2000 document. In this sense the Energy 2000 review process will be a continuing one that ensures that a proper focus is maintained on the vital energy issues that affect Australia's future economic well-being.

The Australian people expect energy security-and they have a right to do so. The energy industries expect both stability and pragmatism in government policies-and they have a right to do so. Our policies will give us the solid basis we need, and will give industry the incentives it needs, to maintain energy security well beyond the year 2000. I commend the report to honourable senators and to the general community. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is a new $5m.

I refer to the Director-General of Victoria's Department of Industry, Technology and Resources, Hans Eisen-a very good friend with whom I went to school but have not seen for a very long time. In a very good article in the Bulletin of 27 October a Mr Peter Gill said:

Representatives of all sectors of the energy industry and state governments had a round-table conference with the then Resources and Energy Minister, Senator Gareth Evans.

Issues were debated, well-rehearsed arguments were aired and a major policy statement covering the rest of the century was promised.

If one looks at this poster advertisement from Esso Australia Ltd which appeared in The Australian of Thursday, 17 March of this year, it will be seen that Esso is asking:
What can we hope to achieve now we pay 83 per cent tax?

Any new offshore oil discoveries still face a tax rate of up to 70 per cent.

One sees that the so-called policies that Senator Cook claims are working are in fact a nonsense. Far from working, they are sending our investors in exploration industries overseas. I refer to a statement by my very good colleague Mr Warwick Smith, the shadow Minister for science and energy. In Brisbane on Wednesday, 23 March this year he said:
The decline in crude oil production has already had an impact on Government revenues. Those of the Commonwealth have fallen from a high of $4 billion in 1985-86-
that was as a result of Fraser Government initiatives in this area-

to $2 billion. By 1990-91 it is expected to halve and by the mid 1990s will fall to only $400m. As you well know, the burden of filling Government coffers has been transferred to the petroleum product industries.

Let us now look at a study by the Australian Minerals and Energy Council (AMEC) which was released in February this year. The AMEC study projects that oil imports, without major new Australian discoveries, will cost between $2.8 billion and $4 billion in seven years time, using current dollar values. The study forecasts that, after being a net exporter of 12 million barrels of crude oil and LPG in 1985-86, Australia will be a net importer of some 114 million barrels by 1990-91. Self-sufficiency will fall from 90 to 55 per cent and continue to deteriorate. I put it to the Senate that I have proved that Senator Gareth Evans as Minister responsible for energy was an absolute disaster, and now that the Prime Minister has taken him out of that job and put him into communications, we believe he is proving to be a disaster in that portfolio, too.

I refer to a graph, provided to me by my colleague Mr Warwick Smith, showing the decline in offshore exploration since 1983. In 1983 expenditure on offshore exploration amounted to $520m, and under this Government that has consistently fallen every year until in 1987 it had gone down to $130m. That decline is a clear consequence of the Government's policies, of which Senator Cook has the audacity to say:
To sum up, our policy on petroleum is much broader than exploration and we now have in place major policies that encourage a range of options to meet our energy policy objectives.

I do not know what his energy policy objectives are, but they certainly are not the energy policy objective of the Liberal and National parties, which is a policy of self-sufficiency. Unfortunately, I am unable to expand on other areas covered by this paper at present. This is as far as I have been able to go in the time I have had the paper available, but within a day or two my colleague Mr Warwick Smith will be issuing a detailed criticism of this ministerial paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rarely in the brief time I have been in the Senate have I read such an appalling document as that with which we have been presented this afternoon. If it had been written two centuries ago there may have been some justification for it, but it fails totally to take into account most of the important considerations which are now properly being debated worldwide. As an Australian, I am ashamed that a government in this country presents this paper as policy for the rest of the world to see. I recognise that the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) has only recently occupied his portfolio and that he would not personally be responsible for this. But I recommend to him that he immediately get rid of all those people in his Department who are responsible for this document and replace them with people who are more competent and more familiar with the important issues that are now clearly on the energy policy agenda.
—It is Evans who is responsible.

—I want to go into that now briefly, Senator Archer. We are all aware of the 10 red-covered volumes which were produced by the Department when Senator Evans was the Minister responsible for resources and energy. Looking through those 10 volumes again, I was appalled by the way in which they failed to address many of the important questions which underlie a proper and well-developed energy policy. One hoped that, out of the limited processes of public consultation in which the Government has involved itself since, the follow-up to those 10 slim documents, the Department would have dealt in this volume with some of the issues that were not earlier addressed. But in this volume even less coverage is given to those important items. The document before us says that Australia's energy policy should be directed in three ways:

SPEECH.PARA: Security of overall energy supplies; development of the export energy sector; efficiency in the domestic energy sector.

There is no mention in the statement of the fact that energy is not in itself a need. Energy is a means to an end. What needs to be guaranteed is not the supply of energy but the services which energy makes available and, in the process of which, causes considerable environmental and social consequences which also have to be addressed. In those 10 volumes which came out while Senator Gareth Evans was the responsible Minister, carbon dioxide, the principal pollutant which comes from the burning of fossil fuel, was mentioned once only in one sentence. Only one sentence in 10 volumes! In the volume before us this afternoon carbon dioxide is not mentioned at all. There is evidently a complete absence of any awareness by the Department that the burning of fossil fuels poses, in the next 40 to 50 years, serious problems relating to the greenhouse effects and the incredibly widespread consequences which flow from that in terms--

TALK.START.PARA: —Your anti-uranium policy is making it worse.
—Coal fired power stations-40,000 tonnes a year.

—As I have said in this place before, if Senator Stone and Senator Collins look at the Flowers report from Great Britain and a number of other documents, they will find that the advent of nuclear energy will increase the consumption of fossil fuel. The point I will get to in a moment and which is inadequately addressed in this document is that the direction we need to take is towards greater fuel efficiency and conservation of energy rather than looking to fresh sources of supply.
—Their mates in the industry would not like that.

—Let me pick up the point which has been made by way of interjection. This document deals with the oversupply of electricity in Australia, the overgeneration capacity by all the State generating authorities around this country, and points to the very large and growing indebtedness which has arisen. For instance, on page 11.3 of the report one will see that South Australia has an installed capacity of 2,680 megawatts, whereas the peak demand in South Australia is less than 1,600 megawatts. We find that the--
—All right, it is wasted. What has that got to do with your case?
—If Senator Stone listens he will hear.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Could you draw Senator Stone to order? If he wishes to contribute to this debate he could get on his feet and actually contribute rather than, as he normally does, sit in the corner and continue to interject and make comments while people are speaking. If he had the courtesy to listen to what Senator Coulter is saying he might be informed.

—There is no point of order. It is not appropriate to take a point of order to put a personal view about the conduct of the debate. Senator Stone is the next listed speaker. I ask all honourable senators to be restrained in their interjections.

—The document before us contains Figure 11.2 which shows that the net public sector borrowings in the electricity area increased from just over $5,000m in 1977 to almost $25,000m in 1987. The point in terms of efficiency is that in building a power station we are, at the moment, paying roughly $1 per watt of capital cost. That dollar is spent whether that watt is used or not. That is the nature of electricity. If I choose to warm my house using electric heating and I go out and buy a 1,000 watt radiator, for which I might pay as little as $35 or $40, the moment I plug it into the power source I demand from it a generating capacity of 1,000 watts. In other words, I am demanding that the State spend $1,000 to instal the capacity so that I can turn my radiator on. Yet I may turn it on for only five minutes.
—Plug it into your solar power.

—It is interesting that Senator Collins should mention this because in the Northern Territory the Government, of which I think he was once a member, on one occasion subsidised the purchase of solar energy using equipment, namely hot water services. It has recently withdrawn that subsidy and has instead put a subsidy on the purchase of air-conditioners because the Northern Territory Government has now built a power station.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that I am developing is that alternative uses of energy are available to us which use much less energy. If Senator Stone has studied physics he will know that the generation of electricity is dependent upon the Carnot cycle and rarely do we achieve efficiency of greater than about 30 per cent. So twice as much primary energy goes into the generation of electricity as that which comes out at the other end. In Australia I believe the figure is about 28 per cent of the primary energy actually emerging at the power point.

Clearly, we have to shift users of energy closer to the primary source. In other words, those who cook clearly require energy to cook but if they use gas-if gas is available to them-rather than electricity, they immediately double the efficiency with which that primary energy source is used. Those who choose to use solar energy for the warming of water, domestic purposes or even light industrial purposes do so without placing a demand on either primary non-renewable energy sources or on the sources of electricity which necessarily involve large capital expenditures, much of which goes offshore. Approximately 25 per cent of the cost of power stations goes offshore for the purchase of heavy generating equipment. So there are enormous opportunities for increasing the efficiency with which we use energy in Australia, which provide greater security of end use availability of energy without necessarily increasing the total amount of energy used and which certainly have a much more benign effect on the environment.

We have not gone very far down this road, but I shall read some interesting figures from the United States of America. Between 1978 and 1986 the official United States of America economy, measured as real gross national product (GNP), grew by 19 per cent, while energy consumption fell by 5 per cent from 78.1 quads in 1978 to 74.3 quads in 1986. Had United States energy efficiency stayed at the 1978 level-that is, the amount of energy used per dollar of gross national product-the economy would have required 93.1 quads in 1986. Accordingly, improved energy efficiency measured as the decline in energy per unit of GNP since 1978 contributed 18.8 quads to the United States economy in 1986. A quad per year equals approximately 500,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. So the application of efficiencies in automotive fuel use, building heating and cooling, home appliances and so forth improved the energy efficiency in the United States by as much as 25 per cent.

Coming to the points that Senator Stone and Senator Collins made, it is interesting to note that while United States coal production increased by 2.9 quads and nuclear power increased by 1.5 quads-a combined increase of 4.4 quads-the contribution which came from conservation was 18.8 quads. In other words, four times as much energy, effectively, was derived from conservation than was derived from the increased consumption of coal and nuclear fuel together. That is a course which has been embarked on in a major way, particularly in California, and it is a course which we need to embark on much more deliberately in Australia. Clearly, there are enormous gains to be made in going down that path, and that is the way to go.

I have mentioned briefly the greenhouse effect. There is no mention in the paper of the environmental consequences of the use of energy. Yet, around the world-it does not matter whether one looks at the United Nations environment program, the World Meteorological Office, the United States National Academy of Science, our own National Academy of Science or the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation-there is a consistent prediction that because of greenhouse warming the average global temperature will rise between 1.5 and 4.5 degrees Celsius within the next 40 to 50 years, with enormous consequences to every aspect of life. It may well be that Australian agriculture will benefit from this, but certainly there will be major shifts in the world economy which are in no way addressed in the document. They are not even mentioned.

I return to the question of Federal policy in relation to the behaviour of State electricity authorities. If one chooses electric hot water heating rather than solar hot water heating one pays the capital cost of the equipment which one uses in the home but not the capital cost of the generating equipment which the purchase of the hot water makes necessary. If, on the other hand, one purchases a solar unit, one pays the total capital cost. That capital hurdle is a considerable impediment to the use of solar energy for water heating in Australia. It comes about because the electricity authorities, which although they are public bureaucracies, are behaving just like private bureaucracies, see the expansion in the use of electricity, the increased consumption of electricity, as in their best interests. They have set tariffs in such a way as to encourage the use of electricity rather than the use of alternatives which would be a great deal more efficient. They do this by absorbing the capital cost of their generating equipment into their general tariff structure.

For a long time many people in the conservation movement have been pointing to the desirability of tariff structures in which the capital cost of generation equipment is made evident in the tariff structure. That would mean having a two-part tariff essentially the same as is used by Telecom. The greater the demand, the greater the cost of the first component. It would be a demand charge. The second part of the tariff would be a flat rate charge related to the amount of energy actually used. Interestingly, West Germany, France, Spain and several other countries have gone down that road. But the electricity authorities around Australia have resisted such a simple change in the tariff structure. Although tariffs are mentioned in the report, no considerable detail is gone into which would allow one to perceive that simple changes in tariff structure such as those outlined would lead to significant changes in energy use with considerable benefits in terms of the use of less energy, less environmental pollution and less demand on non-renewable resources.

Wind energy and all renewable forms of energy are mentioned in the report-as they are in the original Energy 2000 reports-in rather disparaging terms. Yet, an inquiry conducted in South Australia by Mr Stewart found that in that State the cost of wind generated electricity was already cheaper than the use of coal. When one looks at the capital indebtedness of the electricity authorities-I believe that some 30 per cent of Australia's indebtedness is related to the borrowings of State instrumentalities-and recognises that wind generating units are small units which can be built as demand increases, rather than large units which involve forward borrowings, followed by the sort of thing we see now in the Northern Territory where the use of electricity is subsidised to generate a cash flow to pay back those enormous capital borrowings, one sees that there are considerable economic advantages in using wind energy in terms of both overseas borrowings and the capital indebtedness which the use of electricity involves.

The report, by not dealing with these important aspects of energy use, is a totally inadequate document. To imagine that one can in any sense plan energy in the short time scale of the next 12 years is quite ridiculous. The construction time of power stations is at least 10 to 12 years. The life of cars and most other energy using equipment certainly exceeds 12 years in most instances. A much longer time frame is required. In that longer time frame considerations of depletion of non-renewable resources and the environmental consequences of using energy must be fed into the equation and the economic consequences of that fed back into economic policy at the Federal level in 1988. This document does not do that. The document is totally inadequate and I think the Government should be thoroughly ashamed of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I spent all of last Friday and most of the weekend attending a conference of the National Party in Queensland at which one of the central items under discussion was whether or not we should, as in the end we decided to do, ignore a particular politician. Without wishing to reflect on Senator Coulter in any way, I struggled to remind myself of the need for such self-restraint in the course of his remarks. I am sorely tempted to deal with some of Senator Coulter's remarks but, in the interests of putting our time in this place to better use, I shall restrain myself.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, having said that, I must say that I agreed with one aspect of Senator Coulter's remarks; namely, the intellectual slenderness-if I may call it that-of the statement put down in this place this afternoon by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook). We have in front of us a 12-page ministerial statement. To use the most kindly description possible, one would have to say that it presents the Senate with a long search through the chaff to find the occasional grain. So in that respect I would agree with Senator Coulter's remarks. I came to one such grain when I got to page 11 of the statement-which, as my colleague Senator Lewis incidentally very properly reminded us beforehand, was available to the Opposition only very shortly before delivery. I, like Senator Lewis, have had, therefore, only very limited time to examine the document and to think about it in order to frame these few remarks. As I say, on page 11 of the document I encountered what I regard as a grain, among the mostly chaff preceding it. The following statement is made:
In that context-
that is, the context of a range of options to meet the Government's energy policy objectives-
Energy 2000 is not a master plan of targets for Australia's energy industries, or a series of new and detailed policy prescriptions to 2000.

I must say that I am glad that it is not. I have the impression that a master plan of targets would be the kind of thing that might appeal to Senator Coulter. I hope I am not misrepresenting Senator Coulter because I certainly would not want to do that. Of course, I understand that he would have very different targets from those the Government would employ or which, I suggest, some industries might employ. However, my own view about that kind of approach to these questions is that they are totally destructive so far as outcomes are concerned.

One way of illustrating that is to note that in this area of policy there is-I think this must be observed-a tendency to focus upon one area of the energy spectrum-petroleum products. We get a great deal of material in this place particularly, but also in the media, about problems which people foresee or which, in some cases, they affect to foresee, coming down the track in relation to the availability of petroleum products for the world. On the one hand, we had all that stuff from the Club of Rome, for example, back in 1973 or thereabouts. That is totally discredited now but we should not forget that at that stage it was being put forward as the greatest set of projections since sliced bread. We still have that kind of approach to these questions. We have had such an approach since the nineteenth century, when the great English economist Jevons made similar projections about the adequacy of British coal supplies. We are still getting it today in relation to petroleum. We have it particularly in Australia so far as own petroleum self-sufficiency is concerned.

I do not want to go into that particular matter here this afternoon because it is not basically the point of the matter before us. But I welcome the emphasis in the Minister's statement upon the total energy spectrum. I think it is fair to say that. It simply does not make rational economic sense to concentrate all our interest upon the supply of one particular form of energy, namely petroleum-important though that source of energy is; no-one would begin to contest that, of course-when, as we are all well aware and as the Minister's statement quite properly brings out, we are talking about a whole range of energies in Australia's case. We are talking about coal. We are talking about uranium. We would talk a great deal more about uranium production if the Government, and the Australian Democrats for that matter too, would allow us. We could talk a great deal more about it if we did not have a great many restrictions on the production of uranium in this country for proper and peaceful purposes. Of course, we are talking most particularly and, I suppose, most recently today about natural gas, whether in its natural form or in its liquefied form for export purposes.

It is worth remarking-this is another grain I found in the Minister's statement-that today the production of natural gas in Australia amounts to the equivalent of 250,000 barrels of oil, compared to the present production from the Bass Strait wells of 400,000 barrels of oil. In other words, natural gas production is becoming quite significant in terms of the total energy mix in this country.

On page 5 of the Minister's statement he refers in specific terms to the fact that Australia is at present-and I think it will continue to be, particularly if we dispose of the present Government at the next election-a major energy exporter. As the Minister said in his statement, Australia is the largest exporter of coal. Of course, again one has to observe, so far as that statement is concerned, that were it not for a number of aspects of our coal industry we would be a very much bigger exporter of coal. Instead of having 25 per cent of the world coal trade, we would have an even higher proportion of the world coal trade than that.

When one comes to look at the reasons why that is not the case one finds, as one so often does when one finds problems of this kind in Australia, trade union influence and activity and depressing consequences for the industry behind that situation. We find the uncertainties of supply produced by the endemic disruptions of our ports for coal exports. That is the situation that led to the development of the term `Wran's navy' a few years ago. We find that our costs are obviously still quite competitive by international standards-although mainly because of the major devaluation of the Australian dollar in the past few years. However, notwithstanding that fact, our costs are still very much higher than they need to be. That is to say that productivity is much lower than it needs to be in many of our coal mines. Some of our coal mines are models of productive performance, particularly the great Queensland open cut coal mines. However, others are far from that.

We have in the coal industry, particularly as it applies in New South Wales, what I can only describe as the depressing influence of the Coal Industry Tribunal, which at one stage this Government was promising to disband, abolish and fold into, if you like, the depressing enough, after all, operations of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. But the Government, in the end, did not have the courage to press on with that proposal. It abandoned that particular proposal, which, if I recall correctly, was one of the few proposals I would have agreed with from the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. However, in the fact of opposition from the New South Wales coal mining unions and, no doubt, from some members in its own ranks, the Government went to water on that particular proposal also. Nevertheless, notwithstanding all these handicaps which the trade union movement in particular has placed upon our great coal industry, it is, as the Minister quite rightly says, still the world's largest exporter of coal.

The Minister also concedes-I think he must have had some hesitation about including this in his speech or, at least, approving the draft given to him by his public servants-that we are a major exporter of uranium. I make that comment because, of course, the Minister's own views on uranium before he acquired a ministerial mantle are well known and voluminously known and well and truly on the record. There can have been few more vehement opponents of the development of the Australian uranium industry then the Minister, Senator Cook-who, I note for the record, is not doing the chamber the courtesy of being present while his own ministerial statement is being discussed. I happen to think that there are some--

TALK.START.PARA: —He has missed nothing.

—Senator Ray is entitled to his opinion in that regard. I am not referring to that matter. I am referring to the question of common courtesy on the part of a Minister who has brought down a statement in this chamber but who then has run away while some senators at least pay him the courtesy of paying attention to it.
—Senator Ray meant that the Minister is listening on the speaker.

—I thank Senator Collins for that interjection to the effect that Senator Cook is listening on the squeak-box. He may well be doing so but that does not really meet the point. Let me come back to the statement that we are a major exporter of uranium. That is perfectly true. Again, all one can say is how much greater an exporter of uranium we could have been had it not been for the malevolent influences of the left wing of the Labor Party-indeed, the Labor Party more generally before it assumed some responsibilities-the environmental movement and the usual people who want to shut down the country.

SPEECH.PARA: I have recently had the benefit of speaking to some representatives of an Australian mining company, Denison Aus Pty Ltd, which is an associate of the Canadian based Denison Mines Ltd. I think Senator Tambling may have spoken about this matter in recent days when we were debating legislation, but the facts can be succinctly stated and they bear repetition because they bring out clearly the kind of situation into which this country has got itself by pandering to the kinds of interests represented by people such as Senator Coulter. We have in the Northern Territory the potential uranium mine at Koongarra. It is ready to go. Mining could begin there, basically, tomorrow. There has been meticulous preparation by the mining company and the local Aboriginal people which has resulted in full and total agreement on royalty payments and everything else that is involved in these matters. So there is no road block on that score. I understand that similar agreements have been arrived at with the Northern Land Council. Again those agreements are fully signed, sealed and delivered. The project has the full approval of the Northern Land Council, which is in favour of this mine proceeding. It has undergone a full scale environmental impact study, and that study has been subjected to investigation and review by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and his Department. That has also received the stamp of approval from the Minister, so another one of the numerous road blocks has been removed.

One might ask about markets. What is the point of opening a mine if there are no markets for this additional source of uranium? In fact, in this particular case there is a market available. The Denison company already holds firm contracts for the supply of additional uranium into the 1990s, and I am given to understand-I have no reason to doubt this information-it has a choice: it can either proceed with the Koongarra mine in the Northern Territory to satisfy these uranium contracts it has entered into or it can provide that uranium from a mine in Canada, where the uranium is equally available to it and which it already owns. We have a choice in this country as to whether this uranium will be supplied to the world for peaceful purposes-I emphasise that-from Australia or from Canada. That is the choice. It is not a small matter. If we were to proceed with this project it would bring into Australia $1.6 billion in the course of the next 10 years or so, which is roughly the life of the ore body. But nothing is happening. Nothing is happening because of the policy of the Australian Labor Party, fully supported by the Australian Democrats, that there should be only two uranium mines operating in this country. So while Senator Cook is quite correct in saying that we are a major exporter of uranium, I do put it to him that that is only half the story.

The Minister also notes that we are about to become a major exporter of liquefied natural gas (LNG). Again that is true. The North West Shelf project is finally coming to fruition and shortly we will become a major exporter of LNG. On the basis of all that, the Minister has put to the Senate some estimates, derived from the Energy 2000 document, of projected energy exports over the next 12 years, from 1989 to the year 2000. These projections are made on the basis of 1986-87 prices, set out on page 5 of his statement. The document projects total exports of more than $94 billion over that time. Although it is not altogether clear from the Minister's statement-in the time available I have not been able to find out-I take that to be a gross figure because immediately preceding those export figures the Minister talks of a favourable energy trade balance-that is, a net figure-of $60 billion over that time.
I want to conclude with some remarks relating to one final aspect of the Minister's statement. There is a reference on page 9 to the oil exploration industry, stating:
Latest industry estimates of activity for 1988 include 190 exploration wells onshore and 26 wells offshore.

Material supplied to me by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association (APEA) agrees with the Minister's statement that, in all, 216 wells are currently estimated to be drilled this year, including both onshore and offshore wells. However, what the APEA material brings out, and which I regret the Minister's statement did not, is that the figure of 216 wells to be drilled this year includes not only wells to be drilled for oil but wells to be drilled with the objective of finding natural gas. One has to say that in this respect the presentation in the Minister's statement is misleading-I take it to be inadvertently misleading, but misleading nevertheless. If we remove from the figure for total wells expected to be drilled, which in aggregate terms at least is the same figure that the Minister has used, as the totals correspond, those with gas as the only objective, the overall exploration figure for oil drilling this year shows a continued further small fall on the figure for last year, which was already down from the year before and the year before that. The figures specifically are that in 1985 202 oil exploration wells were drilled; in 1985-86 195 such wells were drilled; in 1987 that figure fell significantly to only 157 oil exploration wells drilled; and this year it is expected that only 151 such wells will be drilled.

The Australian Petroleum Exploration Association has supplied to me a point that ought to be further elucidated. In any comparison of what one might call the true level of search for new oilfields, which is what the game in the end is all about, we should focus on wildcat wells rather than on wildcat appraisal wells. The figures that I have just put into the record and which therefore are relevant to the Minister's statement relate to such wells. I am given to understand that there are wildcat wells being drilled to explore for oil only as distinct from wells being drilled for gas. Sometimes, of course, wells being drilled for gas encounter oil, but that is not the objective in the case of these figures. In 1985, 151 wildcat wells were drilled for oil exploration purposes. That figure rose to 179 in 1986. It fell very sharply last year to only 116, and there is a very slight recovery estimated for this year, to 124.

To make it quite clear that I am not trying to show that you can prove anything with statistics, there is one point that the Minister could have made in his own favour in this area. If we look at offshore wildcat wells being drilled for oil-many people would say that our offshore exploration territory is likely to be the most fruitful for oil discoveries for Australia in the period ahead-we will see a significant recovery in the number of such wells this year on the basis of present estimates. The number of such wells in 1985 was 21, and in 1986 it was 20. It fell sharply last year to nine, and it is estimated to recover this year to 24. I think that is the point of good news which the Minister might have included in his statement but which in fact he failed to include, for reasons not altogether clear to me.

I want to conclude by saying, as I think the two preceding speakers have said, that in the time which has been available to us to examine this statement we have obviously not had an appropriate opportunity to look into the detail. I have no doubt there will be future occasions in this place when we may want to refer further to these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate briefly to provide a local resident's response to some of the nonsense that was delivered about the Northern Territory during this debate, once again by Senator Coulter. Senator Coulter is perfectly correct in saying that there is enormous scope in the area of energy conservation for reducing demand for electricity. There is no question about that, and there would be few places in Australia more conscious of that, considering the cost of electricity, than the Northern Territory. There is no question at all that the energy conservation measures that have already been introduced around the world and the continuing emphasis on energy conservation have been largely responsible for the downscaling of demands for energy sources such as uranium. It has not been because of any problems within the uranium industry; it has been because of the drastic and, in my view, very welcome drop in the demand for the end product itself, that is, electricity.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, Senator Coulter then went off with the fairies, as he often does. As a Territorian, I found his remarks not only inaccurate but offensive. He condemned the Northern Territory Government for offering a subsidy to consumers on the purchase of air conditioning units, and said that that was simply an encouragement to people to purchase air conditioning units because of their high electricity demand-and they indeed consume an enormous amount of electricity. He also said twice that that was simply an attempt by the Northern Territory Government to subsidise the enormous costs of constructing the gas pipeline and establishing the new power station in Darwin.

It is very easy for someone who lives in South Australia to advance arguments like that, but those who live in the Northern Territory and know the reality of why the Northern Territory Government makes that extremely small subsidy on air conditioners find such remarks from people such as Senator Coulter, delivered with such great authority from his point of view of being some sort of scientific expert, highly offensive. The subsidy on the purchase of an air conditioner that he referred to is a very small one indeed-$50-provided that it is of a certain size and that it is brand new. It is not designed to subsidise the cost of power or to encourage the increased use of power in the Northern Territory. It is designed to make just a little more bearable the lives of people who are not on high incomes and who are living in some very unpleasant weather conditions in Darwin at certain times of the year.

When I was the Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory I had at various times a very small staff of nine people working for me. One of the major reasons that I consistently lost staff-and I have to admit that there are times of the year when Darwin is less than delightful-was the weather conditions in Darwin. We have three months of idyllic weather: we have three months of very good weather; we have three months of bad weather; and we have three months of bloody bad weather, when the place is not fit for man or beast.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come and live in Tasmania.

—Not a hope. The Northern Territory Government, to its credit, has attempted to reduce the demand on electricity by constructing public facilities, such as schools, deliberately designed without air conditioning, efforts which we at the time in opposition encouraged. Unfortunately, they did not work effectively. It is easy for Senator Coulter to say to Northern Territorians, `do not purchase air conditioners because they are dreadful consumers of electricity. Do not take up the Northern Territory Government's assistance for subsidising air conditioners because you consume too much electricity'. It is easy for him to say that while living in South Australia, but most people who have to stay at home in the Territory are women, especially if they have small kids-and we have an extremely young population in the Northern Territory, the youngest in Australia. Senator Coulter should try sitting at home without any air conditioning at all in November, December and January and see how he likes it. In my home in Darwin, like most people in Darwin, I have one air conditioner-in the bedroom. When I purchased my house it had installed in the wall a very large unit that was designed to air condition the living room and the lounge room. It has literally never been switched on since I bought the house, because I am currently paying, with one air conditioner, $440 a quarter for power. That is right. How does Senator Coulter like them apples? And $440 a quarter for power is a pretty average power bill in the Northern Territory. The reason for that is that I have an 18-month-old daughter, and in the wet season young kids particularly find the heat rather stressful. I love the Northern Territory and I have no intention of ever leaving it. If I want to purchase an air conditioner to make life a little more bearable up there for myself and my family, I will do so and I will plug it into the electricity, Senator Coulter notwithstanding.

SPEECH.PARA: I pose this question to Senator Coulter: How many people in Canberra would be happy to turn off the heating in June, July and August? Not too many. I wonder whether Senator Coulter himself lives in an unheated room. Actually, knowing Senator Coulter, he probably does. He probably pedals a bicycle to keep himself warm, attached to a generator to drive his television set. I would not doubt that for a minute. His solar panel would not do too well in Canberra, I might add, because there is not enough incidental sunlight down here to run it. I simply want to correct the record. The Northern Territory Government does not irresponsibly encourage an increase in electricity consumption in the Northern Territory, as Senator Coulter stated, purely to pay back the cost of the new power station.

I want to conclude my remarks by referring to the new power station. If the Northern Territory Government did encourage additional consumption of electricity for that purpose, then good on it. Before the Northern Territory Government constructed the new power station and connected it to an indigenous energy source-natural gas-in the ground, which produces very little pollution, I might add, we used to get things in Darwin called blackouts. Blackouts are things that people down here have not heard about for a very long time, but we used to get them on a regular basis. They were part of life in Darwin. Not a house in Darwin was not equipped with candles and alternative lighting sources. I tell honourable senators this: When there is a power blackout because the clapped-out Stokes Hill power station-the one that has been replaced by a new power station-has turbines which fall apart, and if one has small children, and it is the pre-wet season, and the temperature at 2 o'clock in the morning is 32 degrees centigrade, and the humidity is 100 per cent, and all the meat is going rotten in the fridge, and there is no fresh milk, food or anything else, Senator Coulter might find that people in fact use electricity because it makes life just a little more bearable. As a Territorian, I simply wanted to correct the record. Senator Coulter is factually incorrect. As I said, he is off with the fairies, and if he wants to contribute meaningfully to debates on subjects as important as energy, he should first do a little bit more homework.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak very briefly to correct a factual error made by Senator Collins, and by Senator Stone by way of interjection earlier. Before Senator Collins gets on his high horse and speaks with high dudgeon about other people's factual errors, I think he should correct a few factual errors of his own. In the debates about the use of uranium as an energy source and in the debate here today about the use of alternative energy sources, there have been interjections from Senator Collins and Senator Stone to the effect that we want to turn off the lights and go back to the caves-basically to turn off the technology that we already have. That is not what we are on about.

SPEECH.PARA: When Senator Collins says that we need sunlight to generate solar energy, he is factually wrong. Siddons Industries Ltd, which belonged to a former Australian Democrat senator, Senator Siddons, markets solar water heating and solar space heating which work in the dark and do not need sunlight or even a warm day. Modern alternative energy sources can produce heat and act as heat pumps in temperatures not much higher than freezing point. This is all we are advocating-not that we should put the atom back in its box, now that we have unlocked the atom. I am not suggesting that we can lock it away again and pretend that we do not know how to use nuclear energy and I am not suggesting that we go back to living in caves-there are not enough caves for us all.

I have to agree with Senator Collins. I was with a young child in Wilcannia in New South Wales and Wilcannia in the heat is pretty unlivable and unbearable. I quite well understand the value of electricity in making life more bearable not just for older people or young children, but for all of us. We were described by Senator Stone as the malevolent forces. If caring for the environment and for future generations and looking for more appropriate technology is malevolent, I am quite happy for Senator Stone to describe me, and others who support the ideas I support, as malevolent. That would mean that we are changing the definition of malevolent. If it is malevolent to want a better future and environment-if that is what malevolent means-I am quite happy to be called one of the malevolent forces.

One of the reasons that we have not gone into alternative sources of power is that one cannot sell sunshine. It cannot be bottled up and sold in a supermarket or high technology service station at dollars per gallon. When the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) talks in his statement about securing future energy, he is talking about securing future profitability for gigantic economic concerns which can afford and which profit from the sorts of centralised mass production of energy that we see at the moment. Appropriate technology which uses the sun or a heat pump to take heat from the outside to the inside or heat from the inside to the outside are the sorts of mechanisms being marketed by Siddons Industries. This is not a plug for Siddons Industries; it is a plug for alternative energy sources. By the way, the Siddons Industries solar heaters require a small amount of electricity because they operate basically on the same principle as a refrigerator.

I am not advocating that we completely and totally abolish electricity or that sort of energy source. All I am advocating is that we put the same sorts of money and resources into the research and development of alternative energy resources. Senator Coulter made the point about how inefficient the centralised production of electricity is. Senator Stone agreed with him that something like 25 per cent of the energy produced is consumed. We need the sort of alternative energy resource which can heat and cool space and heat and cool water-and other such energy uses-in a more efficient way. Had we put the same sorts of resources into the development of those technologies that have been put into the development of nuclear technology or any of the other technologies we would now have reduced substantially the requirement for the production of electricity. We would have gone some way towards producing for the future a different sort of technology.

This is the point I am making and the point I will conclude on. Senator Collins the other day, in a different debate, pleaded with us to try to find some sort of energy alternative to uranium, coal or hydrocarbon. I am suggesting that at this point in time-to use a phrase that I hate-there is no economically competitive energy source in the economic environment in which we live. We require the commitment to the environment and to future generations to make the investment now which will make nuclear energy and large-scale electricity generation obsolete. So we do not have to put the atom back in the bottle and instead use lots of fossil fuels. Alternative energy resources in the future could become more profitable than even nuclear energy or other forms of energy. It would be a sound, rational and economic decision to go for small-scale, more appropriate sorts of technology. But that requires the will now to invest in a large and consistent way in alternative energy sources.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper is a summary record of the proceedings of the Australian Environment Council meeting of November 1987 held in Perth. The Australian Environment Council is made up primarily of Ministers responsible for the environment from the Commonwealth and the States. I take this opportunity to draw attention to the presence in the President's Gallery of the Hon. Tim Moore, MP, the new New South Wales Minister for Planning and Environment, who is now a member of the Australian Environment Council. I want to say how delighted I am to have a friend and colleague in charge of environmental matters in New South Wales, where I know he will do an outstandingly good job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank Senator Collins for his support for those remarks. I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to two matters in the report. The first concerns the discussion of the establishment of a facility somewhere in the eastern States for the disposal of intractable wastes and the report on the Northern Territory proposal to establish a high temperature incineration facility in the Territory-and I am glad to see Senator Collins in the chamber at this time. The eastern States proposal is a matter of continuing discussion between the Commonwealth and the governments of New South Wales and Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The establishment in the eastern States of an appropriate facility for the disposal of intractable wastes is a most important initiative. It is something that must be undertaken and I sincerely hope that if the governments of the three parties involved can reach agreement on the location of such a facility they will all equally be prepared to make some contribution towards it, although I think the primary responsibility relating to the financial support for this undertaking must lie with the Commonwealth.

The other matter dealt with in the report is the extent to which the Ministers responsible for the environment addressed their minds to the difficulties of the protection of the ozone layer and the impact of chlorofluorocarbons on the ozone layer and the use of CFCs in the aerosol sprays.They agreed that immediate action should be taken in Australia to implement the international agreements on this matter. They are primarily the Vienna Convention and the associated Montreal Protocol, which deal with the protection of the earth's ozone layer. This is an important issue which has been debated previously in the Senate and undoubtedly it will be further debated in the future.

On behalf of the Opposition, I indicate our continuing support for the Government to move as expeditiously as possible to put into place the provisions of the Montreal Protocol. I continue to pay proper respect to the industry for the steps that it has taken in reducing the production of CFCs in Australia. Both the association which deals with the producers and the consumers of CFCs and the aerosol industry have indicated their support for the provisions of the Montreal Protocol and I think that as an industry it is taking a responsible approach to this matter.

A large number of other matters are dealt with in this summary record of proceedings. I am glad to see that in so many areas there is a clear desire on the part of the Commonwealth and the States to cooperate in particular areas of environmental management, particularly in the disposal of waste and the protection of the physical environment from pollution. The work of the Australian Environment Council is very important. I look forward to joining, in the not too distant future, my friend and colleague Mr Moore as a member of the Council and to establishing a clear majority on the Council of non-Labor Ministers, at which time a large number of the issues to which the Labor Government will not give proper attention can be dealt with in an effective and proper fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

First, I ought to indicate some distress at the extent to which Ministers were absent from what was supposed to be a meeting of Ministers responsible for nature conservation. Most of them were not at the sixteenth meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM) in Perth. The second paragraph of the report indicates that apologies were received from Mr Carr, the Minister for Planning and Environment in New South Wales; Mrs Kirner, the Minister for Conservation, Forests and Lands in Victoria; Mr Bennett, the Minister for National Parks in Tasmania-who at least was represented by the Minister for Environment, Mr Hodgman; Mr Hanrahan, the Minister for Conservation in the Northern Territory; Mr Brown, who was the Commonwealth Minister responsible for environmental matters; and Mr Jones, the Commonwealth Minister responsible for science. It was allegedly a meeting of Ministers responsible for environmental matters, but very few Ministers bothered to turn up. Perhaps one of the reasons for their not turning up was that one of the things on the agenda paper was headed `Listing of World Heritage Areas'. On this agenda item the summary record of proceedings states:
Council noted and discussed the views of the Northern Territory delegation regarding World Heritage listing of areas in Australia. Council resolved to:

Reaffirm the procedures established in Resolution 198 (1984 meeting of Council) that as a matter of principle nominations by the Commonwealth for World Heritage listing should be undertaken in consultation with the States and Territories.

I have raised previously-and my colleagues here from Tasmania and Queensland would be aware of this-the fact that in 1984 the meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers agreed to a set of procedures for the handling of World Heritage listing. Those procedures were comprehensively and thoroughly ignored by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, in proceedings for the World Heritage listing of north Queensland. In November 1987 the meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM) re-affirmed the procedures that were laid down at the 1984 CONCOM meeting.
