Since that CONCOM meeting in November 1987, Senator Richardson has repeated the process of proceeding with World Heritage listing without proper consultation with the States and Territories. Frankly, the taxpayers of Australia should be relieved of the burden of financing trips to Perth, for example, so that Commonwealth and State Ministers can meet and put down resolutions as to how they will deal with World Heritage listings, because a series of procedures was agreed on in 1984 and another meeting in 1987 re-endorsed those procedures, yet the Commonwealth Minister glibly ignored those procedures to which, as I said, he has been a party on two separate occasions.

Clearly, Senator Richardson does not take these proceedings seriously or, if he does, he simply does not take seriously the agreements that he enters into with his State colleagues to observe a particular set of procedures for handling a very difficult matter. If these meetings of Commonwealth and State officers and Ministers are to be meaningful, if they are to reach agreements and reinforce and resolve to re-affirm these procedures, only to have the Commonwealth unilaterally ignore them, I think that the people of Australia should ask exactly what the Commonwealth is doing in attending these meetings, giving assurances to the States, and then not being bound by those assurances. I think that Senator Richardson should be required to tell Parliament what his attitude is to the assurances that he has given.

We know that the Government is perfectly prepared to give assurances to its rich and unpleasant mates in the media, that it will poison the Parliament and agree to lift the television reach limit from 60 per cent to 75 per cent. Of course, it tries to at least honour that type of agreement. Having taken the money, it cannot find itself capable of delivery on its promises. Nevertheless, the Government is certainly prepared to make, and attempt to discharge, promises to its rich mates in the media; but it quite glibly breaks promises made to State Ministers around Australia. I think that is disgraceful and it is simply indicative of yet a further exposure of the Government's hypocrisy when it says that it wants to negotiate with and consult the States, that it is prepared to enter into resolutions promising consultation with the States, but as soon as the opportunity arises it ignores those promises.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Publications, Senator Brian Archer, I present the seventh report of the Publications Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present Report No. 289 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts-Advance to the Minister for Finance. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Report 289 is a review of the Advance to the Minister for Finance facility which has arisen from concerns that the Committee developed during its preparation last year of Report 286 on the final expenditure under the Advance for the financial year 1986-87. One of the Committee's statutory duties is to report to the Parliament on any alteration it thinks desirable in the mode of receipt, control, issue or payment of public moneys. It is in this regard that the Committee has examined the Advance with a view to improving its efficiency and effectiveness, and presents this report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Advance to the Minister for Finance is a central contingency fund in the annual Appropriation Acts. It allows the Minister for Finance to issue money for items which will not undergo the normal parliamentary review process prior to expenditure. Such items consist mainly of expenditures that were unforeseen at the time of the preparation of Budget and other Appropriation Bills, and which are urgently required before the next appropriations.

The Advance is a special area of government expenditure because it gives the Minister for Finance considerable discretion over expenditure without prior approval by the whole Parliament. However, the Parliament has long recognised the need for the Advance for the smooth running of the government. A certain amount of flexibility is always required. Therefore, the Parliament has developed strict procedures to ensure that the Advance is administered and used correctly, and that full details are later reported to the Parliament. The Committee is concerned that use of the Advance remains within the strict parameters laid down by the Parliament. This is a fundamental element in the role of the Parliament supervising the executive government.

The Minister for Finance is required by law to submit to the Parliament a statement of all amounts for urgent and unforseen expenditures remaining as a final charge to the Advance at the end of the financial year. The Committee has routinely examined this statement, and its precursors, as part of its statutory duties since the Committee was re-established in 1952, and duly reported to the Parliament. The Committee has also reported in the past on the general use of the Advance and has made recommendations which were adopted to improve its administration.

This report focuses again on the more general questions surrounding expenditures remaining as a final charge to the Advance. The three main concerns of the Committee are: whether the procedures for the use and reporting of the Advance are appropriate for this special area of government expenditure; whether the wording of the various Appropriation Acts with respect to the Advance is being interpreted correctly, particularly the terms `urgent' and `unforeseen'; and whether the Committee should maintain its present routine role in reviewing the Advance. The Committee draws attention to the wording of a legal opinion obtained by the Committee from the Attorney-General's Department which makes clear that there are serious doubts about the legality of the present Department of Finance guidelines for the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

It is of great concern to the Committee that a central co-ordinating authority such as the Department of Finance is issuing guidelines and approving expenditures in this way. The Committee has noted in its report that the Department of Finance has not itself sought a legal opinion on the wording and interpretation of the Appropriation Acts. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that the guidelines be revised in certain respects to ensure conformity with the law and effective scrutiny of all expenditure.

The Committee notes that other committees of the Parliament have adopted a role in scrutinising expenditure from the Advance. This Committee concludes that it should not routinely examine the Advance while it is satisfied that parliamentary scrutiny is being undertaken. At present, the terms of reference for the Senate Estimates committees include examination of the Advance.

I would like to emphasise that the Committee strongly believes that the existence and use of a contingency fund such as the Advance to the Minister for Finance is essential to the operations of government, provided that it is used strictly in accordance with the terms set out by the Parliament and that its use is subject to prompt and effective scrutiny.

The report tabled today recommends important reforms to overhaul and revitalise parliamentary scrutiny. The report is indicative of the commitment of the present Committee not to simply deal with issues on a case by case basis, but to make important recommendations which will improve the system of parliamentary scrutiny as a whole.

The Committee's specific recommendations are: use of a standard form for applying for funds from the Advance; monthly reporting of the application forms to the Parliament; and revision of Department of Finance guidelines on use of the Advance to ensure conformity with the law. I am pleased to report to the Senate that I was advised on Monday that the Department of Finance had just adopted the first of the recommendations, which was also a recommendations of this Committee in an earlier report. I look forward to the speedy adoption of the other recommendations in this report by the Department. However, I note that the Committee reported on the need for recommended changes to the guidelines. However, the Government has sought to change the law. The Committee has advised the Minister for Finance that support for the changes is conditional upon the Government supporting the only outstanding recommendation of the Committee. That recommendation called for more detailed information to be provided to the Parliament on the Government's use of the Advance. The Government's prompt response to this report emphasises the importance of the Public Accounts Committee's role in overhauling and revitalising parliamentary scrutiny in order to improve the system. The Public Accounts Committee, in a letter to the Minister for Finance following the welcome response from that Minister, said that the Committee acknowledged:

. . . that there are circumstances where inadvertence or clerical error occurs where it is appropriate that the Advance should be used. It is in this light therefore that the Committee supports the proposed amendments. However this support is conditional upon the second recommendation of the Committee being accepted.

That recommendation is to the effect that the monthly statements from the Department of Finance to the Parliament have appended applications made on the standard forms for funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance so that Parliament can see clearly for what purposes advances are applied. That refers to paper 2.18 of the report. I commend the report to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

On 15 December 1987 the Senate referred the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987 to the Committee for inquiry and report. That Bill, if enacted, will impose obligations on cash dealers to report certain transactions. It will require verification procedures to be taken when accounts are opened. It is introduced as part of a law enforcement package. This package includes the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act, the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act and the Proceeds of Crime Act.

The Committee's terms of reference raise specific issues which the Committee has considered in its report. The Committee received over 50 submissions. It held public hearings in Canberra and Sydney. It became possessed of a considerable body of material. That material was insufficient to enable it to make conclusive findings on the issues raised in the reference. On the question of the costs of the proposals in the Bill to the Government, to cash dealers and to consumers the estimates given in evidence and in submissions varied from `massive' to `not substantial'. Few submissions actually quantified the costs.

The Committee received varying submissions on the operation of the exemption conditions contained in clauses 8 and 9 of the Bill. One submission was that, because of the onerous responsibilities on financial institutions in maintaining an exemption register and the potential for discrimination, there should be no exemptions. Another called for more exemptions because it was claimed that `traceable' records of cash flow were always maintained by some organisations, such as armoured car cash carriers. The Committee found that both submissions had force.

The Committee was concerned that `blanket' reporting of transactions might swamp the Cash Transaction Reports Agency and impede the speedy analysis of information. On the other hand, exemptions might allow some people seeking to avoid the operation of the Bill to do so. The evidence as to whether the threshold of $1,000 on accounts attracting the identification verification procedures is appropriate was inconclusive. Any precise limit amounted to a matter of choice and that choice varied.

There was evidence suggesting that cash dealers should seek identification verification at the opening of all accounts because of the difficulty in monitoring accounts and blocking unverified accounts which passed the limit, rather than making use of the exceptions in clause 16 of the Bill, were it to become law. This would mean that everyone dealing with cash dealers would go through an identification procedure. Swift and efficient analysis of data by the Cash Transaction Reports Agency is essential to the Bill's effectiveness were it to become law, as would the ability of the Bill, if enacted, to yield information leading to the detection and prevention of tax evasion, money laundering and organised crime. The United States of America is the only country with a mechanism comparable to that proposed in the Bill. The evidence in respect of that was contradictory. No firm conclusions could be drawn on the basis of the evidence given about the United States model.

The Committee recommends that the operation of the Bill be reviewed after a suitable period of time-not more than three years. The Committee has recommended that this review include the economic, taxation, law enforcement and privacy implications of the Bill. On the evidence, the Bill impinges on privacy. The expected law enforcement benefits of legislation should be balanced against legislative intrusion into the privacy of individuals. The Committee believes that, after no more than three years of operation, the Bill be reviewed to ensure that such a balance has been achieved.

I thank members of the Committee, who have carried out a lot of hard and rapid work on this report. I also thank the staff, led by Bronwyn McNaughton, Stephen Argument and Kathleen Gibson. I would make a short comment on my predecessors as chairmen of the Committee. This is my first report as the Committee's Chairman-I use the term `chairman' in the sense that that term is used in standing order 36aaa (7). Senator Bolkus, my predecessor on the Committee, has now reached the exalted status of Minister of the Crown. Prior to that Senator Tate adorned the Committee as its Chairman. Therefore, my two predecessors having set that precedent, one never knows where I may end up. Senator Bolkus, as the Committee's Chairman, produced three vital reports. One dealt with the Freedom of Information Act, the second with the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act and the third with war crimes legislation. Senator Bolkus filled his position as Chairman with distinction and I am proud to be his successor. The Committee wishes him all the best in his ministerial post.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also commend the report presented by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and join the Chairman in thanking the staff for what was a particularly difficult exercise. The inquiry related to a Bill that was advanced as a tool to counter tax abuse and organised crime. Therefore, it should be seen as part of a package of Bills which the Senate has been enacting into law in recent years. This was a particularly important exercise of the Senate because clearly the Bill will be at a cost in real money terms as well as a cost in inconvenience to the community at large. I suggest that it was important to weigh the balance of claimed advantages against disadvantages in a serious considered way allowing for adequate professional and community input. The committee mechanism in the Senate has again allowed that task to take place.

SPEECH.PARA: Four principal mechanisms are included in the Bill to facilitate law enforcement. The first is the mechanism that will require cash dealers to report certain cash transactions. The second is that dealers will be required to report certain transactions where there are reasonable grounds to suspect the circumstances surrounding the transaction. The third is that the Cash Transaction Reports Bill will also require reports of certain transactions of currency into and out of Australia. Fourthly, it will require verification of identity of certain account holders.

As we now know from numerous royal commissions, organised crime tends to involve large sums of cash and often the laundering of that cash through legitimate businesses so that it reaches the ultimate beneficiary in an apparently legitimate form. I suggest, and I think it is the conclusion of the Committee, that this Bill will make such transactions more difficult to achieve without risk of the transaction coming to the attention or knowledge of the authorities. Therefore, at the very least, it will hinder the operation of criminal activity. Clearly, in recent times following the money trail has been acknowledged as an important technique in tracing crime. The method was made famous by Mr Costigan and his inquiry but what is often not appreciated is that it is also a method utilised as an effective tool by the National Crime Authority and other law enforcement agencies. Eventually, cash tends to get into a recorded transaction. It is through that method that the movement of large sums of cash can come to the attention of the authorities provided there is a mechanism to make it work. Therefore, at the least, this Bill will hinder these unlawful activities.

I have little doubt that criminals, being somewhat resourceful, will find ways of avoiding-they certainly will attempt to avoid-the provisions of the Bill but as I indicated it will at least make their efforts more difficult and, as the difficulty increases, so does the risk of detection.

I will deal briefly with the second obligation-that is, the obligation to report suspect transactions. It has been the view of some financial institutions in this country that the circumstances of transactions which are obviously suspicious have been beyond the concern or responsibility of those institutions. At the time of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union particularly, one recalls criticisms of banks facilitating organised crime by turning a blind eye-I am not suggesting that they knew of the detail of any illegality-by not asking obvious questions because of a belief that it was none of their business. This provision makes it clear that organised crime is so serious and has such an enormous social and economic cost to the community that the financial institutions must accept a new responsibility-that is, to report suspect transactions. It disappoints me that there now seems to be a need specifically to place this obligation on such institutions-an obligation which is clearly inconsistent with the principal of confidentiality in financial relationships. When I wrestled with the question of which is the greater evil I came to the conclusion, particularly after looking at the record of some financial institutions in this area, that it was necessary to place this obligation upon them. I suggest, and it is the Committee's view, that in many ways this technique is better than the Canadian voluntary alternative because at least the banker can point to a government-imposed obligation. Furthermore, it avoids the difficulty that has been experienced in Canada of bankers being concerned about making reports because of fears of a defamation action.

I will touch briefly on the third area which is covered in this Bill-that is, the requirement to report certain overseas transactions. The Government clearly facilitated organised crime in this country by abolishing the need to record certain foreign exchange transactions. To be able to monitor movement of money in and out of the country is an important tool in fighting organised crime. Therefore, I support the Committee's view that this is a step in the right direction. Obviously, there will be criminals who do not meet the requirement of declaring large sums of money which have been taken out of the country or in fact brought into the country for illegal activity. But by refusing to make a declaration consistent with the principles of this legislation they are raising the risk of their operation. In other words, this amounts to a further hindrance to their criminal activity.

Fourthly, I turn to the subject of verification. The opening of a number of accounts in a number of false names has also been recognised in many royal commissions as a tool of organised crime, particularly when one reflects on the comments made by Mr Justice Stewart in the report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. Mr Costigan, QC also made specific reference to it in his reports. Verification of accounts will make this more difficult for the criminal. That is one side of the equation and the conclusion is that the provisions of this Bill will make life more difficult for criminal activity. Therefore there is some worthwhile purpose in it.

But as I said at the outset, there is another side to this debate. Clearly, these further obligations are at a cost to law abiding citizens. At the least, the requirement to prove identity will be an irritation to members of the community. Also, the Bill will clearly be a financial cost to law abiding citizens because I for one have no doubt that the financial institutions will pass on the burden that they are obliged to take under this legislation. It is frustrating that honest citizens must bear these costs. As I have indicated, on the other side of the equation, conceptually I do not like the idea of forcing institutions to enter into a reporting obligation in relation to transactions being carried out for their clients. Nevertheless, it seems to me to be necessary. In an ideal society this type of legislation would not be necessary, but this is not an ideal society. So there are two sides of the equation. The Committee had, as I indicated at the outset, the extremely difficult task of weighing both sides and determining whether, on balance, the cost to the community outweighed the benefits or vice versa. The Committee found this particularly difficult. In fact in some ways it was an impossible task. Estimates of costs that were put to the Committee by those involved in these industries varied to extremes. Basically, the Committee found it impossible to make a reasonable calculation of costs to put to the Senate. It also found it impossible to assess, in any objective way, the likely effectiveness of the measures-that is, effectiveness beyond that which I have stated which is that they will clearly be a hindrance to organised crime.

As Senator Cooney indicated, the only precedent that we were able to look at was that of the United States of America. This precedent has not yet been adopted in any other jurisdiction. When one looks at the experience in the United States of America one must realise that anything to be drawn from the American experience is inconclusive. Therefore, the Committee felt that there was no alternative but to put the Bill into law and these requirements into practice and make another assessment after a reasonable period when costs could be determined accurately and the benefits that flowed could be calculated-in other words, whether it had proved to be effective in the task of contributing to countering organised crime. The Committee concluded that a three-year period of operation should be a sufficient period upon which the Parliament could make a better assessment. So that is what we recommend-that that further assessment be made after a period of three years.

I regret that the Committee has had to be so hesitant in its conclusions. When the Senate reads the report and hopefully the submissions put to the Committee, honourable senators will realise that on information that is currently available it is impossible to become more conclusive as to the calculation of either side of the equation. I trust that the Bill, if enacted as law, will prove worthwhile and I trust that the report will help the Senate in its deliberations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, together with the transcript of evidence, and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The history of the tabling of this report is a long saga of Government delays and backdowns. It goes back just over four years when the then Attorney-General, the present Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), introduced new regulations applying to the importation of video material. I quote Senator Evans when he outlined the Government guidelines to the Film Censorship Board:

Barriers to the importation of hard core pornography-other than child pornography, publications which incite terrorism and publications containing extreme violence and/or sexual violence-have been lifted.

At that stage the majority of people in Australia had no idea just how far Senator Evans, as Attorney-General, was prepared to go but, as the word spread, there was immense backlash and nearly 50,000 signatures on petitions were brought to the Senate alone. Many more were brought to the House of Representatives. As a result the Senate moved to set up a joint select committee to inquire into video material. By October of that year the Senate had finally resolved to set up a Senate select committee for that inquiry because the Government had refused to bring forward for debate in the House of Representatives the Senate's decision to form a joint select committee for that purpose. Once the Government realised that there was nothing it could do to stop the setting up of such a committee, it moved to set up that joint select committee and brought the Senate Select Comittee on Video Material to an end. The same terms of reference as the Senate Committee had been pursuing were passed on to the incoming committee. On 19 March 1985, the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, with Dr Klugman as its Chairman, was formed. Prior to its conclusion, the Senate Committee on Video Material brought down an interim report. The main recommendation was:

A moratorium be placed on the sale and hire of `X' rated videos in the ACT consistent with the Resolution of the Senate of 17 October 1984 as the most practical interim measure to facilitate regulation of videos throughout Australia until the Joint Committee reports.

We all know, from the history of this Committee, that that recommendation was ignored totally by the Government. During that time the Government changed its guidelines many times. It went from the guidelines to the Film Censorship Board of April 1984 to the guidelines of December 1984. The guidelines for X-rated videos in April 1984 read:
Language: No proscriptions-
in other words, anything goes-

Sex: All explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults (except those referred to under ``Refused Classification'') including explicit penetration, masturbation, ejaculation, fellatio, cunnilingus; insertion of objects in orifices; miscellaneous other sexual activities and fetishes, (e.g. urolagnia, necrophilia, coprophilia, sado-masochism).

As far as violence went, the guidelines said that explicit depictions of violence were allowed except those referred to under `Refused Classification'. They included depictions of abuse of hard drugs, which might be construed as advocacy. The X-rated category in the later guidelines of December 1984 included material which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults but did not include any depictions suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind. The guidelines, while not mentioning it, included all those fetishes contained in the earlier guidelines, but there had been a change in terms of violence. Explicit sexual violence was out altogether, but other sexual violence was moved from X to R. Because the committees' terms of reference were the same, the Joint Committee did not re-advertise for submissions and, as a result, many of the 1,717 submissions were presented on the original guidelines, which allowed sexual violence to be depicted in the X-rated category.

The Committee held public meetings in each State capital, as well as in Canberra, and held briefings in Darwin. In all, 26 public hearings were held and the Committee took 3,530 pages of evidence at public hearings. The result of the hearings and submissions was the two reports I table today. The first is the majority report and the second contains a number of minority reports. I do not want honourable senators to be fooled by the size of the second report because large areas of the majority report are duplicated in the minority report, but the Chairman wanted it that way. There are many areas in which the Committee was in total agreement. Indeed, the majority of the report was unanimous. I will mention just a few recommendations. We recommend that the classification symbols should be clearly marked not only on the jackets but also on the videos themselves and that a clear description of the classification must be displayed at every video outlet. Recommendation III states:

We recommend that the specific reasons for classifying a non-G film be displayed on the front cover of video slicks as part of the prescribed markings . . . on all posters, advertising material and trailers.

We recommend that special areas be set aside for the display of R and X videos restricted to those 18 years and over. We agreed that it should be an offence to show a minor an R-rated or X-rated film without parental consent. Recommendation XIX states:
We recommend that all video outlets including mail order outlets be registered under the Ordinance, and it be made an offence to trade without a certificate of registration.
The Committee also states:

As a condition of registration we recommend that the proprietors demonstrate a knowledge of their legal requirements under the Ordinance. Non-compliance with the legal requirements shall result in withdrawal of registration.

As regards interstate trade in X-rated videos which is being undertaken by the Australian Capital Territory presently, the Committee noted that some States are moving to close that loophole by making it an offence to be in possession of videos not legally allowed to be marketed in their State. But that practice would stop if the majority recommendation of not permitting the sale of the majority of X-rated videos were carried.

There is also general agreement on the need for a reduction in the showing of violence. Even though it may seem a minor change, a unanimous recommendation of the Committee resulted in the addition of just one word. That word tightened quite considerably the guidelines for the type of violence permitted. The Committee recommended that the current guidelines for R violence be altered. It recommended that the R violence guidelines now read:
Explicit depictions of violence, but not detailed, relished or gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty.

The word added is the word `relished'. In other words, we can no longer have depictions of people enjoying committing violence. I believe that the Committee's recommendation is a very great step forward. I sincerely hope that the Government will take up that particular recommendation.

Evidence given to the Committee regarding violence and sexual violence warned us that there were potential problems particularly in regard to the regular viewing of videos. I would like to quote Paul Wilson because he is, I suppose, one of the people that we should particularly be listening to. He is now the Deputy Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology. He appeared before the Committee to elaborate on his studies on child killing and serial killing. With a great deal of caution Dr Wilson told the Committee:

While I find no evidence that sadistic sexual pornography causes serial killing, lust killings or child killing, depending on the terms that one uses, in my own mind, and reluctantly, I have found evidence that in the killer's background there is, first of all, a preoccupation with this material, secondly, a feeling that their sexual and sadistic fantasies are fuelled by this material and, thirdly, a feeling in some cases that the material is not strong enough and that their fantasies are not satisfactorily fulfilled. Those are the only three statements at this stage that I am prepared to make. I am not drawing a cause and effect relationship, but I am fairly deeply concerned.

The Committee, therefore, chose to tighten the regulations. There was great difficulty experienced by the Committee in tightening up the further words of the guidelines on violence without eliminating many of those ordinary goodie and baddie videos that so many of us watch. The degree of violence we wanted to eliminate was very difficult to put into words. I would like to quote the former Chief Censor in evidence when she said:
I think it is easier to define pornography than violence.

The Committee simply has asked the Commonwealth Film Censorship Board to lower the level. As I have said, the Committee was in agreement on by far the majority of recommendations. However, it was when the Committee came to look at the contents of the X classification that some inconsistencies and divisions occurred within our membership. While the minority of members said that it was impossible to define pornography, the majority of the Committee, of which I was a part, agreed with the Chief Censor when she said she thought that it was easier to define pornography than it was to define violence. Consequently, we were able to clearly define pornography in the following manner:
When using the term `pornography' in this report the Committee means to speak of video material which is predominantly sexually explicit and intended primarily for the purpose of sexual arousal.

This is the same working definition description of pornography used by the Meese Committee and, essentially, that used by the Williams Committee and the Fraser Committee. We then divided pornography into three categories. Category 1 was video pornography or violent pornography. Category II was video pornography or non-violent degrading pornography. Category III was just video pornography. We said that category I or violent pornography:
. . . sanctions threatening, beating, raping, and even torturing, maiming, and killing women.
of category II we said:
. . . the material in this category, although non-violent, treats women as sexual commodities to arouse the sexual desires of its target audience.

Our Committee, as did the Meese Commission, also referred to this material as degrading in that it frequently depicts people, usually women, as existing solely for the sexual satisfaction of others in sexual practices that would be to most people considerably humiliating. We described category 3 as a:
very small category which depicts two adults participating as fully consenting equal partners in reciprocal sexual activity of a heterosexual nature in a one to one relationship . . .

This material contains little plot or character development and its intent is to arouse the sexual desires of its viewers. It is not otherwise degrading, we believe, for one particular individual as both people are equally consenting and equal partners. Social or behavioural science researchers who appeared before the Committee to give similar evidence were Professor Peter Sheehan, Professor Edward Donnerstein, Dr Paul Wilson, Professor James Check, Mr Frank Horwill, and Associate Professor James Weaver. Taken together, their evidence was to the effect that violent pornography in the media in general and category 1 video pornography in particular have marked tendencies under certain circumstances and conditions to break down inhibitions to aggression.

The breaking down of inhibitions to aggressive tendencies is not limited to category I. Evidence given to the Committee was to the effect that category II and some areas of category III are equally effective in stimulating aggressive behaviour. Professor James Check, who undertook research for the Fraser Committee on pornography and prostitution in Canada, met with members of the Joint Committee in Sydney and elaborated on his research. He found that the anti-social effects of both category I and category II pornography were the most pronounced in individuals who already possessed certain sexual aggressiveness. Moreover, he said that the data revealed that it was the frequent users of pornography who had the most striking inclinations to sexual aggressive behaviour and that the same group was also the most influenced by category II pornography. He said that the high users, those people who viewed this type of non-violent video or film at least once a month, more readily accepted the rape myths or the need to use violence against women. They were more sexually callous, more disposed to endorse adversarial sexual beliefs and more likely to report that they would rape or force on women unwanted sexual activity.

This evidence substantiates my discussions with senior officers at Scotland Yard when I was in London. I was told that there was evidence that regular viewing of R or X rated videos acted as a stimulation to those who, while they have an aggressive nature, would not normally go out and commit a violent act but who, if tipped over the edge when stimulated by these videos, would do so. We know that we can be desensitised. We know that when we are horrified by certain acts on television and later see worse acts of violence, we are not so horrified by those first acts of violence. I have cited evidence to substantiate the problems in relation to category II from just one of many witnesses. Other witnesses said they could not positively claim or were not convinced that this degrading type of pornography would cause harm. Paul Wilson, by `harm', meant criminal activity, and went on to elaborate:
The issue of whether it causes harm in other ways is an issue that I am not really particularly concerned about at this stage.

At that stage he was concerned only with criminal violence. So, as he said, he was not sure whether the category II and some of the category III pornography would indeed cause other sorts of social harm. I have not time to go in greater detail into some of the additional evidence we were given. Suffice it to say that the evidence given to the Committee at the very least led to claims such as those made by Professor Sheehan. I believe we ought to take note of what he said. He claimed in his evidence that the case against consenting non-violent pornography was not proven; however, he went on to advise that the case `is sufficiently strong . . . that some control seems advisable'. He argued:

There is no question that a lot of people are stimulated mildly or strongly by seeing sexually explicit material. When one is aroused one tends to behave as a consequence of that arousal and I think if the person is aggressive aggression will out . . . In and of itself, I do not think that sexually explicit material divorced from aggression leads to strong negative effects. Once you combine sexually explicit material with aggression you have a different kettle of fish . . .

We should consider that in conjunction with the latest survey put out by Senator Reynolds and the Office of the Status of Women concerning community attitudes to domestic violence. The survey indicates that one in five men accept the use of physical force by a man against his female partner. In other words, the survey says, 22 per cent of men believe it is all right to bash up their wives or hit them. If that is the case, we have a problem. If we believe, as I do and as Professor Sheehan has said, that if there is aggression in someone and the viewing of these videos will stimulate that aggression, we have real problems in the community. As a result of evidence given to the Committee the majority of the Committee has voted against almost all the present X-rated category being made available. I read from that part of the report:

Almost all of the current X-rated video pornography (and their R equivalents) fall within Category II. Non Violent Degrading Pornography and some in Category III. Rather than entrenching this material into the community we believe that the Commonwealth Government introduce substantive legislation to ensure that this material is refused classification for the purposes of the Commonwealth laws.

If the above recommendation were adopted it would not refuse classification to video materials which are gratuitous in regard to sexual matters to the extent that they are crude, tasteless and vulgar rather than pornographic. Nor would it apply to those video materials which include simulated dramatic depictions of sexual acts in the development and treatment (whether serious or humorous) of themes involving human sexuality which in context and intent are not pornographic. The video materials referred to in this paragraph fall within at least the scope of the current R category.

One member of the Committee who signed the majority report believed that there should be a special category for explicit sexual acts demonstrating a loving and caring relationship. Because his view was not supported by any other member of the Committee he signed the majority report, saying that X-rated videos should not simply be moved to a new category called NVE, or non-violent erotica.

The minority of the Committee who voted for retaining the present X-rated category under the new NVE heading did so in the belief that, as Dr Klugman said this morning when tabling the reports, `only where there is clear evidence of harm should we move to censorship'. They also took the view that adults should be able to read and view what they wished. There is no clear evidence that the tremendous increase in the incidence of crime, particularly crime associated with violence including violence against women, is a direct result of violence in videos, even though many researchers believe that there is some association. Nor do we have proof that the viewing of child pornography, bestiality or indeed depictions of gross cruelty directly leads to crimes in those areas. Yet those minority members do not suggest that this type of video should be allowed on the market. It is totally inconsistent to demand now positive proof that X-rated videos cause direct harm when they did not demand that same proof when they recommended the increased censorship against violence. Of course they believe in censorship; it is a matter of where to draw the line. While they may be willing to run the risk of ignoring all that evidence the Committee received, warning us of the potential harm, we the majority were not prepared to run that risk. I repeat that, on page 207 of the report, Professor Sheehan is recorded as having said:

There is no question that a lot of people are stimulated mildly or strongly by seeing sexually explicit material. When one is aroused one tends to behave as a consequence of that arousal and I think if the person is aggressive aggression will out . . .

I am satisfied that that is true, and we would be irresponsible not to act to avoid the potential problems that could result from allowing these videos to be marketed. It was for these reasons that, as Deputy Chairman, I happily signed the majority report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things that all members of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material would agree on is that the best thing about the report is that it is finished. I pay sincere tribute to the members of this Committee who served on it for its entire duration. I have been on it only since the last election and I must say that it has probably been, at a personal level, one of the most acrimonious and unpleasant experiences of my parliamentary career.

SPEECH.PARA: I intend to discuss the Committee's report in a meaningful way and to point out some of the inconsistencies and hypocrisies in some sections of the report, although I must say that I am pleased to be in a position to support most of the recommendations. I think they are valuable and should be implemented. But I cannot discuss this report in any meaningful way without talking about sex. I do warn people in the public gallery-and I am quite serious about this-that if they are going to be offended by some explicit discussion about sex, they should leave. It is absolutely impossible, and I do make this statement seriously to those in the public gallery, for me to point out some of the absurdities of this report, which will be pointed out in days to come by people who read the report, without discussing some of the definitional aspects of classifying material.

It is true to say that my own position on this matter changed dramatically in the time I was on the Committee. My own view towards sex-and I did say this on one occasion when the Committee was taking evidence-is that I view sex very largely as I view cricket. I see the two things in a very similar way, that is, I enjoy greatly playing the game but I get bored to tears watching it.

I have got no particular axe to grind at all in terms of X-classified material. I started off the exercise with a predisposition to come down very hard on X-rated material. Indeed, after listening very carefully to tedious hours of discussion, in numerous meetings of this Committee often within the same week, I realised that by taking this position I was simply wanting to impose my particular view of the world on 16 million other Australians. Having started on the Committee from a position of waiting to be persuaded but tending towards banning X-rated material, I was successfully persuaded by the arguments of both Senator Walters and Senator Harradine not to do so, because in the final analysis I just could not face the thought of getting into bed with Senator Walters and Senator Harradine. That is really what it came down to. I felt I had to make a decision and come down on one side or the other, and I chose to come down on the side of the Chairman's original report. I make that point because I want to make it clear that I do not necessarily agree with everything that is in those sections of the report to which I have put my name, but I agree with the majority of it. I do not want to inflict on the Senate a small taste of what it was like in the Committee room by engaging in acrimonious debate across the chamber with Senator Walters, who has just sniggered at that remark. It just happens to be the view I take of most things. I think there are no blacks and whites in politics or indeed in life, and that most things are shades of grey. I felt that in fairness to the public I should come down in a decisive way on one side of this argument or the other. I could not come down on the side of the report that was supported by Senator Walters and Senator Harradine, because I thought that it was an absolute travesty of an interpretation of the evidence that had been placed before the Committee, although I did have disagreements with some of the emphasis that was also placed in the Chairman's report-and I stress that it was only the emphasis, not the substance. I simply want to put a caveat on it by saying that the substance of the Chairman's report, which has now become the minority report--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about David Charles?
—I will get to David Charles in a minute.
—Well, he signed our report.

—Is that an indication from Senator Walters's tiny mind that she has some feeling that, because we are members of the Australian Labor Party, we all have the same views on every issue and that some political bonus point can be made from the fact that two Labor members of the Committee, not just one, signed the report to which Senator Walters has just spoken? I do not quite see it in that light. This is an acrimonious and divisive debate in the community. One of the positive things that I guess we could say about this report is that the inconsistencies within the report itself and the acrimonious debate that took place on the Committee are simply a reflection of what is going on in the broader community on this highly controversial subject. My position certainly did change. I am perfectly happy to advise the Senate as to why it did.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to make some comment about the dissenting reports which are contained in volume two. On page 307 of the minority report of the Committee, the Hon. Evan Adermann, Mr David Charles, Mary Crawford, Brian Harradine and Shirley Walters said:
We strongly oppose the introduction of this new category-
that is NVE-
as it entrenches pornographic video material in the community under the misleading title of NVE.

I take exception to that. There is nothing misleading about the title. That particular category deals with material which is non-violent erotica. That is what the letters stand for. It is unquestionably erotic and it is certainly non-violent. All violent erotica has been totally banned and refused classification in this country for some years. But I am willing to concede-and this is where the debate falls down in the community-that there is widespread misunderstanding about that. It was only a matter of a few months ago, when the Western Australian Government introduced legislation to make it an offence to possess an X-rated video, that the West Australian newspaper, in its leader, said in thundering tones, `We support the Government. What a relief it will be to see such dreadful things as bestiality and child pornography off the shelves'. Of course, that material has been totally banned from import into Australia and refused classification for years. Yet people still have this misconception that that is contained in X-rated material. It is no wonder we get the results we do from public opinion polls, when editorial writers in leading newspapers in the country have the same misunderstanding. That is the reason that the majority of the Committee recommended that a new category be established, called NVE, to precisely define the material that was contained within it.

With respect to Mr Jull, his dissenting report on page 309 is a total absurdity, but is valuable in that it points up the problem with this entire debate. Mr Jull agreed to provide for a category of NVE, non-violent erotica, provided it depicted explicit sexual acts only in a loving caring situation. One actually has to see the pornography, one has to watch it, to realise what an absurd position that is to take. He believes it is perfectly all right to sit there and watch on the screen people performing fellatio and cunnilingus, the full hard-core porn bit, provided they are in a loving and caring situation, in other words, they are both wearing wedding rings and there is a framed copy of their marriage certificate on the wall within shot at all times. I can tell honourable senators that that reflects the tenor of the debate that resulted in that recommendation. It points out the absurdity of these dividing lines that we try to draw in determining what 16 million Australians will see, hear or read.

I now get on to the dissenting report of David Charles and Mary Crawford, which, I confess, I did not read until the printed report came down. That did not reflect any lack of diligence on my part; it simply reflected the dreadful trouble that we had in trying to meet the deadlines that were set by the extension of time that we had. That dissenting report states:
The dissenting material as presented by the Chairman-
Dr Dick Klugman-
lacks argument, logic and he has presented a totally one-sided view point, having little regard for the evidence presented to the Committee.

I have no hesitation, and I said this to David Charles last night, in saying that I consider that particular quote-to use material and language that are familiar to members of the Committee-to be crude, tasteless, vulgar, violent and certainly gratuitous. I intend to demonstrate just what I mean by that. It is also wildly inaccurate and unjustified. I turn to page 185 of volume one, which contains what has now become the majority chapter, headed ``Likely Effects'' of Video Material'. This is the most important chapter in both the majority and the minority reports. Everything flows from it. It is the chapter that deals with the effects of this material on people. Clearly, if we consider that there are effects, that warrants taking some action. If we consider there are no effects, that warrants not taking any action. The difficulty that I have with the majority report, largely drafted by Senator Harradine-and I again pay very sincere tribute to the amount of effort and work that he put into this-is what is said in paragraph 13.8, which states:

The Committee notes that frequent public statements have been made by publicists and other demanding an unreasonable standard of proof before acknowledging the harmful effects of violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene video materials.

That sets the stage for the rest of this chapter, because although in my view, the majority has stuck pretty closely to the evidence for all of the pages devoted to violence, when we get into that section of chapter 13 dealing with the effects of sexual material, the further the chapter goes, the further away from the evidence it gets-until finally, in respect of dealing with what the majority report classified as category III sexual material, that is, happy sex, consenting sex, there is absolutely no evidence whatever of any substance that would support a recommendation to have it banned.

Senator Zakharov is going to deal with chapter 13 so I will not dwell on it at length. It quotes reams and reams of psychologists' reports. I read them all and was able to have the experience of hearing some evidence given by psychologists. It is fair to say that in a general sense I was impressed with very little of it because once we get into that esoteric area of setting up tiny studies on 200 or 300 people, exposing them to particular material, asking them about their attitudes towards marriage and violence towards women, immediately after they see the material, then drawing a result that will be applied in this case to 16 million Australians we get into tiger country on both sides of the argument, both for and against. But there is a great concentration in the majority chapter 13 on that. Senator Walters quoted Paul Wilson from volume 1 of the report. She did what is done all the time by people who are trying to create a case when there is not one. She quoted only half of what he said-not only just half of what he said but half of what is contained in the report. I would like to read the rest of it, which appears on page 194. She quoted Dr Wilson's statement:

. . . while I find no evidence that sadistic sexual pornography causes serial killing, lust killing or child killing, depending on the terms that one uses, in my own mind, and reluctantly, I have found evidence that in the killer's background there is, first of all, a preoccupation with this material . . .
He then went on to say:

Again I say `reluctantly' because my basic philosophical position has always been one of allowing adults to read what they want in private, or, more relevantly, to view what they want; I believe there is a strong case for censoring material which combines sex and sadism, even though I am at the same time concerned about what effect that censoring will have on opening up a black market.
By reading chapter 13 one will find a great deal of material that I agree with.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you--

—The honourable senator will get his turn next. That is the effect of violent sex or violence on people. But that material has been banned totally for years. The misapprehensions in the community that already exist are very easily played upon by people who want to continue to create the impression that that material is contained in the current X category and is freely available. Volume 2 at page 512 nails down the great hole in most of the psychological evidence that has been presented by the majority in support of its recommendations. I will quote from paragraph 14.5:

SPEECH.PARA: What became clear to us was the flexible use of data, both statistical and of a research nature, by protagonists of both the harmful and `unproven-harm' points of view. The interchangeable use of material, often taken out of context, made us particularly wary of accepting the conclusions of the research.

I fully concur with that statement. That is certainly one of the reasons why I opted to support this part of the report instead of the majority report. Donnerstein is a researcher who comes in for a great deal of quotation in the majority chapter 13. It is very interesting to refer to what Dr Edward Donnerstein said. I will quote from section 14.10 on page 514 of volume 2:

Dr Edward Donnerstein, Professor of Communication, Center for Communication Research, University of Wisconsin, USA, told the Committee that in his recent research using video material and viewing the films in their entirety:

. . . it turns out, of the R rated material which we used not one of those films would be allowed in Australia and if they were, most of the material, and in fact from what I understand all of the material which would have produced any effect, would have been censored out. None of the X rated violent material which we used in our research which produced certain types of effects, would be allowed in Australia or any other country than I am aware of.
He went on to say:

. . . the sexually explicit X [American] rated material of a very popular nature-films such as ``Debbie Does Dallas'', ``The Other Side of Julie'', ``Inside Jennifer Wells'' and other titles which I cannot remember at the present moment-which do not contain physical violence, did not produce any effects whatsoever.
Nevertheless, Dr Donnerstein is quoted with approval in much of the majority report.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, in respect of category one. Be fair.

—I think the Senate is getting just a taste of what it was like to be locked up in that Committee room. Let us look at the recommendations in volume 1. This is where we really see the absurd position that some members of this Committee put themselves in. Senator Walters said that the one recommendation that was made by this Committee in respect of violence `might seem like a small thing'. Indeed, it is a very small thing. The majority of the hypocrisy which has been attached to chapter 13, the majority section of the report, is that although there is a total preoccupation with giving lip service to concerns about violence-and the majority of all the psychological evidence that was presented was related to the harmful effects of violence, not `happy' sex-practically nothing was done about it by the Committee. That is the nub of the hypocrisy of the entire argument-and always has been. We came down like a tonne of bricks on sex but although we expressed our great concern about violence in the majority report we did practically nothing about it. We banned the sex but category R is still on the shelves.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to point out how much it is still on the shelves. I will quote from the majority response-Senator Harradine's and Senator Walters's response-to the proposal contained in recommendation II; that is, that a category of non-violent erotica (NVE) be provided which contains that material currently defined in the existing category X. This is what they said:

We, the majority of the Committee, strongly oppose that proposition. It would entrench X-rated video pornography (described officially as `hard core pornography'-see paragraph 3.40) in the community under the guise of the misleading title of NVE.
5. If the above recommendation were adopted-
that is, the majority's recommendation-

it would not refuse classification to video materials which are gratuitous in regard to sexual matters to the extent that they are crude, tasteless and vulgar, rather than pornographic. Nor would it apply to those video materials which include simulated dramatic depictions of sexual acts in the development and treatment (whether serious or humorous) of themes involving human sexuality which in context and intent are not pornographic. The video materials referred to in this paragraph fall within at least the scope of the current R category.

When we look at the material and the position that the Film Censorship Board would have to take on that piece of gobbledegook, we can understand the hypocrisy of this argument. The honourable senators in the majority report are perfectly happy to allow simulated sex if it is vulgar, tasteless or crude-that is all right-because they were not prepared to bite the bullet and say, `We are going to ban R as well'. There would be a scream right around Australia if they did. They did not want that, so R is still okay. There is a problem. I have seen a lot of R-rated movies with simulated sex. There are, as Senator Harradine knows, quite a lot of X-rated movies around that are reclassified as R. I would say, without fear of contradiction, that the Film Censorship Board, based on that stupid definition, would have no choice--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are pornographic.
—In whose view? When does simulated sex not become pornographic? What a nonsensical argument.
—I will deal with that.

—The honourable senator can try. Debbie Does Dallas, or what should more accurately be called `Dallas Does Debbie', is a classic pornographic film. It is an X-rated film and also an R-rated film. What is the difference between the X and R? In a word-genitalia. That is the difference. To expand a little, the X-rated version has genitalia, the interesting bits, in a state of sexual arousal, while in the R-rated version, of course, the genitalia are obscured by a knee, a hand, a page, or a pot-plant or whatever. But there is absolutely no doubt about what the actors are doing: one is not under the impression that they are playing chess, tiddlywinks or backgammon. It is very obvious what they are doing, but one cannot see the interesting bits, the genitalia. So, what the Committee is saying is `off with their `X' ', that provided they are legally castrated it is okay to watch the film.

SPEECH.PARA: The amazing thing about this position is that chapter 13 of the majority report makes out a great case against citizens of this country watching X-rated movies because they may be totally corrupted, but it is okay to watch depictions that are simulated, vulgar and tasteless-the majority Committee's own words. So apparently we are strangley depraved and corrupted by the sight of genitalia. That is an extraordinary proposition, and it will result in this section of the report being roundly condemned and laughed at right around this country. `Off with their ``X'',' says Senator Harradine, `you can't see their genitalia; if you do you will be depraved and corrupted'. However, a person can sit there and watch, as I have done, endless depictions of simulated explicit sex and, apparently, that does not hurt a person at all.

Further, we all have the overriding concern about access of children to this material. I will tell the Senate this, and it is an honest view: I do not want my eight-year-old son to see X-rated movies or R-rated movies, but if, in a hypothetical situation, he had to be exposed for some reason to one or other of these type of movies, I would much prefer him to see Debbie Does Dallas than Blood Sucking Freaks, I Spit on Your Grave, or The Texas Chainsaw Massacre. But of course that material will still be on the shelves. I would have a far easier time explaining the facts of life to him after he had watched Debbie Does Dallas than I would after he had seen Blood Sucking Freaks, I can tell the Senate that-and that is where the hypocrisy comes into this argument.

Despite all the cant in the majority report about violence and the Committee's concern about it, as I have said, the majority of all the psychological evidence was in fact to the effect that it is the violent movies that cause these undesirable effects. That was Dr Wilson's position. He referred to sadistic sex, not happy sex. In fact, I am sure that he would be insulted and very defensive indeed if he knew that he was being misinterpreted in this way. Of course, in the course of the Committee's deliberations I tried to point this out.

The reason for my involvement with this mater is that it became an issue in the Northern Territory when I was a member of the Northern Territory Parliament. I raised this matter in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly: a laissez-faire attitude had developed in the Northern Territory and X-rated material was freely available in supermarkets and at service stations, and something had to be done about it. I took a very simple position on it: if we are going to be just as concerned about violence as we are about sex we should do more about the matter than just give it lip-service-which is what this majority report does. The law says that one cannot have access to R-rated material unless one is 18 years of age or over, and the law in the Northern Territory says that one cannot have access to X-rated material unless one is 18 or over.

I thought it made a lot of sense to treat both categories in exactly the same way, to insist that only registered outlets hire these movies and that they provide a restricted area for them, with a big sign outside saying that people could not enter unless they were 18. That is the law in the Northern Territory. I approached the Northern Territory's then Chief Minister, Ian Tuxworth, and got his complete approval for the proposition. In fact, I said to Mr Tuxworth that I would much prefer the Government to introduce the measure and that we would support it. That is exactly what happened. The video retailers, of course, screamed their heads off, because they had to install these special areas. Although the legislation was passed, it was put on hold for 12 months until the retailers got their act together.

We also provided an alternative for people in the Northern Territory-which we have done in this report as well: instead of those facilities being provided, the slicks of restricted videos can be made available to people at the counter but only people 18 years or over. The Northern Territory is currently the only place in Australia where R-rated and X-rated videos are treated in exactly the same way-and I am proud of the fact that I was responsible for that. In the Northern Territory we have given more than lip-service to our concerns about violence rather than simply those about sex.

Most of the recommendations in the report are good and sensible. The report has a considerable amount of value. Most of the recommendations in it are supportable, and I want to see them implemented. The moves that have been made by the Northern Territory Government, as I have just outlined, have resulted in a great deal of control and restriction of this industry. We are all concerned mainly about the potential access by children to this material. That has resulted in a recommendation in this report that reflects precisely the situation in the Northern Territory. We have recommended that both the new category of NVE and R-rated be placed in similar restricted facilities, that they both be treated in exactly the same way. I commend that recommendation to the Senate. I hope that it will be adopted in any State jurisdiction that decides to adopt the majority report or the minority report or a version of both reports of the Committee.

I conclude by saying that it has been a difficult exercise even to get to the point of being able to present this report to Parliament. An enormous amount of effort has gone into it and sincere concern has been expressed by all members of the Committee, irrespective of their points of view. I must pay a tribute to them and I particularly pay a tribute to the long-suffering staff who assisted the Committee. I refer especially to Jane Vincent and Rosemary Brissendon for putting up with us for the length of time that they did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, I rise also to add my remarks to this debate. The Chairman in his acknowledgments has duly expressed the thanks of the Committee to all those who contributed to and assisted the Committee in its inquiry. As one who joined the Committee only in October last year when it was reappointed after the 1987 Federal election, I want to add my personal thanks in particular to our secretary, Jane Vincent, and our research officer, Rosemary Brissendon. It was a very difficult Committee on which to serve, and my personal thanks go to them for their efficient, sensitive and good humoured assistance at all times.

SPEECH.PARA: The original Joint Select Committee on Video Material was formed on 19 March 1985. It then had nine members, eight of whom formed part of the 11-member Committee responsible for the report that has been tabled today. As stated in the preface to the report, the report was extremely difficult to prepare because of basic philosophical disagreements among Committee members. These were not on political party lines, and many sections of the report are accepted or deleted by varying six to five majorities. The issues are extremely complex and do not lead to an easy consensus.

In fact, there are two reports. They are included in two volumes, totalling 829 pages, and there are additional charts, which I believe should have been included in a pocket at the end of the second volume, but that was not possible because of our time constrictions. Volume 1 is the majority report. It includes recommendations voted on by varying majorities of six to five-but on occasions in opposite directions-and that has led to contradictions within this report. Volume 2 is the major dissenting report, and largely corresponds to the original draft of the Chairman of the earlier Committee. The majority report also contains a significant proportion of the original Chairman's draft.

In addition, there is dissent from recommendation I by five of the six Committee members who support the majority report; a dissent from recommendation II by the sixth member in support of the majority report; a further dissent from recommendation XV by one member; a further general dissent by two other members; and a further qualifying comment from one other member-all these supporting the majority report.

I think that that demonstrates to the Senate the problems and divisions among members of the Committee. After much deliberation, consultation and heart searching, I chose to support the major dissenting report, together with the Chairman and three other Committee members. The philosophical differences in the views of the 11 Committee members no doubt reflect only some of the philosophical differences among members of the community. There has already been some insight into that in this debate.

The terms of reference refer to `violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene material'. One of the fundamental differences among Committee members was the definition of the word `pornography'. Those members who supported the majority report tended towards the view that all sexually explicit material is pornographic and thus to be condemned and perhaps banned. The members who supported the major dissenting report were unable to come to such a simplistic solution, believe that one person's pornography is another's erotica; in other words, pornography means different things to different people. These differences can be found in chapter 3 of both volumes.

It is not only this Committee which has had a problem with the perception of the meanings of definitions because so, too, did the Committee which produced the report of the Attorney-General's Commission on Pornography by the United States Department of Justice, also known as the Meese Commission, which reported in July 1986. Page 350 of our Select Committee's report states:
With regard to the word `obscenity' the Meese Commission found it difficult because `obscenity' need not necessarily suggest anything about sex at all. They said:

Those who would condemn a war as ``obscene'' are not misusing the English language, nor are those who would describe as ``obscene'' the number of people killed by intoxicated drivers. Given this usage, the designation of certain sexually explicit material as ``obscene'' involves a judgment of moral condemnation, a judgment that has led for close to two hundred years to legal condemnation as well.

The Committee's conclusions and recommendations are contained in chapter 17 of the majority report and chapter 18 of the major dissenting report, and they are substantially the same. Both reports recommend that a new category, non-violent erotica (NVE), be instituted; and both reports recommend that the new NVE category should contain material as defined in the current X classification. However, I add here that the majority report Committee members added the following note to its recommendation:
The Committee draws attention to the fact that the majority of the Committee disagrees with the proposal contained in this Recommendation-
that is, Recommendation No. 2-
and abstained from voting on it in the light of certain procedural constraints. Their response and recommendation are set out at the conclusion of this chapter.

I also note at this point that some of those who made submissions or gave evidence-and I believe also, alas, some parliamentarians-are not aware of the difference between the current X and R rated videos or what is refused classification. I believe that the confusion is compounded by the different definitions of X which prevail in the United Kingdom and the United States of America. In this regard, page 506 of the report states:
As the South Australian Classification of Publications Board in its submission noted:

The decision in the Eastern States to call the class of videotape beyond the R classification, ``X'', was unfortunate in that this term is used in the U.S.A. and U.K. where it includes what are known as video nasties, a generic term for material including child pornography and sexual violence of the worst kind. The public assumed that X rated material in Australia was synonymous with the X rated material constantly mentioned in news items from abroad and this fed the campaign to have X rated material banned.

I refer to page 723 of the report and appendix 5, which is headed `Film Censorship Board, Attorney-General's Department, Guidelines for Classification of Videotapes/Discs for Sale/Hire December 1984, where the various categories are defined as follows:
X Extra-restricted (18 years and over)
Material which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, but does not include any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind.
R Restricted (18 years and over)
Adult material which is considered likely to be possibly harmful to those under 18 years and possibly offensive to some sections of the adult community.
Language: May be sexually explicit and/or assaultive.
Sex: Implied, obscured or simulated depictions of sexual activity; depictions of sexual violence only to the extent that they are discreet, not gratuitous and not exploitative.
Violence: Explicit depictions of violence, but not detailed and gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty.
Refused Classification
Sex: Child pornography, bestiality.
Violence: Detailed and gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty; explicit or gratuitous depictions of sexual violence against non-consenting persons.
That category also includes terrorist type weapons and acts, and the abuse of hard drugs. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to clarify an answer to a question from Senator Hamer during Question Time today.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time I replied to a question and said, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: The War Crimes Act 1945 applies to all persons in allied or axis forces and covers the types of conduct proposed to be proscribed in the War Crimes Amendment Bill.

That answer is inaccurate in that the War Crimes Act 1945 applies only to a person who has committed a war crime against an Australian resident or, by virtue of section 12, `against a British subject or citizens of any power allied or associated with His Majesty in any war'. So there is a significant difference between the statute and the proposed Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.29 to 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the sitting was suspended, I was quoting the guidelines for classifications for videotapes for sale or hire as put out by the Attorney-General's Department and used by the Film Censorship Board. I had quoted the definition for X-classified videos and R-classified videos. I am sure that honourable senators will have noticed that, whereas X-rated material is described as `material which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults but does not include any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind', R-rated material, on the other hand, can have sexual depictions within it and also depictions of violence. Therefore, in common with many other people, I am sure, I see more potential for harm in R-rated videos, which contain depictions of violence, than in X-rated videos, which include explicit depictions of sexual acts between consenting adults.

SPEECH.PARA: Whereas it is possible to find some R-rated films which have a good story line and can be quite exciting, whether based on fact or fiction, the level of the X-rated videos, and certainly the ones I saw in relation to the Committee, would appear to me to be abysmal, entirely lacking in taste and thoroughly boring. Bearing these facts in mind, I commend the recommendations both of the majority and of the dissenting reports that the NVE classification, the non-violent erotica classification which we recommend, and the R-rated videos be given equal and restricted status. It is my opinion that these recommendations will be welcomed by those in the community who are particularly concerned about explicit video violence. At present X-rated material-that is, our recommended non-violent erotica-is classified above violence; that is, with or without sexual implications.

The Joint Select Committee report recommends equal classification with equal and considerable restrictions. It is a recommendation of both reports that all R-rated and NVE-rated material be not displayed for sale or hire at a retail outlet alongside videos of G, PG and M categories.
