NVE- and R-rated videos are recommended to be displayed in a separate room, access to which would be restricted to those who are over the age of 18 or, if this is not possible, they could be made available in catalogues at the counter and again only to those over the age of 18.

The Committee also recommends that these recommendations should also be present so far as films in hard top cinemas are concerned. I am sure that everyone is aware that these days there can be more than one cinema theatre in a complex. One may take a child along to see a PG- or G-rated film or perhaps an M-rated show and be confronted with material promoting R-rated films. We recommend that this should not be the case. In other words, we recommend that minors and adults should be protected from this sort of promotional material being flaunted before them. Those under 18 would be further protected by recommendations that would prevent a videotape having a trailer of higher classification than the feature on the same tape, and also by its being an offence to show a minor an R- or NVE-rated video without the consent of parent or guardian.

Other recommendations that will, I am sure, be welcomed relate to the consumer knowing for sure before hire or sale of a video the exact classification of that video, what it denotes and the reasons for the classification. Such information would have to be on the video container and, where possible, also on the video cassette itself.

The Committee's discussions ranged far and wide. Its report is lengthy and sections of it are very different in both volumes. I refer particularly to chapter 3, relating to the problem of definition, violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene material; chapter 13 in the minority report, relating to video content and classification; chapter 14, harm and video material and chapter 15, concerning access of minors. Those chapters in the minority report, the dissenting report, are quite different from the corresponding chapters in the majority report. That is where the main philosophical differences lie.

The issue of control of video materials is vexed. It is a question of what line to draw, where to draw it, how to police availability and how to put in place controls without creating a flourishing racket for criminals in the distribution of elicit materials. The problem is that one cannot legislate for morality. Evils are not eliminated by passing laws against them. The evidence seems to be that they are only driven underground and made more susceptible to criminal exploitation. I am also concerned that we avoid the trap of treating a symptom as though it were the problem. Violence, sexual exploitation and deviant sexual behaviour are problems in our society. Violent videos certainly are available. The Committee's recommendations would mean that violent videos would no longer be accessible to those under the age of 18.

I suspect that the causes of violence and sexual crimes are more deep-seated and that they may be connected with a lack of really deep and genuinely intimate relationships; with our inability to cope with leisure time in constructive and creative ways; with a dominant ethos of violence in the way we treat our fellow human beings so often in the rat race and also in our environment; with a strong emphasis on the individual's greeds as against the community needs; with the individual's presumed right to gratification of all desires; with the lack of adherence to fundamental moral principles; and with a sense of alienation arising from meaningless work and social deprivation-and no doubt many other factors too. These are matters which, alas, cannot be put to rights by the prevention of access to certain types of videos.
I would like to conclude my remarks by reading point 4 of the introduction to the minority report. It states:

The dissenting Report takes a critical look at the evidence and it does not come to `simplistic solutions': as H. L. Meancken put it, `to every complex problem there is a simple solution and it is always wrong.'
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I deal with the statements that have been made in this debate today, particularly those of Senator Collins-I hope he stays for the rebuttal I intend to make of his remarks-I simply want to say that the minority recommendation of the Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material that there be a new non-violent erotica (NVE) category which would contain all existing X-rated material will give John Cain a great big headache. The Victorian legislation, the Films (Classification) Act, provides that in the event of a new classification being accepted by the Australian Capital Territory's Classification of Publications Ordinance it will automatically have effect in Victoria. Currently X-rated material is banned in Victoria and if the recommendation by Dr Klugman, Senator Collins, Senator Jenkins and Senator Zakharov is adopted it will mean that this X-rated material will automatically go into Victoria. I suggest that that will, in no sense, get off the ground. What Premier in his right mind would want the type of material which is contained in the X classification distributed in Victoria on the eve of an election?

SPEECH.PARA: I might say that this type of material has been covered up by the minority report. Nowhere in this document-in the Chairman's draft which is included in volume 2 of the report-will one see a complete and accurate description of what is contained in X-rated material. I will read it so that honourable senators can hear the bland statement that is made. Paragraph 5.32 describes X-rated material as:
Material which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, but does not include any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind.

Publicly stated it sounds very bland. If one looks at the majority report one will see that it does include a description of X-rated material and has used words which the Film Censorship Board submitted to the Committee in evidence to it. I suggest, as Senator Collins did, that the galleries be cleared if people are not prepared for the type of description that will take place here. I suggest that they remove themselves now.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are about five kids up there.

—I do not know who is up there. I ask honourable senators to compare paragraph 5.32 of the Chairman's draft with paragraph 5.33 of the majority report. Who is trying to hoodwink whom? Who is trying to say that the material is harmless and does not involve certain explicit acts which include anal insertion, homosexual acts and all the rest of it. This is the material that will go into Victoria on the eve of an election. I am sure Mr Cain would love that! The majority report attempted to describe in proper terms for honourable senators precisely what X-rated material and pornographic material portrayed. I will come to that in a moment but first let me digress.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins said that he wanted to tell the Senate that he had changed his mind from being opposed to X to now being for it. Why? Because of the arguments of Senator Walters and myself. I read the following quote:

There are members on this side of the Assembly-and they will be free to say so-who want to see X-rated videos banned completely in the Northern Territory. I am sure there are members on the opposite side of the Assembly who also have that view. That does not happen to be my personal view. Other suggestions have been made that perhaps the X criterion classification should be narrowed simply to make it more difficult for videos to get that kind of classification. I do not agree with that either because I think you can really get into some very esoteric arguments about the fine lines that are to be drawn between these classifications as they now stand.

Who said that? It was Senator Bob Collins in a debate on the legislation in the Northern Territory on 6 March 1985. He then launched into what I believe was a most unfair and unjust attack on members of the Committee. He accused them of hypocrisy and stated that the majority report contained a travesty of interpretation of evidence. Yet later in his speech, in an attempt to discredit Senator Shirley Walters, he quoted the full text of what the Committee's majority report said was the evidence given by Dr Paul Wilson. He quoted from our majority report against Senator Walters. I think I would agree with him in quoting against it, but what Senator Walters was doing, as I recall her speech, was referring to Dr Wilson in respect of violence and not in respect of pornography without violence. Nevertheless, Senator Collins used our majority report. I was trying to say at that stage, `Isn't our majority report fair? Aren't we giving a balanced view of what the evidence that has been given to us is?'. Certainly, we did so then and we did so in respect of the other evidence to which we referred.

Senator Collins then started to attack Mr Jull, Mr Charles and Mrs Crawford for what they said about the Chairman's draft-that it was one-sided. I notice that Senator Collins himself said that he did not agree with everything that was in the Chairman's draft, which is now contained in volume 2. That is very significant. Mr Acting Deputy President, you know as well as I do that when members of parliament go into committees they attempt to reach a consensus on particular matters. That is what the majority of Committee members attempted to do in this case. There are a number of things in the majority report which the majority, on balance, would have preferred to have not seen in the report, but because they were in the Chairman's draft we went along with them in the hope that we would get some sort of consensus. We did not know and we were not told that, ultimately, the Chairman would put all his draft, in bulk, in the report. As far as I can recall, it is unprecedented for any committee to agree to 85 per cent of the chairman's draft and include it in the majority report and the Chairman then to put in a minority report including the whole lot. That is intransigence and an abominable waste of money. Each volume of the Committee's report costs $70. TALK.START.PARA: —The supporting arguments were totally different.
—If Senator Zakharov is thinking of chapter 13 or chapter 14, as an example, why did the Chairman not just put chapter 13 and chapter 14 in without all the rest?
—There was a chapter on definitions and a chapter on children.

—Sure. He could have put those chapters in and left out the bulk of it. Let me outline some of the differences between what is contained in the majority report and what is contained in the minority report, because it is important. I invite honourable senators to refer to the documents which, I hope, are before them. Paragraph 2.9 at page 15 of the majority report deals with the history of the legislation. It deals with material available to the Committee which showed that over a 15-year period, starting in 1973, the laws of this country in regard to pornography have been deliberately flouted in order to give effect to a policy decision announced by the then Attorney-General in 1973. If that is not significant for a committee to unearth, I do not know what is. Legislation of this Parliament was ignored by Executive decisions which required officers of the Commonwealth Public Service to direct their Customs officers to turn a blind eye to breach of the law.
—No, to concentrate on more important matters like illicit drugs.

—That is contained in the material that is before you, Mr Acting Deputy President. In case there is any misunderstanding about what was meant by this-for Senator Zakharov's benefit-let us look at what page 17 says. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The document raised for consideration-
the document prepared for the then Attorney-General-
the question of whether the policy announced by the Attorney-General should be brought fully and immediately into effect or by stages.
The Attorney-General's Department document stated:
You would need to have regard to repercussions in the electorate; the Australian public is notoriously conservative, whatever its political affiliations.

The Government's policy might best be achieved by a strategy of hastening slowly-gradually broadening the standards of imported material so that public opinion can be developed to embrace the principles embodied in the policy.
In immediate practical terms the greatest hindrance to radical change could be the Senate, which may disallow any amending regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you make it clear that that was a departmental minute?
—Yes; it is in the document, Senator. The report continued:

SPEECH.PARA: In the event the policy was given effect to, not by amendments to legislation but by administrative direction.

I think that a lot of people around the place have been breaking the law and I wonder what the Government intends to do about it. There has been a consistent, continuous attempt to undermine the laws of this Commonwealth in regard to Customs under directions from on high. Of course, one does not see one word of that in the minority report.

There is a difference between the majority report and the minority report in respect of the term `pornography'. The minority report appears to indicate that it is impossible to come to an understanding of that term, that it is subjective. That view is expressed in dismissive statements such as, `What turns you on may not turn me on'. The majority report stated in paragraph 3.50:

Any perceived difference of view over the meaning of the term `pornography' based on that subjective approach denies the possibility of a clearly identifiable reality corresponding to the term `pornography' which would be capable of reasonable understanding by both sexes, young and old.
That is a factor that would make the task of this Committee almost impossible. The majority report continued:

3.52 To make the claim that the term `pornography' really refers to the subjective reactions of individuals to particular representations of sex, rather than to the representations themselves and their intent, involves a serious misuse of language. It is clear that the term `pornography' does not refer to the interior dispositions of the viewers. Both the person who experiences outrage and the person who experiences arousal of sexual desires from viewing exploitative depictions of sexual activities aimed at sexual arousal knows what kind of material is being referred to when they hear the term `pornography'.
3.53 The term refers to the nature of the materials themselves-their content and apparent or purported intention to arouse the sexual desires of its target audience.
3.54 When using the term `pornography' in this Report the Committee means to speak of video material which is predominantly sexually explicit and intended primarily for the purpose of sexual arousal.

That was the broad definition description used by the Meese Commission and, essentially, by the Williams and Fraser committees. Again, we come back to Senator Collins and his misunderstanding of this situation. He attempted to charge the majority of the Committee with ignoring violence. Let me say that the majority of the Committee spent a great deal of time considering and detailing the evidence relating to violence. In fact, the majority of the Committee had in the forefront of its examination the types of films that Senator Collins said he would not like his son to see. I refer to films such as Blood Sucking Freaks and similar slasher type films. If Senator Collins did not already know it, he should have known the propositions we put forward in respect of that type of film which portrays violence in such a way as to try to develop a sense of relish in and a sense of satisfaction from the violence that takes place. We proposed that there be a provision in the R guidelines to ensure that films which contained relished acts of considerable violence, be refused classification. That is a small but absolutely most significant amendment, if it is carried through. Senator Zakharov is laughing.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you define `relished'?

—How does one define `relished'? How does one define `pornography'? Let it all go through! That is at the basis of what Senator Zakharov and Dr Klugman are about. They will try to undermine the evidence that has been given to us by behavioural scientists. The danger of their attempts to try to undermine the evidence given to us is not only in the area of pornography. If they attempt to try to undermine that sort of material, on what do they base the decisions to exclude certain acts of considerable violence? In my view, we are not talking here about censorship. We are talking about where to draw the line. It is the view of the majority that the line is not satisfactorily drawn. The minority relies on the slogan that people should be able to read and hear what they wish. It is, in fact, a slogan.
—With qualifications.
—Where are the qualifications in Senator Zakharov's minority report? In paragraph 16.2 of the majority report we make it clear when we state:

SPEECH.PARA: When the principle that adults be free to see, hear and read what they choose was originally stated as public policy the number of videotapes entering Australia was insignificant and there was not the widespread availability of objectionable video publications as exists today as the result of the flood of these materials into Australia . . . This principle is often stated, but not adhered to in practice, since adults are not free to view video material depicting, inter alia child pornography, bestiality and sexually explicit violent pornography as these are banned under censorship guidelines . . . and prohibited from entry into Australia under the customs regulations . . . The principle that adults be free to see, hear and read what they choose is dependent on the pornographers' claimed right to freedom of expression and the balancing of this claimed right against requirements fundamental to the common good which legislators are bound to uphold. The issue now is not whether there should be censorship as was the case in 1973 when the principle was first stated as public policy but where to draw the line. The Committee considers that the current line is not appropriately drawn.
To a certain extent even the Film Censorship Board suggests that it is a question of where to draw the line. I refer the Senate to paragraph 13.54 of the majority report, which indicated:

13.54 The Film Censorship Board relied on a limited range of research in its document attached to the Attorney-General's press release following the meeting of Attorneys-General on 26 October 1984. After that meeting it was decided inter alia that sexually explicit violent pornography (Category 1) should be removed from X but the other categories of sexually explicit video pornography . . . should remain available in X.
The Film Censorship Board stated:

Unless it can be demonstrated, to the satisfaction of a substantial majority of the population, that the ``pornographer's'' view of sexuality, as depicted in filmic images, produces tangible social harm, such views should be allowed to take their place in the market place-besides other views depicting different life-styles, attitudes and values.

What we have here is a policy based on a proposal that the pornographer's view should prevail unless it can be `demonstrated', whatever that means, to the `satisfaction', whatever that means, `of a substantial majority of the population'-however that is to be achieved. That is the basis on which the current X material is classified. What the majority of the Committee has done is to consider all of the evidence, not only the material from the behavioural scientists-although that material was quite telling-but that of all the other people who came before us. This included people such as the police in Victoria who indicated that this type of material was used by paedophiles to inveigle-if that is the right word-their victims.

There are a significant number of differences between the minority report and the majority report. Suffice it to say that there are substantial errors of fact and omission in the minority report. I will give honourable senators just one example. The parties to the minority report do not even know what is contained in the Customs legislation. I refer to paragraph 2.8 on page 331 of the minority report, which says:
The Commonwealth Customs legislation which was operative at the time of the introduction and growth of VCRs did not of course explicitly address the new technology of domestic video and videotapes.

They were referring to the period 1970-73, and go on to refer to successive governments since 1971. If we have a look in the appendices we find the Customs (Cinematograph Films) regulations, which define a film as follows:
`film' means a cinematograph film or a video tape, and includes a positive or negative of a cinematograph film;

That was included in legislation well before the period they were talking about. So they did not even know the legislation. This minority report is shot to bits with errors of fact and of omission. The majority report has attempted to set the facts before the public and before the Parliament. It is hoped that we have done that in a fairly logical and readable fashion, though I admit that we formulated the report under certain very grave constraints indeed. For example, as a student who would study the evidence received by the Committee and put on the public record, I found it frustrating that the Chairman indicated before he took up the chairmanship of the Committee that his prejudice was against any form of censorship.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are prejudiced as well.

—I have not declared my prejudice one way or the other. I attempted throughout the whole period that public evidence was given to the Committee to adopt an attitude whereby I could consider the evidence and come to my conclusions. So did the other members who have signed the majority report.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —In case I do not have time later, I want to pay tribute to the staff of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, particularly Jane Vincent and Rosemary Brissenden, who have done a tremendous job in enabling us to table this report without any further delay. The major part of the draft was written before the 1987 election, but a great deal more had to be done when there was a change in membership and consequently different views coming into the Committee which had to be accommodated. I think Senator Collins dealt with that point.
—We didn't see the draft.

—The honourable member knows he saw the majority of the draft. He did not see the whole draft, but he saw a major part of it. Before moving on to what I intended to say I would like to answer just a few of Senator Harradine's points. He started off by saying that the Victorian Government would be very concerned about this report coming forward with its recommendations at this time. He might be interested to know that most of the letters I receive-I have not counted them but they are probably running at about eight to one-are not from Victoria, although I represent Victoria, but from interstate. I think Victorians are mature enough to have a right to choose in this matter. No-one has to watch what they do not want to watch. That is something that is sometimes forgotten. Everyone has the right to choose whether they hire, buy or watch videos, as they do with television.
—Have you asked John Cain?

—No, but I have spoken to other Ministers recently. One must remember, after all, that we have had X-rated movies in Victoria before and they did not cause any of the major problems that Senator Harradine seems to think they will, and they did not cause any political problems either. The matter of X-rating has not been covered up in the minority report. What is contained in the X category is outlined in the appendices, in the guidelines. All senators, incidentally, have had the opportunity to see for themselves, if they wanted to, what an X-rated movie looks like-a right denied to people in their own States unless they can afford to buy or hire by post.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to hear Senator Harradine raise the question of cost, because I think the minority could just as well have raised the matter or what might be called the plagiarism involved in the majority's lifting of so much of the Chairman's draft to put into its own report. But that is a minor matter.

On the definition of pornography, of course any definition of pornography is subjective as it depends on the attitude of the speaker. This matter was ably dealt with by Senator Jenkins in her speech. The dictionary definition is different from any definition that is used in either report, and is different again from the one which Senator Harradine chose to quote and adopt from the report of Meese et al. To answer all the claims that Senator Harradine made about our report would take hours so I will leave it there.

Before coming to more specific matters I would like to emphasise two points. First, there was much common ground in the recommendations of both reports in spite of the major philosophical differences referred to in them. This common ground spread across political boundaries and also across the boundaries of beliefs. This, then, has been a very valuable inquiry and should form an excellent basis for more informed discussion, both by the general public and by decision makers, both State and federal. Apart from the major differences of opinion concerning the non-violent erotica classification, I believe the other differences between the two sets of recommendations are relatively minor and/or technical.

The second general point I want to make is that the Committee discovered, and we continue to discover, a vast amount of ignorance in the community about the existing law, not only among persons in the street but among senators and members and their State equivalents who are in a position to act on these recommendations and who, in many cases, have voiced impatience about seeing our report while neglecting their own homework. One example was found in a Press release put out a few months ago by the Opposition spokesperson, Mr Peter Reith-I do not know whether he still is the Opposition spokesperson-who called for the banning of material which is in fact already banned; for example, depictions of explicit sexual violence and child pornography. He clearly believed, as do most of those who write to us, incidentally, that material rated X is more violent than material rated R. Clearly Mr Reith had not read the guidelines or consulted the Attorney-General's Department or the Film Censorship Board.

I would like to spend a little time concentrating on chapter 13 of the majority report. I emphasise for the sake of the record that I am a qualified psychologist of some years standing, a member of the Australian Psychological Society and a practising counselling psychologist, so I do have some experience in dealing with the subject matter before us. The majority report's discussion of learning theory is very simplistic and selective. It seems to have been written without reference to anything more than selected submissions and perhaps an encyclopaedia. Thus chapter 13 of the majority report goes into great detail about variations within social learning theory, yet even the theory itself does not seem to have been adequately understood, while ignoring a range of other equally well accepted theories of learning which are less simplistic, such as Gestalt theory which relates learning to the restructuring of the learner's view of the subject matter, and such as cognitive or, broadly described humanistic theory which takes into account factors such as intelligence, insight, the process of concept formation, as well as motivation which is not based on simple reward or punishment, as the earlier theories were. There are even physiologically based theories which may have relevance to this issue; for example, violent acts may result from a reduction in inhibitions due to, say, drug intake or perhaps brain damage.

The muddled psychology, or pseudo-psychology, in this chapter is not really capable of sensible debate, but I do not want to draw attention to some underlying assumptions about methodology which are probably responsible for the morass of theory and claims about likely effects of viewing which we find in this chapter. There is a basic lack of logic involved here or a misunderstanding of the precise meaning of some terms used in common speech and also used with more precision in the fields of science and statistics. These terms are `cause' and `correlation'. The third word which is not used in this chapter, but which should be, is `antecedent', literally meaning something going before, a prior event or a pre-existing condition. Thus, an antecedent may be a cause, but certainly not necessarily so. Attending school is an antecedent for most adult criminality, but I doubt anyone would say that school attendance causes crime or that the drinking of milk causes alcoholism, although clearly it is an antecedent. Yet we find in the majority report statements that seem to assume that, if one action is followed in time by another, it is likely, or even highly probable, that the first causes the second. Thus, viewing violent videos is seen as causing the violence, whereas the causes probably lie in any one or more of a number of factors. Viewing violent videos may be an antecedent, for example, to juvenile violence, but the cause may well be something like parental attitudes to violence or viewing actual violence at home or elsewhere where it is seen as the only way to solve conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't read our report, because we made those comments.

—I have read that report in great detail. Similarly, correlation does not in itself imply causality or even a basis for the prediction of future behaviour, as seems to be claimed in chapter 13 of the majority report. When a correlation is found or even sometimes, as in this case, claimed to be found between the hire and sale of videos and crime rates, for example, whether sex crime or violent crime, there will also be correlations with many other factors, such as average weekly earnings, school retention rates or even adherence to fundamentalist religion or vegetarianism-all things which have risen in recent years.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of the supposed link between the crime rate and video viewing, the cause may well lie elsewhere, and I would suggest it is more likely to be related to economic factors or early childhood experience, for example. Correlation alone cannot be the basis of prediction, but it may lead to further research as to why there is a correlation and whether there is a casual connection in either direction of the two correlates.

These basic points of logic are virtually ignored in chapter 13. There is much of the evidence which the majority accepted, seemingly without questioning the methodology. When methodology was questioned, the answer given was often unsatisfactory. In laboratory experiments cited there was often little attempt to choose the sample to reflect the general population. Weaver, for example, whose research got a mention, used psychology students, who from my own experience usually find it very easy to predict what the experimenter is looking for and to react accordingly. Many other studies also used students as subjects and often the effects, when found, were after a very short period. Most studies failed to account for factors such as prior experience or even tastes in reading, for example, pornographic magazines. Yet the writers of this chapter do not stop at drawing unwarranted conclusions from this research. In some cases evidence has been distorted by taking it out of context. I want to give the Senate two examples of that. Paragraph 13.29 of the report states:
Dr Edgar sees it as `feasible' that some individuals may select materials that exaggerate their aggressive tendency and hence allow the committal of a violent crime . . .

That is what the report said, but listen to what the transcript said. It is not exactly the same. Senator Walters asked about a person with an inhibiting factor to stop him from actually carrying out the aggression, and Dr Edgar said:
The video breaks it down.
Senator Walters said:
After psyching himself up on the videos he is then able to commit the crime. I wonder whether you think that is a feasible proposition because it is put in a number of court cases that it is so.
Dr Edgar answered:
I am sure it is feasible. I do not know the proportion of people or the numbers and the circumstances.
Later she said:
When you look at the analysis of crime you see that statistically most murders are domestic and most violence is domestic.
There is another example in the next paragraph of the report. Dr Ann Knowles told the Committee:
. . . American, British and some other research does suggest that viewing television violence can, in some children, subsequently increase aggressive behaviour.
Further, the report says:

While noting the paucity of equivalent Australian research, she stated that one `can have a certain amount of confidence' in the long term studies in America `demonstrating a weak but significant causal link between watching violence on television and later aggressiveness in some children, who are probably somewhat predisposed to aggression in the first place.'
If we look at the transcript, we see that Dr Knowles said:
There has not been a great deal of Australian research done but the research that has been done to date has not supported that finding.
That is the American finding. To continue:
There is no Australian evidence to support a causal relationship between watching violence on television and later aggressiveness in children.

The point that Dr Knowles makes here is very important. Attempts to repeat the experiment to get similar results have not, on the whole, been successful, and replication is very important to validity, particularly if validity is being claimed in two different countries with different histories, different cultures and different attitudes to violence, which is the case between the United States of America and Australia.

There is in chapters 13 and 14 reference to anecdotal evidence, some of which is said to be from professionals, but the `professionals' are not necessarily from professions which give them any expertise on matters involved in this inquiry. For example, in the other place this morning one of the members of the Committee majority referred to a priest in Melbourne who related viewing videos to prostitution, drugs and homelessness in young people. I have personally attended meetings and conferences with that priest, and he certainly does not seem to understand the distinction between antecedents and correlates and causes. In this case the underlying causes for the characteristics of these young people undoubtedly lie elsewhere, whether in economic factors, in early childhood experience, in domestic violence or in any number of other possible causes.

Similarly, the majority report seems to give the views of teachers, untrained community volunteers and police equal weight with evidence from those with direct professional knowledge of the issues under discussion. For example, I find that policemen, I think because until very recently they were recruited with a very low level of education, are often very simplistic about their views on crime. Magistrates, too, who also get a favourable mention in the report, usually have no training in the social sciences and are not always careful enough about accepting again an antecedent as a cause. Who are some of the people quoted approvingly by the majority report as experts, who have presented evidence which convinced them that the viewing of X-rated videos was harmful? As I have said, some have been quoted out of context and others have been quoted selectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —Edgar and Knowles have been talking about violence.
—I thought part of the report was about violence, Senator.
—That's right, but you said about pornography.

—I am not going to go into that argument about definition again. For example, Frank Horwill, a psychologist who appeared on behalf of a working party of the Australian Psychological Society, although not representing the Society itself, in fact is quoted favourably. But when I looked at what he had actually said, his conclusion does not seem to go along with the quotation that was given. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: On the present psychological evidence, the extent and kind of harm which may follow from viewing non-violent erotic material depends on the extent to which the content is arousing and pleasing or displeasing, the amount of viewing, the message communicated by the material, and the context in which the viewing takes place. Much more research is required before it is fully incriminated for or exonerated from contributing to violence or other physical or psychological harms. Such research would still leave open the question of harms in areas not readily amenable to psychological research.

Other parts of the so-called expert advice would be laughed out of court at any gathering of people who understood the subject matter and methodology. I would like honourable senators to listen to this excerpt from the transcript of the Committee when Dr Radecki was before it. He was talking about the effects on viewers of watching pornographic material. He said:
I have noticed in myself that after I see some of these types of things I start to have more rape thoughts-
that is interesting-

I hope that that does not mean that I am a perverted psycho. I try not to consume this because I know that it affects me. I would suggest that it can affect all of us and none of us should really entertain ourselves with this stuff.
I said:
The problem is, where do you draw the line between fantasising and doing and is fantasising harmful?
Again, that is another logical slide. Dr Radecki said:

I know of research done by Dr Gene Able-and this has nothing to do with violent entertainment. He works with sex offenders and does measurements with penile tumescence and stuff like that. He plays rape audio tapes to both rape offenders and people out in society who have not yet been convicted of raping women. He finds that a substantial minority of people do get more excited by rape fantasies and that people who accept the rape myth that women enjoy being raped, that women really want to be raped, and things of that type, are the same people who tend to get erections when listening to that type of material. That type of reaction is more common in society than we would like to think. Also, according to the most recent figures, at least one out of every six American men will rape a woman at some time during his life.

That was in answer to a question when he was asked whether fantasising leads to doing. In other words, he was quite incapable of answering the question in a straight manner. That question, unanswered by Dr Radecki, of whether viewing leads to doing is very important to the debate. But, unfortunately, this example is typical of Dr Radecki's evasion of questions which had much depth and which questioned methodology. Another breathtaking Radecki claim was made, unfortunately after the Hansard people had switched off their tape, when I challenged him about a statement that linked liking heavy metal rock music with violent tendencies, by telling him that I, who abhor violence, liked that music. He replied that that explained why I had shown in my questions that I was desensitised to violence. This is laughable stuff yet this is the sort of expert that the majority has believed.

Dr Court is another expert witness relied upon heavily in the majority report. I would like to quote just briefly from the evidence given to us by Dr Gus Brannigan, in an excellent critique of much of the research that was presented to the Committee. Dr Brannigan was referring to a book that Dr Court had written. He refers to the data presented and says:

As usual, not a jot of data is presented to establish that change has taken place, nor is there any independent variable reflecting the change in the actual circulation of pornography. One is supposed to presume that something happens between 1964 and 1974 and one is supposed to assume that the change was not already underway . . .
Again, that is looking at antecedents, not causes. He says further:

Court counsels against comparison of the actual levels of rape because of definitional problems across jurisdictions, though this strikes me as rather convenient since Williams had already reproached Court for contrasting rapes in liberal England with illiberal Singapore when, in fact, the rate of rape is lower in England, where pornography has been available, contrary to everything Court has preached.

There is very much more in Brannigan's contribution which is worth quoting, but I do not think there is time. I would like to mention briefly the matter of access by children, going to another chapter. Here I will quote from my own speech when the Senate Committee report was tabled, because I do not think that I can say it any better than I did three years ago. Senator Harradine would probably say that that says something about me. On that occasion, I said:

We have heard the argument on past occasions about children who will see video material that their parents have hired. As parents, we must all take responsibility for what goes on in our homes. I do not consider that it is responsible for a parent to leave a whisky bottle around where there are children. Similarly, I do not consider it responsible for a parent to leave an X-rated movie around, but I do not think there is any real difference between the two cases. One could say that a parent who leaves prescription medicines around is probably far more likely to cause harm to the child than the parent who leaves an X-rated video movie around. That is in the hands of the parents and we are certainly not going to ban whisky or prescription drugs just on the supposition that children might get hold of them.

I do not think that anyone is claiming that we should go ahead with that sort of action. I would like to emphasise the value of the report at this point and ask honourable senators to read both volumes. I know the amount looks heavy, but some of it is quite entertaining. Honourable senators should see that there are many recommendations, some of which were referred to by Senator Jenkins, to which everyone on the Committee agreed. They were very practical recommendations about advertising and classifications being put in a meaningful way on the outside cover and on the tape itself, for example. I commend the whole report to the Senate and hope honourable senators will read it.

I said in my dissenting report on the Senate Select Committee report that I believe it to be unpardonable arrogance for the State to dictate to its adult citizens what they shall or shall not see, read or hear unless cogent reasons are advanced to the contrary. That is the sort of qualification that I was referring to in my interjection to Senator Harradine. Nothing I have heard or read during the inquiry by the Joint Committee leads me to change that point of view. I should add that over many years prior to both these inquiries I have also read a great deal on the issue of censorship. What I have learnt during this inquiry is that censorship in a pluralist society is a matter for community discussion, to reach an acceptable community standard. That is what we should be aiming for. There is no evidence available of any cause or connection between what people read, hear and view, and what they do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented by the previous speaker. Senator Zakharov in her speech indicated that the majority, of whom I was one, plagiarised the Chairman's draft.
—I said it could be seen that way.

—I am sorry. Senator Zakharov suggested that it could be seen that the majority, of whom I am one, plagiarised substantial parts of the Chairman's draft. I thought it was the job of members of a committee to consider a chairman's draft. A chairman's draft, under Standing Orders, must be prepared and submitted to the members of the committee. The Joint Select Committee on Video Material was not unlike other committees which have considered the chairman's draft. There was an attempt on behalf of members of the majority of the Committee to follow, as far as possible, the Chairman's draft and to accept as much of it as possible. If that is plagiarism, that is a new ball game for all committees whether they be Senate, joint or House committees. It is an unwarranted reflection on the majority of the Committee, particularly as some of the sections of the Chairman's draft which we would rather not have included in the majority report were included because we hoped that we would get some sort of unanimity and balance in the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper relates to air fare consultations by the Australian National Airlines Commission and Ansett Airlines of Australia and it examines the question of setting fares for domestic air travel within Australia. This is an important subject in the operation of the airlines, but there are other aspects of air travel that are important to the Australian community. This evening I wish to speak briefly on the matter of airline schedules. I believe that the smaller capital cities and the outlying States are penalised very badly indeed by the structure of the Australian domestic airline schedules. One reaches the conclusion that the airline schedules are drawn up to suit the convenience of the operations divisions of the airlines rather than the needs of airline travellers.

I refer in particular to the vexed question of duplicated flight departure times in Australia, the so-called parallel schedules which, as I am sure Senator Walsh would agree, are very bad for Perth and Western Australia. They certainly penalise business and leisure travellers from my city of Adelaide, and I know that Senator Collins is concerned about airline schedules in the Northern Territory. I refer to the latest annual report of the Australian Tourism Commission, that for 1986-87. A section in that report entitled `Looking Ahead' states:
There is insufficient flexibility in domestic aviation services.

That is referred to in the context of barriers to an ideal tourism environment in Australia. Our domestic airline system is just not flexible enough to present a good service for tourists. I assume that in making that comment the Commission is referring to the paralleling of schedules. The parallel departure times must be a nightmare for people coming to Australia from overseas who try to organise a domestic itinerary within Australia. It must be particularly hard to visit places such as Alice Springs and other places in central Australia which are obviously highlights for visitors from overseas.

Australian Airlines has seven weekly flights at 8.45 a.m. from Adelaide to Alice Springs; Ansett has six weekly flights at 8.40 a.m.-that is, a five-minute difference-and there is another flight at 9 a.m. one day a week. So, the seven Australian Airlines weekly airline services from Adelaide to Alice Springs are paralleled by Ansett. I think that is an unacceptable situation. In fairness, I should point out that there is one other Ansett departure each week at a totally different time.

However, having gone to Alice Springs and Ayers Rock and having looked at the highlights of central Australia, to fly south one must leave either on the daily 4.20 p.m. Australian Airlines flight or the 4.40 p.m. Ansett flight to Adelaide. That is the great choice. If one misses those flights one has to wait until late afternoon of the next day to make that journey. It must be a nightmare for overseas visitors trying to put together a timetable for travelling around Australia to see the tourists attractions.

Similarly, there is a high degree of paralleling of departure times for the Adelaide to Sydney flights. In fact, of the 24 Australian Airlines direct flights every week, no fewer than 17 are paralleled by Ansett, with departures within 15 minutes. Thus, 17 out of 24 departure times are directly paralleled. Instead of a theoretical 45 different weekly departure times, the real figure is much less than that. I hope that when the new arrangements foreshadowed by the Government for the Australian domestic airlines system come into operation in 1990 we can really get stuck into this totally unacceptable problem of parallel scheduling which penalises domestic air travellers in the outlying States and in the smaller capital cities.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper is a report of the Advisory Group on Australian Airlines. It is significant that the composition of that committee is very heavily loaded in favour of the governing party, with Mr Bill Kelty, Mr Peter Redlich and Dr Peter Wilenski being three of the five members of that committee. Yet, despite their very powerful party backgrounds they have effectively blown the arguments against privatisation out of the water. They have done that in the nicest possible way and I suppose, one could say, with very careful regard to the consequences of the debate that will take place shortly at the Australian Labor Party national conference. But the end result is that they do not advance any significant arguments that would indicate why it is not appropriate to sell the whole of Australian Airlines.

However, some rather cryptic statements need to be addressed. One in particular is that the sale of any portion of the airline at the present time would be unlikely to realise full value for current shareholders, that is, taxpayers. No argument is advanced as to why that should be the case. I suppose one could always say that there are market fluctuations that must be taken into account and with hindsight that one did not sell at the top of the market. If what is meant by `full value' is full market value, there is no reason to imagine--

TALK.START.PARA: —The presumption is that they have been run inefficiently in recent years but will be run better in the future.

—One would have thought that a premium would be paid by investors who had the same foresight as Senator Walsh. There is no particular reason to make those sorts of assumptions. One can do net present value streams of income calculations and add a premium and no doubt if it is out in the marketplace some will place more value on its present worth than others. That in itself perhaps is an argument for profit maximisation, but it is certainly not a philosophical objection to the sale. The next item that I find rather curious in the report is the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The group believes that the Government could . . . give consideration to infusion of equity capital from strategic investors.

It is made abundantly clear that capital of the order of $1,400m will be required over the next four years and thereafter some $2,200m, and presumably that is in current dollar terms. Those sorts of figures are well beyond the Budget capacity of the Government, and that must be abundantly evident to everyone. The consequence is that the necessary capital injection will not be forthcoming.

It is also interesting that the report acknowledges that there can be an appropriate gearing ratio, in this instance 60 : 40, and that that would require the injection of something like $80m a year over the next three years. However, to suggest that consideration should be given to the infusion of equity capital from strategic investors is a very quaint notion because strategic investors are defined as:
Parties who may be able to contribute to the airline's future by way of specific skills and experience.

I believe that that is a nonsense. Those who should invest or should be entitled to invest are those who are prepared to put in money up front, and they will make their judgments based on their own capacity to invest and the return that they would expect to obtain. There is absolutely no point at all in trying to artificially limit the category of those who should be entitled to invest. That sort of logic flows through in another fairly crucial recommendation, concerning the appropriate ways of ensuring that the airline meets the wider social responsibilities of a government-owned enterprise. That is not defined. Time and again the report argues for commercial orientation and it makes the assumption that social responsibilities should be associated with a government owned enterprise and that they can be met by the appointment of appropriate persons to the board. If that is not simply party stacking I do not know what is.

The notion of social responsibility becomes a little clearer when one looks at page 95 of the report, because that spells out that apart from needing a strong commercially oriented board there are obligations such as an innovative and well-regarded employer and service provider. If that means providing a service on uneconomic routes or paying wages higher than the market requires, I would have thought that that is acting in a non-commercial manner, which is the very sort of vice that this report says should not be condoned and, therefore, I find it unsatisfactory--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) endorses the findings of the Draft Report of the Industries Assistance Commission on Coastal Shipping that coastal shipping in Australia is uncompetitive and inefficient;
(b) notes the disastrous effect on the Australian economy of the high costs of coastal shipping; and

(c) condemns the Government for its negative reaction to this Report and urges the Government to take immediate action to prevent inefficient coastal shipping services further jeopardising growth and employment opportunities in the rest of the economy.

Before dealing with the justification for the motion, I will make a few general remarks. The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report is a devastating indictment of, first, the state of our coastal shipping and, secondly, our port handling facilities. They are a burden that a country in our economic situation cannot afford. The IAC has brought these matters to the attention of the public-and I point out that I have been talking about them for years-and they must be tackled. I would have thought that the high cost of coastal shipping and its disastrous effect on the Australian economy was obvious. We have many isolated communities around our coastline with vast distances in between and we depend desperately on efficient shipping links, which is something that we do not have at the moment. Any Government action is very hard to see, in that it either calls for more reports or, in the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), it addresses the problem. I am not sure what is meant by `addressing the problem' but it sounds like the old Latin form in that they say, `Oh problem, I wish you would go away'. The Government does nothing because it is not prepared to engage in the confrontations that are necessary to tackle these serious problems.

When we were rich and our export values were high, we could possibly afford our coastal shipping and port handling facilities; but we can no longer afford their level of inefficiency. We must tackle these problems. The Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has said that he wants to go very gently-`They are making progress; let us not rush things and cause an upset'. That is not a practical approach to the problem. The maritime unions have a monopoly in coastal shipping and monopolies do not yield to persuasion. Perhaps they make some token changes and do a few things to make themselves look a bit better in the eyes of the community, but ultimately they will yield their monopoly position only if one of two things is done. The first is that someone legislates to control them. With our industrial relations system and the limited power of the Federal Parliament, that is not an effective option. The only approach to deal with this monopoly and this abuse of power is to introduce competition, but the Government is extraordinarily reluctant to do that.

We will not have an efficient coastal shipping service unless there is competition, and we will not have an efficient port handling system unless there is competition. Given the limitation of Federal power, there is no alternative unless we want to continue to be blackmailed and stood over by this monopoly of union power. That has been the history of the past, it is the situation at present and, given the Government's present attitude, it will be the situation in the future. However, it is a situation that this country, which is in deep economic trouble, can no longer afford.

What are we really talking about in regard to coastal shipping? The IAC report summarised it and it is worth recording its summary of the present state of Australia's coastal shipping. In 1985-86 Australian coastal shipping carried about 45 million tonnes of freight between some 40 ports at an estimated cost of about $800m, $200m of which related to shore based activities. This comprised about 3 per cent of the total domestic transport task on the basis of tonnes carried or about 40 per cent of the task based on a tonne-kilometre standard.

Coastal shipping is dominated by bulk cargoes relating to steel-that is, iron ore and coal; to aluminium-bauxite and alumina; and to oil refining-crude oil and petroleum products, with fairly constant demands in terms of volumes shipped, at least in recent times. Our coastal shipping provides employment for an estimated 4,500 seagoing personnel and perhaps as many again on-shore engaged in complementary activities such as stevedoring. That is the industry we are talking about.

How has it got into such a mess as it now is? It is grossly uneconomic, monopoly ridden and doing great damage to the Australian economy. It all stems back to the Navigation Act, which limits coastal shipping to those ships that employ seamen at Australian wage rates and that are not in receipt of foreign government subsidies. The section in the Navigation Act dealing with coastal trade came into force in 1921. When it was introduced in that year it was done behind a web of dishonest publicity. It was said that the legislation supported competition in the coastal trade. It was said then that any ship, Australian or foreign, could be licensed to engage in the coastal trade provided it complied with certain conditions-and I emphasise `certain conditions'. Of course, the licence fee was not a problem. The licence is issued for a nominal fee. In 1981, for instance, the licence fee was $5.

Why then do we not get foreign ships carrying our trade between our coastal cities? The problem is the conditions attached to the licence. Seamen have to be paid at the current rates of pay operating in Australia and the ships have to operate with Australian manning levels and Australian conditions and accommodation requirements. These conditions still apply today, 64 years later; and it is to our great cost that they still apply. Australian shipping has to be operated at award rates, with Australian manning levels and Australian conditions of crew accommodation. By the way, it costs a million dollars more to fit out an Australian ship to our standards than it does in a country with comparable or higher standards of living, such as Sweden.

We also have a problem in that the crews on Australian ships, although much larger than the crews on many foreign ships, do much less maintenance work. This in turn means that Australian ships have to spend a longer period in dockyard hands. These dockyards, in another rort, an inter-union deal, are run in a way which means repairs in an Australian shipyard are three times as expensive as those in a foreign yard. No wonder our ships are not efficient or economic. The only exception-because no foreign owner would ever be mad enough to send a ship to Australia on those conditions-in which a foreign ship may obtain a permit to operate in coastal trade without meeting the stringent Australian crew requirements is for a single voyage where no suitable Australian ship is available, particularly for freight movement. To ensure that only Australian ships or foreign ships meeting the Australian crew requirements operate in the coastal trade, a licence or permit is issued for the ships to operate this trade and no ship can operate without it. The only circumstances in which this can be waived is if there is no suitable Australian ship, and then a single voyage permit issued. These permits are very rare and most are issued only for the transport of liquified petroleum gas (LPG). I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing cargo carried under the single voyage permits.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. What has happened to our coastal ships is that our seamen's unions have managed to get a monopoly of the coastal trade. It has become a total rort for the seagoing unions and a high cost service for which all Australians pay. This is confirmed by the Industries Assistance Commission report to which I referred earlier and its measured words are worth recalling. It is an interim report which the Minister is trying to rubbish by picking up minor factual errors; it is only an interim draft report and minor factual errors are not important because the thrust of the report is accurate. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Coastal shipping in Australia is uncompetitive and inefficient.

High costs and a poor record of service have progressively reduced the industry to a position where the only goods currently shipped around the coast tend to be those for which no alternative transport modes are available, or are not a realistic proposition.

While this must be of concern to the industry itself, the real issue for the Australian community is that inefficient coastal shipping services jeopardise growth and employment opportunities in the rest of the economy.

The IAC has estimated that the excessive coastal shipping freight rates, between 20 and 30 per cent, wipe off between $300m and $700m from Australia's gross domestic product annually. The pendulum on the economy is equivalent to adding between $7 and $16 to the cost of every tonne of cargo transported by ship around Australia's coast or between $35,000 and $80,000 annually for every worker employed in the industry, both at sea and on the waterfront.

What has happened over the years is that there has been a steady and, at the moment apparently, irreversible decline in our coastal shipping. When the Navigation Act giving the effective monopoly to Australian flagships and a monopoly to the unions concerned was ratified in 1921, there was very little competition from other forms of transport such as road and rail. At that time rail was not used for any purposes other than inside States. The transcontinental railway was completed only three years earlier. The situation of very little interstate traffic by rail continued to World War II. But by 1962 the standard gauge made rail an option for services between Victoria and New South Wales. Also in the 1920s there was really no competition from road transport. The roads either did not exist or were not good enough to take heavy traffic safely and quickly between States. But as the roads have improved the competition among road, rail and shipping has become more intense. What has happened is that our road transport in particular has become much more efficient, our shipping has not become more efficient but has declined in efficiency, and cargoes that on any economically rational basis should be carried by sea are being carried by other means, by road in particular, to the great economic loss of the country. It is absurd to see single containers carried across Australia by rail because the shipping and port handling facilities and the reliability of delivery are such that people prefer to send goods by road rather than by the much more economically sensible method of sending them by sea. Coastal shipping's share of total domestic freight has declined from 52 per cent in 1970 to 39 per cent in 1984, while road transport's share has increased from 20 to 30 per cent and rail from 28 per cent to 31 per cent.

How has our shipping got into such a mess? Of course, it is the usual result of a monopoly. Monopolies exploit communities over which they have that monopoly and shipowners have little or no control over costs. The unions have demanded and, because of their monopoly position, have nearly always obtained everything they have asked for. They have been bought off again and again. There is even a situation where the shipping companies have no control over their crew selection. Imagine the consequences of that! There is no incentive to train crews to more efficiency if a company cannot get the same people on successive voyages. There is no proper system of responsibility and efficiency inside our coastal shipping industry.

What is worse, when new technology became available-say, from 1970 onwards-it was either too expensive to introduce or was rejected by the maritime unions. For instance, when the rest of the world was using more efficient drive on-drive off ferries, the Australian National Line (ANL) was, and still is, running vehicle deck ships which need specialised equipment to straddle vehicles off and on board. The costs of loading and unloading these vehicles is estimated to be 40 per cent higher than it would otherwise be with some sort of roll on-roll off vehicle.

Let us look at some of the other problems our coastal shipping industry has. One is manning levels. I am sure that Senator Ray will say something about this, but I do not think that what he says is likely to be credible. Manning and conditions add an excessive and grossly unreasonable cost to our coastal shipping. Despite the report of the Crawford Committee on Revitalisation of Australian Shipping, our progress in crew reductions has been very slow indeed. Although the Crawford report recommendations have been implemented, the first ship has only just come into service under these conditions. This only applies to new ships, the old ones are manned at much higher levels. But we will not see any useful results from this recommendation on manning before the mid-1990s. Even when these reforms are introduced, our crew levels will still be 25 per cent higher than those of comparable maritime nations with comparable standards of living. Australian ships are still being provided with 25 per cent more crewmen to do the same job-actually a lesser job because, as I said, our crews do less on-board maintenance than do the smaller crews in any comparable country.

I will just give one example of the sort of nonsense we go in for in overmanning. Every Australian ship has to have a radio officer. Why do we want a radio officer? Why cannot the officer of the watch man the radio as the captain of an aircraft does? There is voice radio now; we do not need a specialised radio officer. Because of the old built-in inefficiencies and built-in monopoly powers we still provide people we do not need. That is only one example. Many others have to be tackled. We are dealing with big money. The cost per head of a position in an ANL ship is $100,000 per year. That is big money if one can cut back on one's crew. Also, for every position in the ship we have to provide 2.2 people to allow for six weeks on-six weeks off-six months annual leave plus sickness and similar benefits. So we are talking about big savings if we can get our crews down to the levels of comparable countries which are as rich or richer than we are.
