TALK.START.PARA: —Air travel also makes our coastal shipping inefficient. A crew member does six weeks on and six weeks off. When he finishes his six weeks on he has to be relocated back home-first class air travel, of course, and appropriate accommodation in first class hotels.
—The same as you get.

—Yes, it is the same as members of parliament get, but does Senator Ray think that an ordinary seaman from a merchant ship deserves or requires the same standard of transport and accommodation as a member of parliament? If he thinks that, that is equality gone berserk!
—They earn more money than we do.

—They possibly earn more money but that is a different problem. No other country in the world provides these conditions for its seamen. We are not the richest country in the world. We used to be, but we are now down to fourteenth. No other country in the world provides these sorts of conditions for its seamen. We do, and we do so because of the monopoly power of the unions which have managed to extort these conditions from the Australian public.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at another item-repatriation conditions. If a crew member becomes ill, even with a minor complaint, say in an Asian port-this does not, of course, apply to coastal shipping but it is one of our shipping problems-he is flown to Sydney perhaps, first class of course. A replacement crew member is then flown to the port where his ship is-first class of course-and the ship may be delayed several days. It is not permitted to sail with a replacement seaman from the port in which it is caught. It has to have someone come back from the base. The cost is $30,000 to $50,000 a day. Can one wonder why our freight rates are so high? There is one other matter-that of victualling. Australian awards require two hot meals a day with alternative menus and full catering in port, despite the fact that there may be very few crew members left on board.

We then come to the ultimate rort-leave. For every crew billet in one of our ships we require 2.2 seamen. This is because our seamen get six months leave a year. This figure of 338 days leave for each year's work for an Australian should be compared to 226 days for a Frenchman, 216 for an American, 174 for a West German, 141 for a Norwegian and 84 for a British rating. This is an outrageous rort. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the relative leave entitlements for the seamen of various countries.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

PROCTEXT.PARA: LEAVE ENTITLEMENTS BY SHIPPING NATION, DECEMBER 1984 (Days)
Source: Derived from information presented by the Government of Tasmania (Submission no. 48, p. 37)

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator HAMER

TALK.START.PARA: —One can see from the table and from what I have said that our leave entitlements far exceed those of most traditional maritime nations; in some cases they are up to four times as great as those applicable elsewhere, for instance in Japan, the United Kingdom and Greece. This is a significant cost burden. In addition to these factors, there are a number of non-wage items that combine to add significantly to our vessel manning costs. These are payroll tax, fringe benefits tax, superannuation, crew-related insurance for workers compensation and similar claims, travel and accommodation, which I have mentioned, victualling, which I have also mentioned, recruiting and training, medical expenses, provision of special clothing and so on. We are running a very expensive system which is far beyond what any comparable country provides and far beyond our means to provide.

INTERJECT.PARA: Although the motion refers specifically to our coastal shipping, we must not delude ourselves that the problem can be solved merely by getting competition into our coastal shipping. The other problems stem directly from our ports. We have exactly the same problems of lack of competition, inefficiency, gross overmanning and excessive wages and rorts. These must be tackled by this inactive Government. In the international insurance fraternity our ports have the reputation of being the most strike-prone in the world. We have held that title for five years in a row and we do not look like giving it up-unlike the title of the `world's best Treasurer' which Mr Keating once held. However, I believe that the next year he was runner-up to the world's worst Treasurer. I do not think that we are likely to give up our title. We have had five years in a row of having the most strike prone ports in the world.

The productivity, by any standards, is disgraceful. For instance, using identical equipment-it is not a question of capital equipment; it is a question of how the equipment is operated-it takes two days to load or unload 300 containers in an Australian port. It takes four hours, as opposed to two days, using identical equipment to handle the same number of containers in Hong Kong; six hours in Singapore and never longer than one day in a European port. This is a problem we must tackle urgently.

It is obvious that our coastal shipping is in an appalling state. Something has to be done to tackle this problem. It is no use saying, `We will go very softly. We must not offend anyone'. That might have been a possible approach were we one of the most prosperous countries in the world; maybe we could afford this inefficiency. But we can afford it no longer. We will not break the power of monopoly by negotiation. The only way to break a monopoly-everyone knows this; it has been proved over and over again-is by either government regulation-I do not believe that we have the power, because of the limitations of the Constitution, to do much about that; I hope that we do-or introducing competition. It is the only feasible way to solve the problems of our coastal shipping. We must open it up to competition, break the monopoly of the maritime unions and get our conditions so that they are fair but comparable with those of countries as rich as we are or even richer. At the moment, it is an appalling rort for which the whole Australian community is paying very dearly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 July 1987, the Government referred to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) a reference on the efficiency of coastal shipping. Rather than read the terms of reference, I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
A.1 Terms of Reference
I, JOHN NORMAN BUTTON, Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, in pursuance of my powers under Section 23 of the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 hereby:
1. Refer to the Industries Assistance Commission for inquiry and provision of an information report, the coastal shipping industry, excluding waterfront operations at Australian ports.

2. Specify that this reference is intended to elicit information about the efficiency of the coastal shipping industry in Australia and its impact on economic growth and employment within the economy.

3. Without limiting the generality of this reference, request that in its report in accordance with paragraphs 1 and 2 above, and noting the Government's existing policy is that coastal trade be carried in Australian controlled and Australian crewed ships, except where such ships are unavailable or services provided by them are inadequate, the Commission report on:

(a) the economic efficiency of coastal shipping and the cost structures of operating vessels currently engaged in or capable of being used in the coastal trades, taking into account developments currently taking place in the industry
(b) competitive forces within and impacting on the coastal shipping industry
(c) freight charges in coastal shipping and the extent to which these might vary as a result of improved efficiency in the industry
(d) the impact of Government assistance and regulation on coastal shipping operations and on costs to using industries
(e) other factors which impact on the efficiency of coastal shipping or impair its competitiveness
(f) the linkages between these industries and growth and employment elsewhere in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. There is quite a substantial difference between a draft report and a final report. A draft report is circulated on the understanding that it will be given a rigorous examination, that it will invite future public comment and other submissions and further public hearings before a final report is produced. Having first read the draft report, I faced a dilemma: `Do I say nothing and wait for the final report?'. I clearly made a political decision to make my views known, at least on the contents of the draft report, because if I had not done so the debate would have raged on and there would have been no Government comment whatsoever. Everyone was ready at midnight on the 27th. Mr Julian Beale, with his usual immature approach to transport matters-why he has been left in that portfolio, I do not know; it is not surprising that Senator Hamer has the major carriage of these issues-put out an eight or 10-paragraph Press release. Apparently, that was a big effort for him. Andrew Hay from the Australian Chamber of Commerce turned cartwheels because at last he had finally found a philosophy and an exposition of a philosophy more right wing than himself. Other writers, such as Paddy McGuinness, turned cartwheels over the report's conclusions. My greatest objection to the report is not simply its conclusions or the cheap overview statement that was published; it is the methodology. If the methodology is bad it confuses the debate on shipping and leads us nowhere.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Transport and Communications will be making a further submission to the IAC in which it highlights many of the weaknesses in the draft report. I will be very pleased to make that a public document as soon as I can. I should say, I think in some detail, why I put the blowtorch to the IAC report. First of all, I wish to say that my attack, if you like, on the report cannot be seen as an attack on the Industries Assistance Commission. Honourable senators can search through speeches made in this place and they will not find a record of my getting up every time the IAC brings out a report and attacking it. The IAC has a role to play in government-more often than not a hard role-that is, of devil's advocate. Governments are never bound by IAC reports or their recommendations. Nevertheless, I put it on record now that the Industries Assistance Commission is a necessary part of the government process. However, I am not Robinson Crusoe in my criticisms of the draft report. I wish to go to three different groups. The first group I wish to quote is the Australian National Maritime Association. Mr Bill Bolitho, the Chairman of the Association, said:
Ship owners were deeply disappointed with the report's naivety and lack of objectivity.

The cheap rates talked about in the report reflect the past serious world over supplying of shipping-the impact of which has been reducing in recent months. For example, freight rates between Australia and Japan have doubled in the last 12 months.
Mr Max Moore-Wilton, the Managing Director of Australian National Line, described the report in the following terms:
Notable for its inadequate financial analysis and the subjective nature of much of its commentary.
Would do little to assist the necessary restructuring of Australia's maritime and waterfront industries.
The combined maritime unions described it as follows:
Appears to indicate blind acceptance of a series of assertions.
Coupled with a shallow, negative approach to the positive features of the Australian shipping industry.

I go to those points not as absolute proof but to say that a variety of people have the same belief as me that this report is inadequate. My general criticism of the report is that it is too one-sided; it is highly theoretical and, quite frankly, it ignores reality. I will go through my specific criticisms in some detail. When one puts out a Press release and says one does not like a report, people say, `All you are trying to do is shoot the messenger. All you have been doing is being shallow in your criticisms of it'. If I put out a 10- or 12-page Press report we know what would happen to it. People would read the first page and throw the other nine pages away. So I intend right now to put on record my criticisms of that report. Firstly, this inquiry was supposed to have produced a factual report. I refer honourable senators to John Button's Press release when this reference was made. The third paragraph states:
The reference differs from most past references in that it seeks an information report on the industry, rather than recommendations.

That was the direction given. If honourable senators read the reference they will see that it was not like a normal reference to the IAC. What we sought at the time was a factual report on the shipping industry. We did not direct the IAC to bring in a pro-Government or anti-Government position because, time and time again when we discuss Australian shipping, it is very hard to have a good statistical base that all groups agree to work off and to debate among themselves. Rarely do people in the shipping area compare like with like. So it was a Government decision to send it to an independent body which would say dispassionately, `What are the costs of Australian shipping?'. That was the intention. The intention was not to have right through the report especially in the overview section, a whole raft of implied recommendations. The IAC was asked specifically not to put in any recommendations. Therefore, I feel quite entitled to say that we are paying the IAC good money, we sent it a reference, it ignored that reference and ignored its riding instructions and has put in its own implied recommendations.

If one reads the terms of reference one sees that the waterfront was specifically excluded. Yet right throughout the IAC report the waterfront gets a big mention. I have not come in here tonight to say that everything on the waterfront is fine. I would be foolish to say that. But this report was meant to deal with shipping. There are differences, in terms of costs to freight, between the costs of possible inefficiencies in shipping and inefficiencies on the waterfront. In those two major areas the IAC has brought down implied recommendations and has ignored the fact that it was sent away to establish a database from which rational debate could ensue.

As well as that, we find gratuitous insults addressed to the Inter-State Commission. These are not justified in the report. The report says that the Inter-State Commission in its dealings with the waterfront is ineffective and useless. I wonder whether the IAC talked to Ted Butcher? Did it really make an investigation as to whether the Inter-State Commission was effective? Even though this inquiry was not in the terms of reference we have these gratuitous insults from one body about another.

My second criticism simply relates to the lack of intellectual rigour that went into the report. I really feel like asking for a refund. All criticisms of the shipping industry seem to have been taken at face value. Therefore, one could have put any canard to the IAC and it would be run holus-bolus in the overview. The Commission does not bring any independent critical analysis to bear. It does not ask: `Are these assertions true or not?'. It simply did not do that. I can tell Senator Hamer that that was irrespective of the fact that no group appeared before the Commission that was critical of those things. Even so, conceding that, the Commission should have applied some intellectual rigour and asked: `Are these assertions credible?'. It did not do that. It just regurgitated quotes without any rigour and without any analysis. I expect more of a Government agency, which has a great record in bringing down many great reports, than the adoption of this approach.

My third criticism is that the report takes a very theoretical approach. It virtually ignores reality absolutely. In this report there is no attempt to do a benefit-cost ratio analysis of its approach. It is as though it is setting up a pure model, like most economists do. The first words one learns in economics are, `on the assumption that'. In regard to this report there are many assumptions made and many realities of life that are totally ignored. For example, it is being said, `You can do this to the shipping industry because we are assuming that X, Y and Z could never occur; that there will be no reaction to doing it'. That makes the report not only unbalanced but also of no particular use to a government as guidance.

Of course consistently in that report we have a very contemptuous attitude to shipowners and unions. Of course, the report contains factual errors. I have described those errors as minor. However, they are not to be dismissed with the flip of the hand, as Senator Hamer has done tonight. While they do not necessarily detract from all the conclusions in the report, because so many factual mistakes and inconsistencies exist it would be very easy to say that this report was badly researched and superficial. I think that I will just spend some time on that question and probably note five of the factual errors.

The report dismisses the capacity of the Crawford and the Maritime Industry Development Committee (MIDC) schemes to achieve efficiency gains. This is on page 7-4 of the report. In fact, the Crawford scheme resulted in a 25 per cent reduction in crew size on affected ships. The MIDC scheme will result in further improvements of up to 33 per cent, on average, compared with existing ships. As an example, the capacity to ship alumina into Victoria from Western Australia has tripled in three years, but the crew required to do this job has stayed about the same-because of changes brought about by Crawford and the MIDC. That does not detract from the rest of Senator Hamer's case. However, the Commission fails to acknowledge that in this report. I ask Senator Hamer why that is so. Why would the Commission deliberately ignore those sorts of improvements and just blast the unions and the shipowners?

My second point is that the report implies in two sections, 4-14 and 6-3, that under current legislation foreign flag vessels do not pay fuel excise while carrying coastal cargoes. This is simply not true. Foreign flag vessels carrying coastal cargoes pay excise, unless the coastal component of the total cargo is less than a small predetermined percentage-about 10 per cent. That is another major error.

My third point relates to the statement on page 2-20 that, `Ship owners make payments to the pool, and the pool pays all seamen'. This is incorrect. Although ship operators do contribute to the pool for attendance payments and long service leave, wages are paid directly to crew members from shipowners and operators. My fourth point is that the report repeats the claim by some of the participants at the hearings that the Department takes industrial relations considerations into account in its administration of the single voyage permit, the SVP system. This is simply not true. It has not been true while I have been Minister, and it has not been true for my predecessors. The Department administers the publicly available guidelines in a fully professional manner and industrial relations factors simply are not considered. That is the fourth occasion of a simple factual error.

I will go to the last error, before I move on to one of the major inconsistencies. The report asserts that the Australian National Line (ANL) has paid dividends to the Commonwealth totalling $8.3m in the past 20 years. In fact, any research will tell us that ANL has paid dividends of $17m over the last three years to the Government. In fact, the whole attitude towards ANL in the IAC report is a joke. I remind honourable senators opposite that when they left government in 1983 they left ANL technically bankrupt. They left it absolutely bankrupt. If it had been a private firm, it would have been made insolvent and dismissed. We have had to do a lot to turn around ANL's performance. It has meant that it has had to shed ships. We have taken a ruthlessly commercial approach in the running of ANL and it is now starting to pay dividends and starting to pay taxes.

I move on to the question of inconsistencies. There are inconsistencies in the report in the interpretation of the Navigation Act. On page 3-12 it is stated that the capital costs of Australian ships are influenced by the accommodation standards of the Act, whereas on page 6-2 it is correctly implied that crew accommodation standards are determined by the normal processes of industrial negotiation. The report says one thing on one page and a couple of pages later makes a different statement. Again, where is the intellectual rigour? The report leaves itself open to those groups that do not want any reform on the waterfront to say, `Look at this report. Look at these factual errors. Look at all these inconsistencies'.

I move now to another inconsistency. That I have difficulty accepting claims at face value is illustrated by the apparent inconsistency between the following two statements. First, the report stated on page 2-7 that coastal shipments of crude oil cost Australian refineries $30m to $35m per annum more than they would at prevailing international shipping rates. Later on the report states that the protection given to the Australian oil tanker fleet alone costs between $90m and $160m per annum. That is another inconsistency found on page 6-4 of the report. Therefore, it is quite easy to say and to show why I am so disappointed in the report when it has those sorts of factual errors and those sorts of inconsistencies.

I raise now the central question of cabotage because this report says that cabotage should no longer exist. It says that Australian coastal shipping should be open to all sorts of international competition. That is the thesis of the report. I might say that cabotage has been in the Act since between 1912 and 1921. No other government in Australia has ever touched it. I argue-I am waiting to hear honourable senators opposite argue against it-that coastal shipping is part of our domestic transport system. It would be interesting for me to hear honourable senators opposite say that part of our domestic transport system should have foreign crewed ships or foreigners involved. I wonder where that ends? Does it end in our saying, `Well, because we have opened up coastal shipping we will now have guest workers in the railways'? Does it mean that we will have guest workers in the trucking industry, or the airline industry, and then that we will move on to have guest workers in the hospitality and tourism industries?

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't have monopolies.

—A lot of different people may or may not have monopolies. What Senator Hamer is arguing for is for guest workers to come into this country. He is arguing that the cheap labour countries should provide labour to this country. Where is it going to stop? Maybe we should start to get some guest workers in the political area so that opposite we can have Senator Pinochet, Senator Botha and Senator Marcos. We could get them in a lot cheaper than honourable senators opposite cost. We will have some guest politicians.

SPEECH.PARA: The real point about this is that coastal shipping is a part of our domestic transport service. It would be equally ridiculous for me to say that Australian ships should not be open to all sorts of competition on the international run. Of course they are. They live and die by that; they have to survive in that area. But if, as the Opposition says, it would open up the Australian coast to guest workers, where would it stop? I hope that at the time of the next election members of the Opposition will go to all the railway shops and truck depots and say, `Look, we have introduced guest workers to the coastal run and you are next; come and vote for us. We will put you out of your job by introducing low paid workers. How do you like that?'. Of course they would not like that.
We do not entirely preclude overseas crewed ships from the Australian run if no Australian ship can do the work.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you allow guest workers?

—No, Senator; where there is no Australian alternative we grant a single voyage permit. While I am on the subject, I was interested to read the rather shallow editorial in today's Age, which naturally jumped on the bandwagon. It basically says the same as the Opposition-open it up to foreigners. It was only four weeks ago that we heard all the reporters and the management of the Age squealing like stuck pigs, pleading, `Save us from foreign ownership. Please, Labor Government, intervene and protect us because we cannot have Robert Maxwell or some other overseas person come in and own us'. How absolutely hypocritical of the Age. It is no wonder that every morning I go to the Sun first. I usually leave the Age till last, and it is no wonder when we have this sort of hypocrisy.

SPEECH.PARA: The real crux of the draft report on coastal shipping comes down to the analysis of cost and freight savings. The report estimates that the abolition of cabotage would save between 20 and 50 per cent in freight rates. These figures are badly out of date, and they are based on spot rates at the time of a depressed international market. Again, the report does not allow us to compare like with like; it has gone to the bottom of a depressed market and used spot rates. The crews on any Australian coastal shipping operation cost only 15 per cent of the freight rate. That is something to remember. So, even if we sacked all the crews and manned the ships with robots at no cost, we would make a saving of only 15 per cent. Yet the report refers to a 20 to 50 per cent saving in its opening remarks on cost. It is true that the really hard area for freight costs is on the waterfront, and that is an area that has to be looked at. But it is a bit unfair to load all these costs onto shipping in the way that this report has done.

The report has inflated its 20 to 50 per cent penalty to a national economic penalty of between $300m and $700m. Of course, these figures are based on inappropriate 1980-81 Australian Bureau of Statistics input-output tables. If we convert them back in dollar terms to per tonne figures, we get a saving of between $7 and $16 per tonne. The figures of the Department of Transport and Communications show that the costs figure of $17 per tonne or less applies to 75 per cent of the coastal trade. So what the report is really saying is that we could get up to a $16 or $17 per tonne saving by getting foreign ships in. The quite logical conclusion from that is that those ships would carry everything for nothing. What an absurd proposition! The report incorrectly assumes that foreign vessels do not pay fuel excise.

TALK.START.PARA: —You need some intellectual rigour there. It says $7, not $17.

—It says $7; I said at the extreme. Senator Baume should listen. The report says that the savings could be from $7 to $16. If the upper limit of $16 were to be given credibility, the ships involved would have to carry most Australian cargo at $1 per tonne, or for nothing.
—That is rubbish!

—I will listen to the honourable senator later about that. He should go and read the report, apply some sort of intellectual analysis and then let us know what he has to say about it. What is really involved here is a case of taking the assumptions expressed in evidence given only by biased people, pumping them into an econometric model and getting the results out the other end. The reality is that if we put garbage into an econometric model, we will get garbage out the other end.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not spend a lot of time on this report but it simply fails to acknowledge or have the decency to say that there have been some changes in the shipping industry. The Crawford reforms and the Maritime Industry Development Committee have gone some of the way, virtually all in the life of this Government. This report just ignores that. It again gives an unbalanced approach. I wonder what is has to say about areas such as safety. It is not simply a matter of bringing flag of convenience ships onto the Australian run. How many flag of convenience ships have sunk like a rock in the last few years because of poor safety standards? It would be like saying that we want to bring in some cheap South American airline, with its air safety standards, to do a domestic run. I believe that there is a need for reform in the Australian shipping industry. I will not walk away from that. But I look at the long term consequences of what is for the good of this country and I say that changes are best when they come by evolutionary rather than revolutionary means. That we need change is recognised by the unions. The unions have changed, and they have changed in good faith. Changes are most effective when they are well thought out and put into effect. If those opposite want to take that as timidity, they may do so.

I want to point out in my concluding five minutes the massive hypocrisy of the Liberal Party-the good old boys of the Liberal Party, gung ho in opposition and pussy cats in government. Those opposite are the great regulators. When they were in power did they deregulate the Navigation Act? Of course not. They are the great `gunnas'. They were `gunna' float the dollar but they did not. They were `gunna' introduce foreign banks as competition. They were `gunna' introduce tax reform. We have the great `gunnas' of politics sitting on the Opposition benches and saying, `We need revolutionary change'. But the moment the Opposition gets in power it is the harshest regulator since Stalin ruled Russia. It is virtually Stalinist in its desire for central control and regulation. When Opposition members get really guilty they race off to a Liberal Party conference, get excited about free enterprise and talk theory, and then come back to Canberra and ask themselves how many new regulations they can think up. They do not deregulate the economy. I predict that if and when the Opposition ever gets into government it will not do away with cabotage. It will not open up the coast to foreign competition; it will just regulate it more than ever.

This Government has delivered in the shipping area not to the ideal extent but at least with the cooperation of shipowners and maritime unions. When we came into government the basic crew size was 38. Even if we were unfortunate enough to lose Government in 1990, the crew size would be well on the way to 21. We have integrated ratings. We no longer have the social snobbery of the sea where the captain has a mess in one corner and the crew has the rest. We have set up facilities at the Australian Maritime College to provide integrated training. Senator Hamer mentioned the radio operators. They may be going in the next two or three years as we get multi-skilling in the work force. This is one of the areas where multi-skilling has had priority. We have not had to hold a gun at the unions' head. They know what the future is. The future of Australian shipping involves multi-skilling, reduced levels of manning and trying to make Australia competitive not only on the coast but in the international area. We as a government brought in the Ships (Capital Grants) Act to make grants to companies that modified their ships to bring in the 21 crew size.

Senator Hamer said today that he agreed with the conclusions of the report. He spent very little time trying to justify how the IAC got to those conclusions, and well he should have spent little time on that because it got to the conclusions in the wrong way. It got to the conclusions only by repeating the evidence of vested interests. It did not use the necessary intellectual rigour to assess whether that evidence was any good. In the next months we will be faced with a debate on the future of the shipping industry. It is a debate in which I am going to become vigorously involved without fear or favour, without pandering to unions, shipowners or anyone else. But I very much doubt the firepower of the Liberal Party on this issue. Senator Hamer, on the variety of occasions that he has addressed shipping issues, although I do not agree with him, has brought some force and some integrity into the argument. But every time the Opposition's shadow Minister in the other place addresses shipowners or seagoing personnel, they all shake their heads afterwards and say, `Who is this bloke? How come he knows nothing about it?'. Even the right wing groups that want to get support for their reform dismiss him as a lightweight, and that is a pity.

I will be opposing Senator Hamer's motion. I was disappointed with the IAC report. I am not attacking the Commission per se, but this report deserves to be dumped on. However, it is not the end of the world. We have public hearings, and I assume that everyone from all over the place will be making submissions. I look forward to a more balanced and intellectually honest report when the final draft comes out, and one that will contribute to a constructive debate in this country. That was the initial intention-not to bring down a right wing, macho, free- marketeer document so that we could go away feeling pure that we had achieved these theoretical models. It does not help. There is a real world. Those in the Opposition do not have to live in it, but we in the Government do. I say, in conclusion, that we are committed to reforms in the shipping area but not at the cost of disrupting the whole of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Hamer's motion, and I repeat it:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) endorses the findings of the Draft Report of the Industries Assistance Commission on Coastal Shipping that coastal shipping in Australia is uncompetitive and inefficient;
(b) notes the disastrous effect on the Australian economy of the high costs of coastal shipping; and

(c) condemns the Government for its negative reaction to this Report and urges the Government to take immediate action to prevent inefficient coastal shipping services further jeopardising growth and employment opportunities in the rest of the economy.

Let us apply some intellectual rigour to Senator Robert Ray's nonsense tonight. That is where the intellectual rigour ought to be applied. Let us note what his Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said about this report. On page 2141 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 27 April-

TALK.START.PARA: —Quote the lot of it. Quote the piece before.
—If I had more than seven minutes and if the Government had not mucked up the arrangements for the day, I could quote further. Let me quote this. It is not good enough. The Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I endorse the broad conclusion of the report. I do not think that any person interested in the Australian waterfront scene would not do so.

That is, anyone except Senator Robert Ray, because he says that Senator Hamer is wrong to endorse the findings of the draft report. And why is Senator Hamer wrong? He is wrong not because the answers that the Industries Assistance Commission has come up with are wrong, but because, according to Senator Robert Ray, the IAC got to the answers the wrong way. Senator Ray has yet to demonstrate that the answers themselves are wrong, and that, I put to the Senate, is the total incompetence of the speech he made tonight. By drawing attention to some matters in the analysis where some errors were certainly made, by attacking the methodology and by attacking the fact that this report went outside its terms of reference and annoyed the Government, he has tried to denigrate the answers that he cannot himself denigrate. In all honesty-and I commend him for his honesty-he has not sought to denigrate the answers; he sought only to denigrate the methods by which the answers were achieved. So here we have an attempt to smear this report and to damn Senator Hamer's motion in a politically adept way which lacks intellectual rigour.

Let us see why the Government and Senator Ray are so upset. Very simply, it is because this report attacks very effectively the method that this Government has applied so far to fix up this matter, which is now at crisis levels for the Australian economy. Because it is at crisis levels there is an urgent need for this Government to do something about it and to change its slow, steady and ponderous approach. Like the honourable senator's method of departure from the chamber, its approach is in exactly the same ponderous style. There is a need for sudden and urgent action, because of the crisis Australia faces in its balance of payments and in its economy in general, largely as a result of five years of this Government, to fix up this disaster on the wharves. This IAC report explains why something has to be done and why the Government's present policy is incompetent and inadequate. The report states:

Current initiatives are not stemming increases in the costs coastal shipping impose on the rest of the economy. Real and lasting benefits will only come from fundamental reform of both the blue-water and shore-based components of the industry. Because Australia can ill afford to sustain an inefficient coastal shipping industry-
Mr Keating has agreed, as reported in Hansard, that Australia has an inefficient coastal shipping industry-
which jeopardises growth and job opportunities elsewhere in the economy, the need for reform is urgent.

We heard Senator Ray saying, `Would it not be dreadful if these guest employees were to take Australian jobs?'. These are guest employees, by the way, which the Government already endorses when visiting ships are helping out around the coast. The point that this report makes is that the inefficiencies and the incompetence of the Australian coastal shipping industry are destroying and have destroyed the jobs of thousands of Australians by preventing many industries from upgrading, for example, raw materials before they are exported and by denying the prospect of industries to be efficient and competent because of the enormous costs of coastal shipping which price them out of their markets. Let us look at another of the conclusions of the report which damn the Government. It states:

The Government has instigated a Waterfront Strategy, essentially involving problem solving by consensus. The Commission found little optimism in the industry, or among users, that this strategy would achieve significant or lasting improvements.

Now we know why this Government and this Minister are so keen to damn this report; it is utterly damning of the Government's incompetence. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard-I have discussed this before with the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray)-the findings of the report which the Treasurer finds so attractive and which he supports.
Leave granted.
The findings read as follows-

PROCTEXT.PARA: On the evidence to date, the Commission has made the following findings:
Coastal shipping in Australia is inefficient and has jeopardised growth and employment prospects elsewhere in the economy.

Inefficiencies have developed in an environment which imposes little discipline on costs, fails to reward better performance and stifles incentive with a set of complex regulations. Complacency about costs and the quality of service is an inevitable result.
A major factor producing this outcome is the insulation from foreign competition currently afforded Australian flagged vessels.
High costs and poor quality of service impose unnecessary burdens on current users-chiefly those involved in export-oriented bulk cargoes and those transporting goods to and from Tasmania.

While current users have little alternative, many potential users have avoided the costs of an inefficient coastal shipping industry by turning to other modes of transport. However, they still pay more than they would if efficient coastal shipping services were available.

The Commission has estimated that excessive coastal shipping freight rates (of between 20 and 50 per cent) wipe off between $300 million and $700 million from Australia's gross domestic product annually-a penalty equivalent to adding between $7 and $16 to the cost of every tonne of cargo transported by ship around the coast, or between $35,000 and $80,000 annually for every worker employed in the industry (on board and on shore).
The cost of coastal shipping has encouraged exports of raw materials at the expense of further processing within Australia.

I thank the Senate. I thank the Senate. The reason I wanted those tables in Hansard is that they deny some of the nonsense that Senator Robert Ray gave us tonight, and certainly deny the merit of the quotes that the Minister gave from Mr Bill Bolitho of the Australian National Maritime Association.
Senator Hamer-And Chairman of the ANL.

TALK.START.PARA: —And, of course, Chairman of the Australian National Line. He was put up here as a man who could provide us with an objective, not a subjective, view of the situation, a man who was closely and totally involved in the present monopolistic situation on the Australian waterfront, the present cosy club. The Minister cites this man as someone who should be taken seriously in this kind of discussion. He said that ship crews were only 14 or 15 per cent of shipping costs. He tried to present that as a pretty much across the board situation, encouraging him to say that it would not matter if coastal ships were crewed with robots-there would be no real savings in freight rates while they had to use Australia's inefficient ports and pay all the extra costs. The reality is that the great bulk of Australian shipping involves ship-based costs representing something like 70 per cent of the total costs of transport in some instances and 68 per cent in others. That is why this table is of great merit. It indicates just what the scope for saving really is. Of course, we can see that, because of the enormous impact of wharfing costs, it was natural that the IAC should extend itself to look at that area. I commend it for doing so, and I think the Minister ought to commend it for doing so.
